Number System.question: Which one of the following is not correct?
Number System.c: If p × q is even, then p and q are always even
Number System.comment: p × q even implies at least one is even, not both.

Number System.question: If n is a natural number, then √n is
Number System.d: Either a natural number or an irrational number
Number System.comment: √n is natural for perfect squares, irrational otherwise.

Number System.question: Which one of the following is correct?
Number System.a: Decimal expansion of a rational number is terminating
Number System.b: Decimal expansion of a rational number is non-terminating
Number System.c: Decimal expansion of an irrational number is terminating and non-repeating
Number System.d: Decimal expansion of an irrational number is non-terminating and non-repeating
Number System.comment: Irrational numbers have non-terminating, non-repeating decimals.

Number System.question: All prime numbers up to 110 are multiplied together. What is the unit digit in this product?
What is the value of x for which x, x+1 and x+3 are all prime numbers?
If N²−33, N²−31 and N²−29 are prime numbers, then what is the number of possible values of N, where N is an integer?
Number System.comment: Only pair of prime no. with a gap of 2 is 3,5,7; N²−33=3, N²=36, N=(-6,6) .

Number System.question: The sum of three prime numbers is 100. If one of them exceeds another by 36, then one of the numbers is

Consider the following statements:
1. Of two consecutive integers one is even.
2. Square of an odd integer is of the form 8n +1.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
Number System.comment: Both statements hold true for integers.

Number System.question: Which one of the following rational numbers has non-terminating and repeating decimal expansion?

Consider the following statements in respect of two integers p and q (both >1) which are relatively prime:
1. Both p and q may be odd numbers.
2. Both p and q may be prime numbers.
3. One of p and q may be composite number.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
Number System.comment: All combinations are possible for relatively prime numbers.

Number System.question: Which of the following statements is not true?
Number System.a: The difference of two prime numbers, both greater than 2, is divisible by 2
Number System.b: For two different integers m, n and a prime number p, if p divides the product m x n, then P divides either m or n
Number System.c: If a number is of the form 6n - 1 (n being a natural number), then it is a prime number.
Number System.d: There is only one set of three prime numbers such that there is a gap of 2 between two adjacent prime numbers

Number System.question: 'AB' is a 2 digit prime number where A is not equal to B. If the digits are reversed new number 'BA' is also a prime number. Then find sum of all such numbers.
There are numbers which are co-prime to each other, are such that the product of the first two is 286 and that of the last two is 770. What is the sum of the numbers?
x, y and z are prime numbers and x + y + z = 38. What is the maximum value of x?
N is the smallest three digit prime number. When N is divided by 13, then what will be the remainder?
How many pairs of natural numbers are there such that the difference of their squares is 35?
How many pairs of natural numbers are there such that the difference of their squares is 40?
Suppose n is a positive integer such that n²+48 is a perfect square. What is the number of such n?
What is the sum of all integer values of n for which n²+19n+92 is a perfect square?
The sum of the digits of a number 10^n-1, where n is a natural number, is equal to 3798, then what is the value of n?
The sum of two positive numbers is 14 and difference between their squares is 28, what is the sum of their cubes?
The product of three consecutive positive integers is 15600. Then the sum of the squares of these integers is
The sum of the squares of two natural consecutive odd numbers is 394. The sum of the numbers is
Let a, b and c be the fractions such that a = b + c. If c is divided by a, the result is 1/2. If a + b + c =1, then a - b = ?
If I = a² + b² + c² , where a and b are consecutive integers and c = ab, then I is
Number System.a: An even number and it is not a square of an integer
Number System.b: An odd number and it is a square of an integer

Profit and Loss.question: A shopkeeper sold an article for Rs. 250 and made a profit of 25%. What was the cost price of the article?
A man buys an article for Rs. 150 and sells it for Rs. 180. What is his profit percentage?
A shopkeeper marks an article at Rs. 500 and offers a discount of 20%. If he still makes a profit of 25%, what is the cost price?
By selling an article for Rs. 600, a shopkeeper incurs a loss of 20%. What is the cost price?
A trader sells an item at a loss of 10%, but if he had sold it for Rs. 50 more, he would have gained 5%. What is the cost price?
A shopkeeper buys an item for Rs. 400 and sells it for Rs. 480. What is his profit percentage?
An article is sold for Rs. 300 at a loss of 25%. What was the cost price?
A man buys 12 oranges for Rs. 48 and sells 8 oranges for Rs. 40. What is his profit percentage?
Profit and Loss.comment: CP per orange = 48 / 12 = 4, SP per orange = 40 / 8 = 5, Profit % = (5 - 4) / 4 × 100 = 25%.

A dealer advertises that he sales his goods at cost price. But he uses 950 gm for 1 kg weight. Find his gain or loss percentage.
A shopkeeper bought 30 books and sold 25 books for same price. What percentage had he gained or lost?

A shopkeeper claims to sell 450 kg rice at a cost price of ₹40 per kg but uses a weight of 900 grams instead of a one kilogram weight. He makes a profit of ₹2,520 by selling the remaining rice in the black market. The ratio of the black-market price to the original price per kg of rice is:
Profit and Loss.comment: Profit from 450 kg at 900g = 450 × 40 × 0.1 = 1800, Black market profit = 2520 - 1800 = 720, Black market price = 720 / 12.86 ≈ 56, Ratio = 56 : 40 = 7 : 5.

Profit and Loss.question: A vendor buys 20 pens for ₹15 and sells them at 15 for ₹20. How many pens should be bought and sold to earn a profit of ₹245?
Profit and Loss.comment: CP per pen = 15 / 20 = 0.75, SP per pen = 20 / 15 ≈ 1.33, Profit per pen = 0.58, Pens = 245 / 0.58 ≈ 420.

Profit and Loss.question: A shopkeeper normally makes a profit of 20% in a certain transaction; he weighed 900 gm instead of 1 kg due to an error in the weighing machine. If he charges 15% less than what he normally charges, then what is his actual profit or loss percentage?

A dealer buys an article listed at ₹250 and gets successive discounts of 12% and 16%. He spends 10% of the cost price on transportation. At what price should he sell the article to earn a profit of 25%? (Correct to two places of decimal)
Sukrit purchased an item for ₹650 and sold it at a profit of 26%. At what price (in ₹) did Sukrit sell the item?

The percentage profit earned by selling an article for ₹2,100 is equal to the percentage loss incurred by selling the same article for ₹1,460. At what price should the article be sold to make 20% profit?
Sohan sells sugar at cost price but he uses faulty weight and thus earns a profit of 28%. How many g (grams) of sugar is he giving in exchange of 3.2 kg of sugar?
The cost of 4 chairs and 3 tables is ₹2,100 and the cost of 5 chairs and 2 tables is ₹1,750. Find the cost (in ₹) of a chair.

A dishonest shopkeeper sells rice at a cost price but makes a 25% profit by using faulty weights. He decides to give a discount to attract more customers. What percent of discount should he offer to make 10% profit?

B purchased 15 kg apples at the rate of ₹180 per kg from a wholesaler who uses a weight of 950 grams for the kg weight. B sold all these apples at ₹180 per kg but used a weight of 750 grams for the kg weight. Find the percentage profit earned by B in the transaction (correct to 2 places of decimal).
The cost of 2 pencils and 3 pens is ₹55 and the cost of 7 pencils and 2 pens is ₹65. What is the total price (in ₹) of one pen and one pencil?

The first shirt is sold at twice the selling price of the second shirt. The first shirt is sold at 8% profit and the second shirt is sold at a 3% loss. What is the overall percentage profit on the shirts (Rounded off to two decimal place)?

However, Sukhvir managed to sell the rest of the items at a price that helped him earn an overall profit of 19%. At what percentage above the cost price of each item purchased by Sukhvir did he sell each of the items that did not go bad?

A vendor marked the selling price of a table at ₹5,670 after adding 35% profit to its cost price. Since the sale was very low at this price level, he decided to sell the table with 12% profit. Find the new selling price (in ₹).

What is the overall percentage profit made by the company, distributor, and retailer combined?

A medical store owner purchased medicines worth ₹18,000 from a company. He sold 2/5 part of the medicine at a 35% loss. On which gain, he should sell the rest of the medicines so that he has neither gain nor loss?

Praveen sells a study table to Zoya at a loss of 10%, and Zoya sells the study table to Aadarsh at a profit of 25%. If Aadarsh purchased the study table for ₹2,250, then what was the cost (in ₹) of the study table for Praveen?
Profit and Loss.comment: CP for Zoya = 2250 / 1.25 = 1800, CP for Praveen = 1800 / 0.9 = 2000.

Profit and Loss.comment: CP per bag = 13000 / 20 = 650, SP per bag = 10125 / 15 = 675, Profit per bag = 25, Bags = 3225 / 25 = 129.

Profit and Loss.question: On two items of equal prices, T gets 12% profit on one item and incurs 8% loss on other. What is his overall profit or loss percentage?
Profit and Loss.comment: Total CP = 2X, SP1 = X × 1.12, SP2 = X × 0.92, Total SP = 2.04X, Profit % = (2.04X - 2X) / 2X × 100 = 2%.

Square Root.question: When all the students of a school are made to stand in lines to form a square, less than 10 students are left surplus. If the students of the school are 1230, how many students will stand on each line?
Square Root.comment: Largest perfect square ≤ 1230 with remainder < 10 is 1225 = 35², 1230 − 1225 = 5 < 10. So, 35 per line.

Square Root.question: The square of a natural number subtracted from its cube is 48. The number is ______.
Square Root.comment: Let number be n. Solve n³ − n² = 48. For n = 4: 4³ = 64, 4² = 16, 64 − 16 = 48.

Square Root.question: What is the least perfect square number which is exactly divisible by 3, 4, 7, 10, and 12?

A two-digit number has its tens digit as 4 less than thrice the units digit. If the units and tens digits are interchanged, its value decreases by 18. Find the square root of the two-digit number?
Square Root.comment: Let units = u, tens = t. t = 3u − 4, 10u + t = 10t + u − 18. Solve: u = t − 2, t = 5, u = 3. Number = 53, √53 ≈ 7.28.

Square Root.question: The square roots of how many factors of 2250 will be natural numbers?
Square Root.comment: 2250 = 2×3²×5³. Total factors = 24. Square factors: 1, 9, 25, 225 (even exponents), so 4.

Square Root.comment: Sum of first n odd numbers = n². For 5 odds, 5² = 25.

Square Root.comment: Between n² and (n+1)²: 2n numbers. For n = 12, 2×12 = 24.

Units and Dimensions.question: Which of the following is the SI unit of electric current?
Units and Dimensions.comment: Ampere (A) is the SI base unit of electric current.

Units and Dimensions.question: Candela is the unit of _________.
Units and Dimensions.comment: Candela (cd) is the SI base unit of luminous intensity.

Units and Dimensions.question: The SI unit of heat is
Units and Dimensions.comment: Joule (J) is the SI unit of heat energy.

Units and Dimensions.question: Which of the following is the SI unit of energy?
Units and Dimensions.comment: Joule (J) is the SI unit of energy.

Units and Dimensions.question: The SI unit of ‘Work’ and ‘Energy’ is
Units and Dimensions.comment: Work and energy have the same SI unit, joule (J).

Units and Dimensions.question: The SI unit of ‘Power’ is
Units and Dimensions.comment: Power is measured in watt (W), where 1 W = 1 J/s.

Units and Dimensions.question: The SI unit of ‘Capacitance’ is
Units and Dimensions.comment: Farad (F) is the SI unit of capacitance.

Units and Dimensions.question: The SI unit of ‘Resistance’ is
Units and Dimensions.comment: Ohm (Ω) is the SI unit of electrical resistance.

Units and Dimensions.question: The SI unit of ‘Voltage’ is
Units and Dimensions.comment: Volt (V) is the SI unit of electric potential difference.

Units and Dimensions.comment: Siemens (S) is the SI unit of electrical conductance.

Units and Dimensions.comment: Mole (mol) is the SI base unit for amount of substance.

Unit of frequency is

Units and Dimensions.comment: Watt (W) = J/s, SI unit of power.

Motion.question: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
Motion.comment: Displacement has both magnitude and direction; speed and distance are scalars.

Motion.question: Average velocity is defined as:
Motion.comment: Average velocity = net displacement / total time.

Motion.question: If a body returns to its starting point after time T, its average velocity over T is:
Motion.comment: Net displacement is zero, so average velocity is zero.

Motion.question: Instantaneous velocity is the:
Motion.b: Slope of displacement-time graph at a point
Motion.comment: Instantaneous velocity is the derivative (slope) of displacement vs time.

Motion.question: Average acceleration is:
Motion.comment: Average acceleration = Δv/Δt.

Motion.question: If velocity–time graph is a horizontal line (non-zero), acceleration is:
Motion.comment: Horizontal v–t means v constant, so acceleration (slope) is zero.

Motion.question: Area under a velocity–time graph between t1 and t2 gives:
Motion.comment: Integral (area) of v(t) over time = displacement.

Motion.question: For constant acceleration, which equation is incorrect?
Motion.comment: Correct is s = ut + 1/2 at^2; s = vt + 1/2 at^2 is generally incorrect unless u = v.

Motion.question: A body starts from rest with constant acceleration a. Distance covered in nth second is:
Motion.comment: Distance in nth second = s_n = u + a(2n − 1)/2 for u=0 → a(2n−1)/2 (times proper units).

Motion.question: If a particle moves with uniform velocity, the graph of displacement vs time is:
Motion.comment: Uniform velocity → linear relationship between displacement and time.

Motion.question: Which statement is true for instantaneous acceleration?
Motion.a: Slope of v–t graph at a point
Motion.comment: Instantaneous acceleration = derivative (slope) of velocity vs time.

Motion.question: If acceleration is uniform and non-zero, the s–t graph is:
Motion.comment: For constant acceleration s = ut + 1/2 at^2 → parabolic.

Motion.question: A car moving with speed v around a circular track of radius r has centripetal acceleration:
Motion.comment: Centripetal acceleration = v^2/r directed toward the center.

Motion.question: Uniform circular motion means:
Motion.comment: Uniform circular motion: magnitude of velocity constant, direction continuously changes.

Motion.question: Angular speed ω and linear speed v are related by:
Motion.comment: Linear (tangential) speed v = ω r.

Motion.question: Period T of circular motion relates to frequency f as:
Motion.comment: Period is reciprocal of frequency: T = 1/f.

Motion.question: A particle's displacement-time graph is x = 4t − t^2 (SI units). Its initial velocity is:
Motion.comment: Velocity is dx/dt = 4 − 2t; at t=0 v=4 m/s.

Motion.question: Two trains moving in opposite directions with speeds 60 km/h and 40 km/h. Relative speed is:
Motion.comment: Opposite directions add: 60 + 40 = 100 km/h relative speed.

Motion.question: A boat crosses a river of width d with speed v (relative to water) directed perpendicular to banks. If river flows with speed u, time to cross is:
Motion.comment: Time depends only on component perpendicular to bank: t = d / v (boat speed across water).

Motion.question: Range R of a projectile launched with speed u at angle θ (neglecting air resistance) is:
Motion.comment: Range R = (u^2 sin 2θ)/g; note sin 2θ = 2 sinθ cosθ.

Motion.question: Time of flight for a projectile launched at speed u at angle θ is:
Motion.comment: Total time in air = 2u sinθ / g (vertical motion symmetry).

Motion.question: Maximum height H of projectile with initial speed u and angle θ is:
For projectile motion (no air), horizontal component of velocity:
Motion.comment: Horizontal velocity unaffected by gravity (neglecting air resistance).

Motion.question: Maximum horizontal range for a projectile on level ground occurs at angle:
Motion.comment: Range maximized when sin 2θ is 1 → 2θ = 90° → θ = 45°.

Motion.question: If two projectiles are launched with same speed u at complementary angles θ and (90° − θ), then:
Motion.comment: Ranges equal because sin 2θ = sin 2(90−θ). Times and heights generally differ.

Motion.question: A particle with velocity v experiences drag force proportional to v (F ∝ v). Its terminal velocity occurs when:
Motion.comment: Terminal velocity when net force zero: driving (e.g., gravity) = drag.

Motion.question: If a body falls under gravity with air resistance ∝ v^2, terminal velocity v_t varies as:
Motion.comment: For quadratic drag C v_t^2 = mg → v_t ∝ √(mg/C).

Motion.question: Acceleration due to gravity near Earth's surface is approximately:
Motion.comment: Standard acceleration g ≈ 9.8 m/s^2.

Motion.question: A body thrown vertically upward with speed u will reach maximum height when its velocity becomes:
Motion.comment: At highest point vertical velocity is zero.

Motion.question: For straight-line motion with non-zero acceleration, which is true?
Motion.c: Velocity may increase or decrease depending on sign of acceleration
Motion.comment: Sign of acceleration relative to velocity decides whether speed increases or decreases.

Motion.question: If displacement is proportional to square of time (s ∝ t^2), acceleration is:
Motion.comment: s = k t^2 → v = 2k t, a = 2k (constant).

Motion.question: A car slows from 20 m/s to 10 m/s in 5 s. Average acceleration is:
Motion.comment: a = Δv/Δt = (10 − 20)/5 = −2 m/s^2 (negative sign indicates deceleration).

Motion.question: A particle moves such that its velocity is v = 5t (m/s). Its displacement after 2 s is:
Which of the following is path-dependent (non-conservative) in motion problems?
Motion.c: Change in kinetic energy due to net conservative forces
Motion.comment: Friction does path-dependent (non-conservative) work.

Motion.question: If the slope of a displacement–time graph is negative, then:
Motion.comment: Negative slope indicates negative velocity (motion in negative direction).

Motion.question: Area under acceleration–time graph between t1 and t2 gives:
Motion.comment: Integral of a(t) over time equals Δv.

Motion.question: Which of the following is true for motion under constant acceleration starting from rest?
Motion.comment: From s = ut + 1/2 at^2 with u=0 → s ∝ t^2.

Motion.question: Relative velocity of A with respect to B is zero. This implies:
Motion.a: A and B have same speed only
Motion.b: A and B have same velocity (same speed and direction)
Motion.c: A is stationary and B is moving
Motion.comment: Relative velocity zero means they move together (same velocity vector).

Motion.question: If two bodies move with equal and opposite velocities, their relative speed is:
Motion.comment: Relative speed adds when moving in opposite directions: |v1| + |v2|.

Motion.question: A particle moves along x-axis with x = at^3 (a constant). Its acceleration is:
Motion.comment: v = dx/dt = 3a t^2; a = dv/dt = 6a t.

Motion.question: Which of the following quantities can be negative?
Motion.comment: Displacement can be negative depending on chosen direction; distance and speed are non-negative.

Motion.question: If a particle's speed is increasing while acceleration is negative, the particle is:
Motion.comment: Negative acceleration and increasing speed means velocity is negative and magnitude increasing (speed up in negative direction).

Motion.question: Which of these statements about motion in two dimensions is correct (neglecting air resistance)?
Motion.a: Horizontal and vertical motions are dependent
Motion.b: Horizontal and vertical motions are independent
Motion.c: Vertical motion does not obey kinematic equations
Motion.d: Projectile motion is uniform in vertical direction
Motion.comment: Horizontal and vertical motions are independent except common time parameter.

Motion.question: If a particle moves in a straight line and acceleration is always directed toward a fixed point, the motion is:
Motion.comment: If a ∝ −x (toward fixed point and proportional to displacement), motion is SHM.

Motion.question: A cyclist moves along a circular path at constant speed. Work done by centripetal force over one complete revolution is:
Motion.comment: Centripetal force is perpendicular to displacement → no work done.

Motion.question: If a ball is dropped from rest from height h, neglecting air resistance, time to reach ground is:
Motion.comment: From h = 1/2 g t^2 → t = √(2h/g).

Motion.question: Which is true for motion described by x = A cos(ωt + φ)?
Motion.a: It is uniform circular motion when projected on diameter
Motion.b: It is linear motion with constant velocity
Motion.comment: Simple harmonic motion (SHM) can be viewed as projection of uniform circular motion.

Motion.question: A particle moving with velocity u collides elastically with identical stationary particle in one dimension. After collision, the first particle's velocity is:
Motion.comment: In elastic head-on collision between equal masses, moving mass stops and target takes its velocity.

Motion.question: The velocity of center of mass of a system of particles equals:
Motion.comment: V_cm = (Σ m_i v_i) / (Σ m_i) = total momentum / total mass.

Motion.question: Which graph represents motion with constant non-zero acceleration?
Motion.b: v–t straight line with non-zero slope
Motion.comment: Constant non-zero acceleration is constant slope in v–t (straight line with slope = a).

Motion.question: A ball thrown up reaches height H in t seconds. If thrown down with same speed from ground, time to reach same height measured from launch (assuming same magnitude speed) is:
Motion.comment: Times differ because initial vertical direction changed; symmetry applies about peak only for upward shots.

Motion.question: If displacement is given by s = 10t − 4t^2 (SI), maximum displacement occurs at t =:
Which of the following is NOT true about instantaneous speed and instantaneous velocity?
Motion.b: Instantaneous speed is magnitude of instantaneous velocity
Motion.d: Instantaneous velocity is slope of s–t
Motion.comment: Instantaneous speed is scalar (magnitude); velocity is vector.

Motion.question: If v(t) = 4 − 2t (m/s), at what time does the particle stop momentarily?
Motion.comment: Set v = 0 → 4 − 2t = 0 → t = 2 s. (Careful: 4 − 2t = 0 → t=2. Correct option is a.)

Motion.question: Correction for previous question: If v(t) = 4 − 2t (m/s), particle stops at t =
Motion.comment: Solving 4 − 2t = 0 gives t = 2 s.

Motion.question: A particle moves such that acceleration is proportional to displacement (a = −k x). This motion is:
Motion.comment: a = −k x is the SHM condition (restoring acceleration proportional to displacement).

Motion.question: Which of the following statements about instantaneous acceleration is false?
Motion.a: It can be zero while velocity non-zero
Motion.c: It can be negative while speed increases
Motion.d: It is always in direction of motion
Motion.comment: Acceleration need not be along velocity (e.g., circular motion acceleration perpendicular to velocity).

Motion.question: If a particle's velocity is given by v = at − bt^2, the units of a and b (in SI) are:
Motion.comment: Terms must have units of velocity (m/s): at → a has m/s^2; bt^2 → b has m/s^3.

Motion.question: During free fall (neglecting air resistance) acceleration is:
Motion.comment: Free fall acceleration is constant ≈ 9.8 m/s^2 downward.

Motion.question: Two bullets fired horizontally with same initial speed from equal heights but different masses land at same time (neglect air). This is because:
Motion.b: Time of fall independent of horizontal motion and mass
Motion.c: Mass cancels due to air resistance
Motion.comment: Vertical motion determined by gravity only; mass and horizontal speed (if same heights) do not affect fall time.

Motion.question: Which one is true for motion along a curved path?
Motion.a: Velocity and acceleration are always parallel
Motion.b: Acceleration may have components tangential and normal
Motion.comment: Acceleration decomposes into tangential (change of speed) and normal/centripetal (change of direction) components.

Motion.question: If a car negotiates a circular bend of radius r at speed v, minimum coefficient of friction μ between tires and road (no banking) to avoid slipping is:
Motion.comment: Centripetal force mh = m v^2 / r must be ≤ μ m g → μ ≥ v^2/(r g).

Motion.question: If a particle moves such that its position vector r(t) = (3t^2) i + (2t) j (SI), its velocity at t=1 s is:
In projectile motion on inclined plane (angle α), time of flight depends on:
Motion.b: Initial speed, launch angle relative to incline, and g
Motion.comment: Time depends on initial velocity and geometry relative to incline and gravity; mass cancels in gravity-only problems.

Motion.question: Which of the following quantities is conserved for a particle in absence of external forces?
Motion.comment: In absence of external forces, total linear momentum is conserved. Kinetic energy may change in internal interactions.

Motion.question: A body moving in a straight line has velocity-time graph a straight line through origin (v ∝ t). Then acceleration is:
Motion.comment: If v = k t, then a = dv/dt = k (constant).

Motion.question: A particle has displacement x = 2 sin t (SI). Its acceleration at t = π/2 is:
Motion.comment: x = 2 sin t → v = 2 cos t, a = −2 sin t; at t=π/2, a = −2.

Motion.question: Which is true about motion of a body in a straight line if acceleration is proportional to square of time (a ∝ t^2)?
Motion.comment: Integrating a ∝ t^2 → v ∝ t^3 → s ∝ t^4 (constants omitted).

Motion.question: For small oscillations of a simple pendulum, period T is independent of:
Motion.comment: T = 2π√(L/g) (independent of mass; amplitude independence holds for small angles).

Motion.question: If two bodies move such that their relative acceleration is zero, then:
Motion.comment: Zero relative acceleration implies relative velocity is constant (could be zero or non-zero).

Motion.question: When a car accelerates from rest, which of the following quantities increases over time?
Motion.comment: As speed increases, both kinetic energy (1/2 m v^2) and momentum (mv) increase.

Motion.question: A particle describes SHM x = A cos(ωt). What is maximum speed?
Motion.comment: Maximum speed v_max = A ω (occurs at equilibrium position).

Motion.question: A stone tied to string whirled in vertical circle may have different tensions at top and bottom because of:
Motion.comment: Centripetal requirement plus/minus weight changes tension at top/bottom.

Motion.question: Which of the following best describes 'jerk' in kinematics?
Motion.comment: Jerk is da/dt, the derivative of acceleration.

Motion.question: A particle moving in horizontal circle with constant speed v has acceleration:
Motion.comment: Centripetal (inward) acceleration magnitude v^2/r.

Motion.question: Which of the following is dimensionally equivalent to velocity?
Motion.comment: Acceleration (L/T^2) × time (T) = L/T, same as velocity.

Motion.question: If x–t graph is a parabola opening upward, initial velocity is:
Motion.comment: Parabola opening up indicates positive acceleration, but initial velocity sign depends on vertex location; cannot be determined without more info.

Motion.question: Which of the following is true for motion with constant speed in a straight line?
Motion.comment: Constant speed in straight line → velocity constant → acceleration zero.

Motion.question: A particle has velocity components vx = 3 m/s and vy = 4 m/s. Its speed is:
If two particles move with same acceleration and different initial velocities, their relative acceleration is:
Motion.comment: Same acceleration cancels in relative acceleration → zero.

Motion.question: Momentum of a particle is p = m v. If mass is constant and velocity doubles, kinetic energy changes by factor:
Motion.comment: K ∝ v^2; doubling v → K increases by 4.

Motion.question: Which of the following statements about motion in a vertical circle is correct?
Motion.a: Speed at top is always less than at bottom for same energy
Motion.b: Speed at top is greater than bottom
Motion.c: Speeds at top and bottom equal
Motion.comment: Potential energy higher at top, so speed lower (for energy-conserving motion).

Motion.question: A car moving at constant speed negotiates a banked curve with no friction. The banking angle is given by:
Motion.comment: For frictionless banking, horizontal centripetal component arises from normal force: tan θ = v^2/(rg).

Motion.question: If an object moves with velocity v(t) = 10 e^(−t) (SI), its speed decreases exponentially with time. Its acceleration at t = 0 is:
Which of the following best describes terminal speed in presence of air resistance?
Motion.a: Speed at which upward drag equals downward thrust
Motion.b: Maximum speed attained when net force becomes zero
Motion.c: Speed at which gravitational force becomes zero
Motion.d: Speed at which acceleration is maximum
Motion.comment: Terminal speed occurs when net force is zero (weight balanced by drag), so acceleration → 0.

Motion.question: If a particle's displacement is proportional to t^3, then velocity at time t is proportional to:
Motion.comment: Differentiate s ∝ t^3 → v ∝ 3 t^2 → ∝ t^2.

Motion.question: Which of the following is not a kinematic equation for constant acceleration?
Motion.comment: Correct formula is s = ut + 1/2 at^2; s = ut^2 + at is incorrect.

Motion.question: A particle moves in SHM with angular frequency ω. The acceleration at displacement x is:
Motion.comment: SHM: a = −ω^2 x (restoring acceleration).

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by a constant force is defined as:
Work Power Energy.a: Scalar product of force and displacement
Work Power Energy.b: Vector product of force and displacement
Work Power Energy.comment: Work W = F · s = F s cosθ (scalar product).

Work Power Energy.question: SI unit of work and energy is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work and energy are measured in joules (1 J = 1 N·m).

Work Power Energy.question: If a force of 10 N acts on a body and produces a displacement of 5 m in the direction of the force, the work done is:
Work done by gravitational force when a mass falls freely from height h (mass m) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: If taken as work done by gravity, W = +mg h (gravity does positive work while object moves downward).

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by a force perpendicular to displacement is:
Work Power Energy.comment: If θ = 90°, cosθ = 0 → W = 0.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by centripetal force on a particle in uniform circular motion over one complete circle is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Centripetal force is always perpendicular to instantaneous displacement → no work done.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by frictional force is usually:
Work Power Energy.comment: Friction opposes motion, so it does negative work (removes mechanical energy).

Work Power Energy.question: A force F acts at an angle 60° to displacement s. The work done is proportional to:
Work Power Energy.comment: W = F s cosθ → cos60° = 1/2 factor.

Work Power Energy.question: Kinetic energy of a body of mass m and speed v is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Translational kinetic energy K = ½ m v^2.

Work Power Energy.question: Potential energy due to gravity near Earth's surface (taking zero at reference) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Gravitational potential energy relative to a reference: U = m g h.

Work Power Energy.question: Work-energy theorem states:
Work Power Energy.a: Net work done = change in potential energy
Work Power Energy.b: Net work done = change in kinetic energy
Work Power Energy.comment: Net work by all forces on a particle = ΔK.

Work Power Energy.question: Power is defined as:
Work Power Energy.comment: Power P = W / t (rate of doing work).

Work Power Energy.question: SI unit of power is:
Work Power Energy.comment: 1 watt (W) = 1 J/s.

Work Power Energy.question: Instantaneous power delivered by a force F acting on a particle moving with velocity v is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Instantaneous power P = F · v.

Work Power Energy.question: If a body moves with constant velocity v under force F in same direction, the power is:
Work Power Energy.comment: P = F v for collinear F and v.

Work Power Energy.question: Potential energy stored in a spring obeying Hooke's law (spring constant k) when stretched by x is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Elastic potential U = ½ k x^2.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by the spring force in stretching from x1 to x2 is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Spring force is conservative; work by spring = −ΔU = −½ k (x2^2 − x1^2).

Work Power Energy.question: A conservative force is characterized by:
Work Power Energy.comment: Conservative forces have zero net work over any closed loop.

Work Power Energy.question: Which of the following is a conservative force?
Work Power Energy.comment: Gravity is conservative; friction and drag are non-conservative dissipative forces.

Work Power Energy.question: Mechanical energy of a system is:
Work Power Energy.a: Sum of kinetic and potential energies
Work Power Energy.b: Difference between kinetic and potential energies
Work Power Energy.comment: Mechanical energy E = K + U.

Work Power Energy.question: If only conservative forces act on a system, then mechanical energy is:
Work Power Energy.comment: In absence of non-conservative forces, total mechanical energy is conserved.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by a variable force F(x) from x=a to x=b is:
Work Power Energy.b: Integral from a to b of F(x) dx
Work Power Energy.comment: W = ∫_a^b F(x) dx for one-dimensional variable force.

Work Power Energy.question: A block of mass m is pulled with constant force F through displacement d on a frictionless horizontal surface. Change in kinetic energy is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Net work = F d = ΔK (work–energy theorem).

Work Power Energy.question: A car of mass m increases its speed from u to v. The net work done on car is:
Work Power Energy.comment: ΔK = ½ m (v^2 − u^2).

Work Power Energy.question: If a force does negative work on a particle, the particle's kinetic energy will:
Work Power Energy.comment: Negative net work reduces kinetic energy (ΔK = W_net).

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by weight of an object when lifted slowly up by height h is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work done by gravity during upward displacement is negative: W_grav = −mg h.

Work Power Energy.question: If a person climbs stairs of height h at constant speed, the work done by the person (against gravity) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work done by the person (external agent) equals increase in potential energy mg h.

Work Power Energy.question: Efficiency of a machine is defined as:
Work Power Energy.comment: Efficiency (%) = (useful output work ÷ input work) × 100%.

Work Power Energy.question: A crane lifts 2000 kg to a height of 10 m in 20 s. Work done (ignoring friction) is approximately (take g = 9.8 m/s^2):
Work Power Energy.comment: Work = m g h = 2000 × 9.8 × 10 = 196000 J = 1.96×10^5 J. Wait — careful: 2000×9.8=19600; ×10=196000 J. That matches option a. (Correct answer is a).

Work Power Energy.question: Correction for previous question: Work done = 2000 × 9.8 × 10 = 196000 J, so the correct option is:
Average power of crane in previous problem (work 1.96×10^5 J in 20 s) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: P = W/t = 1.96×10^5 / 20 = 9800 W. Wait — calculate: 196000/20 = 9800 W. So correct option should be a. (Corrected below.)

Work Power Energy.question: Correction: Average power = 196000 J / 20 s = 9800 W, so the correct choice is:
Work Power Energy.comment: 196000 divided by 20 = 9800 W.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by a force that varies with x as F(x) = k x (from x=0 to x=a) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: W = ∫_0^a k x dx = ½ k a^2.

Work Power Energy.question: A body of mass m attached to a spring (constant k) is pulled from equilibrium to extension x and released. Maximum kinetic energy achieved is:
Work Power Energy.comment: All elastic potential converts to kinetic at equilibrium: K_max = ½ k x^2.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by normal force on a block sliding on a smooth horizontal surface for a horizontal displacement is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Normal force is vertical while displacement is horizontal → dot product zero → no work by normal.

Work Power Energy.question: If the net work done on a particle is zero, then:
Work Power Energy.comment: ΔK = W_net = 0 → kinetic energy constant (speed may be constant but direction can change).

Work Power Energy.question: A projectile of mass m is fired vertically upward with speed u. Maximum height reached is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Using energy or kinematics: ½ m u^2 = m g h → h = u^2/(2 g).

Work Power Energy.question: If a 2 kg object has kinetic energy 50 J, its speed is approximately (take K = 1/2 m v^2):
Work done by a constant force F = 30 N acting at 60° to displacement of 2 m is:
If total mechanical energy of a particle in conservative field equals zero, the particle's kinetic and potential energies satisfy:
Work Power Energy.comment: Total mechanical energy E = K + U = 0.

Work Power Energy.question: A block is pulled along an inclined plane at constant speed. Work done against gravity and friction per unit time equals:
Work Power Energy.comment: At constant speed, pulling power equals rate of work against gravity plus friction.

Work Power Energy.question: A pendulum of length L released from small angle θ0 has maximum potential energy relative to lowest point approximately:
Work Power Energy.c: Both are equivalent for small θ0
Work Power Energy.comment: Exact: mgL(1−cosθ0). For small θ0, cosθ≈1−θ^2/2 → mgL(1−cosθ)≈½ mgL θ^2.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by non-conservative forces equals:
Work Power Energy.a: Change in mechanical energy of the system
Work Power Energy.d: Negative of change in kinetic energy only
Work Power Energy.comment: Work_non-conservative = ΔE_mech = ΔK + ΔU.

Work Power Energy.question: A motor delivers 5 kW of power to lift water. If pump lifts 200 kg of water per minute, the height it lifts water to (neglect losses, g=9.8) is approximately:
Work Power Energy.comment: Power = m g h / t. m/t = 200 kg / 60 s ≈ 3.333 kg/s. h = P/(m/t × g) = 5000/(3.333×9.8) ≈ 5000/32.666 ≈ 153.0 ≈ Wait—this arithmetic seems off. Correct computation below.

Work Power Energy.question: Correction: compute properly: m/t = 200/60 = 3.333... kg/s. g×(m/t) = 9.8×3.333... = 32.666... N·kg/s. h = 5000/32.666... ≈ 153.06 m. Choose closest:
Work Power Energy.comment: Proper calculation yields height ≈153 m. Earlier options were inconsistent; corrected here.

Work Power Energy.question: Which of the following represents dimensional formula of energy?
Work Power Energy.comment: Energy/work dimension: [M L^2 T^−2].

Work Power Energy.question: If a cyclist increases speed from 5 m/s to 10 m/s, the kinetic energy increases by factor:
Work Power Energy.comment: K ∝ v^2 so (10^2)/(5^2) = 100/25 = 4. Wait — that's 4. Correct below.

Work Power Energy.question: Correction: K initial ∝ 25, final ∝100 → increase factor = 100/25 = 4. So correct option is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Kinetic energy becomes 4 times when speed doubles; increase by factor 4.

Work Power Energy.question: A particle moves under a force F doing zero work over a displacement. Which is possible?
Work Power Energy.comment: All these can yield zero work: perpendicular force, zero force, or closed loop by conservative force.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by force F = (2 x) N when particle moves from x=0 to x=3 m is:
A body of mass m is thrown upward with kinetic energy K. Maximum height reached is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Initial kinetic energy converts to potential: K = m g h → h = K/(m g).

Work Power Energy.question: If the force on a particle is F(x) = −kx (restoring), the potential energy function U(x) (setting U=0 at x=0) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: For conservative F = −dU/dx, integrating gives U = ½ k x^2 (minimum at x=0).

Work Power Energy.question: The unit electronvolt (eV) is a unit of:
Work Power Energy.comment: 1 eV = energy gained by electron across 1 V ≈ 1.602×10^−19 J (unit of energy).

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by weight in bringing a body from height h1 to h2 is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work by gravity = −ΔU = −m g (h2 − h1) = m g (h1 − h2).

Work Power Energy.question: If potential energy of a system decreases, then (in absence of non-conservative forces):
Work Power Energy.comment: Conservation: decrease in U converts to increase in K.

Work Power Energy.question: A 100 W bulb left on for 30 minutes consumes energy of:
Which of the following quantities is NOT a form of mechanical energy?
Work Power Energy.comment: Thermal energy is non-mechanical (dissipated) though originating from mechanical work.

Work Power Energy.question: An object moving on rough surface slows down due to friction. The 'lost' mechanical energy primarily becomes:
Work Power Energy.comment: Friction converts mechanical energy to internal/thermal energy.

Work Power Energy.question: A force doing positive work on a particle must have a component:
Work Power Energy.comment: Positive work requires component of force in same direction as displacement.

Work Power Energy.question: If net work done on a particle is positive, the speed of the particle:
Work Power Energy.d: May increase or decrease depending on mass
Work Power Energy.comment: Positive net work → ΔK positive → speed increases (since K ∝ v^2).

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by normal force on a body moving up a rough incline a small distance dx (along surface) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Normal force is perpendicular to displacement along surface → no work by normal.

Work Power Energy.question: If potential energy function U(x) has a minimum at x0, the point x0 corresponds to:
Work Power Energy.comment: Minimum potential → small displacement increases U → restoring force → stable equilibrium.

Work Power Energy.question: A car engine has an output power of 50 kW. The energy delivered in 2 minutes is:
Work done by gravity in moving an object horizontally across a flat surface (height constant) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: No vertical displacement → gravity does zero work.

Work Power Energy.question: Minimum work required to move mass m from Earth's surface to infinity (escape from gravity) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work needed equals increase in energy to reach zero total energy: W = GMm/R = 1/2 m v_esc^2. (Note v_esc^2 = 2GM/R.)

Work Power Energy.question: A wheel with moment of inertia I rotates with angular speed ω. Its rotational kinetic energy is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Rotational kinetic energy K_rot = ½ I ω^2 (rotational analog of ½ m v^2).

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by buoyant force when an object is submerged slowly in fluid to depth h is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work by buoyant force depends on vertical displacement and volume change; can't say without more info.

Work Power Energy.question: If an ideal spring (k) is compressed from x = 0 to x = a, the work you must do (by external agent, quasi-static) is:
Work Power Energy.comment: External work equals increase in spring potential: +½ k a^2.

Work Power Energy.question: A box is pulled at constant speed along rough horizontal floor by force F making angle θ above horizontal. The normal reaction is reduced because of vertical component of F. Work done by F over distance s is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Only horizontal component does displacement, so W = F cosθ × s.

Work Power Energy.question: A mass m attached to string whirled in horizontal circle of radius r with speed v has kinetic energy:
Work Power Energy.comment: Kinetic energy expression same regardless of path: ½ m v^2.

Work Power Energy.question: If a conservative force does work W on an object when moving from A to B, then potential energy change U_B − U_A is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work done by conservative force = −ΔU, so ΔU = −W.

Work Power Energy.question: Work done by gravity in lifting a satellite from radius R to 2R is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work by gravity W = −GMm(1/2R − 1/R) = −GMm/(2R).

Work Power Energy.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE for energy conservation?
Work Power Energy.a: Energy can be created but not destroyed
Work Power Energy.b: Total energy of isolated system is constant
Work Power Energy.comment: Law of conservation of energy: total energy (including all forms) is constant in isolated system.

Work Power Energy.question: A body of mass 0.5 kg is moving with speed 4 m/s. Its kinetic energy is:
If a force F does work W on an object in time t, average power delivered is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Average power = work done divided by time interval.

Work Power Energy.question: A body slides down a frictionless incline of height h. Speed at bottom v is given by:
Work Power Energy.comment: Conversion of potential to kinetic: v = √(2 g h).

Work Power Energy.question: Which of the following is dimensionally same as work?
Work Power Energy.comment: Power (energy/time) × time = energy = work.

Work Power Energy.question: A bullet of mass 0.02 kg strikes a block and stops, delivering 500 J of energy. The initial speed of bullet was:
If the work done by all forces on a body in time interval is zero, which of the following must be true?
Work Power Energy.b: Speed of the body is constant
Work Power Energy.comment: Zero net work → ΔK = 0 → speed constant (velocity may change direction).

Work Power Energy.question: Work done to compress a gas quasi-statically at constant pressure is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Work done on gas by external agent when volume decreases: W_on = −∫P dV = −P ΔV (sign conventions vary).

Work Power Energy.question: Which of the following increases when non-conservative forces do positive work on a system?
Work Power Energy.comment: Positive work by non-conservative forces adds energy to system (increases mechanical energy if converted to K or U).

Work Power Energy.question: An elevator of mass 1000 kg is raised at constant speed 2 m/s. Power required to lift it ignoring friction is (g=9.8):
If a system's mechanical energy decreases while total energy is constant, the 'lost' mechanical energy has been converted into:
Work Power Energy.comment: Energy conservation: mechanical energy converts into other forms such as thermal/internal energy.

Work Power Energy.question: A constant force of 20 N acts on a particle, displacing it along x from 0 to 4 m. If force acts at 30° above x-axis but displacement along x only, work done is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Horizontal component is 20 cos30° = 20×(√3/2)=10√3; W = (10√3)×4 = 40√3 ≈ 69.28 J. Wait — check interpretation: If displacement purely along x, use F_x = F cos30. So correct value is 40√3 J. Option a is correct.

Work Power Energy.question: Correction: Computation: F_x = 20 cos30° = 20×0.8660 = 17.3205 N; W = 17.3205×4 = 69.282 J ≈ 40√3 J. So correct option:
Work Power Energy.comment: Exact expression 40√3 J.

Work Power Energy.question: Which statement about work and energy is FALSE?
Work Power Energy.b: Energy is conserved in isolated systems
Work Power Energy.c: Work done depends on path for non-conservative forces
Work Power Energy.d: Work and energy have different units
Work Power Energy.comment: Work and energy have same units (joule); so statement is false.

Work Power Energy.question: If the momentum of a particle doubles, its kinetic energy becomes:
Work Power Energy.comment: K = p^2/(2m); doubling p → K increases by 4.

Work Power Energy.question: A small object is released from rest at height h and lands with speed v. If some mechanical energy lost to air resistance is ΔE, then:
Work Power Energy.comment: Initial potential m g h = ½ m v^2 + ΔE → v^2 = 2 g h − 2ΔE/m.

Work Power Energy.question: The work done by electric force in moving a charge in electric field is:
Work Power Energy.comment: Electrostatic force is conservative → work depends only on endpoints.

Work Power Energy.question: If a skier slides down a frictionless slope of vertical drop h, the speed at bottom is independent of:
Work Power Energy.comment: v = √(2gh) independent of mass if frictionless.

Work Power Energy.question: Which of the following can do positive work on a system?
Work Power Energy.comment: All these examples include forces with components along displacement doing positive work.

Gravitation.question: Who proposed the Universal Law of Gravitation?
Gravitation.comment: Newton proposed the Universal Law of Gravitation.

Gravitation.question: The universal gravitational constant G has SI units of:
Gravitation.comment: G units are N·m^2·kg^-2 (equivalently m^3·kg^-1·s^-2).

Gravitation.question: According to Newton's law of gravitation, the force between two point masses is proportional to:
Gravitation.comment: Force ∝ product of the two masses and inversely to square of distance.

Gravitation.question: Gravitational force between two masses varies as the inverse square of the distance. If distance is doubled, force becomes:
Gravitation.comment: Inverse-square law: F ∝ 1/r^2, so doubling r → F/4.

Gravitation.question: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
Gravitation.comment: Gravitational potential is a scalar; field and force are vectors.

Gravitation.question: Gravitational field (intensity) at a point is defined as:
Gravitation.a: Force on unit mass placed at that point
Gravitation.c: Work done to bring unit mass from infinity
Gravitation.comment: Field g = F/m (vector), force per unit mass.

Gravitation.question: Gravitational potential at infinity (for isolated mass) is usually taken as:
Gravitation.comment: By convention potential → 0 at infinity for isolated mass.

Gravitation.question: Gravitational potential due to a point mass M at distance r is:
Gravitation.comment: Potential V = -GM/r (negative for attractive gravity).

Gravitation.question: The gravitational potential energy of two masses m1 and m2 separated by r is:
Gravitation.comment: Mutual potential energy = -G m1 m2 / r (negative, bound system).

Gravitation.question: Which of the following statements about gravitational potential is true?
Gravitation.b: It is always negative (for attractive mass)
Gravitation.comment: Potential for attractive gravity is negative relative to zero at infinity.

Gravitation.question: Inside a hollow spherical shell of uniform mass, the gravitational field is:
Gravitation.comment: Shell theorem: field inside a thin spherical shell is zero.

Gravitation.question: Outside a spherically symmetric mass distribution, gravitational field is the same as if the whole mass were concentrated at:
Gravitation.comment: For spherical symmetry, external field equals that of a point mass at center.

Gravitation.question: If Earth were replaced by another sphere of same mass but twice the radius, surface g would be:
Gravitation.comment: g ∝ 1/R^2, doubling R → g becomes 1/4 of original.

Gravitation.question: Acceleration due to gravity g at Earth's surface is given by:
Gravitation.comment: g = GM/R^2 where M and R are Earth's mass and radius.

Gravitation.question: Mass and weight — which is false?
Gravitation.a: Mass is scalar, weight is vector
Gravitation.b: Mass is constant; weight can change
Gravitation.c: Mass measured in kg, weight in N
Gravitation.d: Mass depends on location; weight is intrinsic
Gravitation.comment: Mass is intrinsic and location-independent; weight depends on g (location).

Gravitation.question: If you go to a planet where gravitational acceleration is double that of Earth, your mass and weight will change as:
Gravitation.comment: Mass is unchanged; weight = mg doubles if g doubles.

Gravitation.question: If two identical spherical planets are separated by a distance equal to their diameters (just touching), gravitational force between them compared to when they were infinitely far is:
Gravitation.comment: At contact distance, force = G m^2 / (2R)^2 — finite and large.

Gravitation.question: If gravitational field at a point is g, the potential difference between infinity and that point is:
Gravitation.comment: Potential V(r) = −∫∞^r g·dr (since V→0 at infinity).

Gravitation.question: Small mass m is moved from infinity to distance r from mass M. Work done by external agent (against gravity) is:
Gravitation.comment: External work = +GMm/r (positive), while gravitational work is negative.

Gravitation.question: Escape velocity from a planet of mass M and radius R is:
Gravitation.comment: Escape speed v_e = sqrt(2GM/R).

Gravitation.question: Numeric value: approximate escape velocity from Earth (surface) is about:
Gravitation.comment: Escape velocity ≈ 11.2 km/s (more precisely ~11.19 km/s).

Gravitation.question: First cosmic velocity (orbital speed just above surface, ignoring atmosphere) is:
Gravitation.comment: First cosmic speed v = sqrt(GM/R) ≈ 7.91 km/s for Earth.

Gravitation.question: If a satellite orbits very close to Earth's surface, its orbital speed (approx) is:
Gravitation.comment: Low-earth orbital speed ≈ 7.9 km/s (first cosmic velocity).

Gravitation.question: Period T of a satellite in circular orbit of radius r around Earth is proportional to:
Gravitation.comment: By Kepler's third law for circular orbits, T ∝ r^(3/2).

Gravitation.question: Kepler's first law states that planetary orbits are:
Gravitation.b: Ellipses with Sun at one focus
Gravitation.comment: Kepler I: planetary orbits are ellipses with Sun at a focus.

Gravitation.question: Kepler's second law (equal areas in equal times) implies:
Gravitation.b: Planet sweeps equal areas in equal times implying angular momentum conservation
Gravitation.d: Orbital period depends on mass of planet
Gravitation.comment: Kepler II reflects conservation of angular momentum for central forces.

Gravitation.question: Kepler's third law (T^2 ∝ a^3) is a consequence of:
Gravitation.comment: Kepler III follows from Newton's inverse-square gravitational force for circular/elliptical orbits.

Gravitation.question: A geostationary satellite has orbital period equal to Earth's rotation and remains above:
Gravitation.comment: Geostationary orbit is above equator and appears fixed to ground.

Gravitation.question: Radius of geostationary orbit (approx) from Earth's center is about:
Gravitation.comment: Geostationary radius ≈ 4.22×10^7 m (altitude ≈ 3.587×10^7 m).

Gravitation.question: A satellite in circular orbit has kinetic energy K and potential energy U (gravitational) related by:
Gravitation.comment: For circular orbit: total energy E = U + K = −K so K = −U/2 and E = −K.

Gravitation.question: Total mechanical energy of satellite in circular orbit of radius r is:
Gravitation.comment: Total energy E = −(GMm)/(2r) (negative for bound orbit).

Gravitation.question: A mass m inside earth at distance r from center (assuming uniform density) experiences gravitational acceleration:
Gravitation.comment: Inside uniform sphere g ∝ r (g(r)=GM_r/r^2 and M_r ∝ r^3 → g∝r).

Gravitation.question: If density of Earth is uniform, gravitational acceleration at half the radius (r=R/2) is:
Gravitation.comment: g(r)=g*(r/R). At r=R/2 → g/2. (But if you meant g inside at half radius, correct is g/2.)

Gravitation.question: A tunnel is dug through Earth's diameter and an object dropped in (neglect friction). Its motion is:
Gravitation.comment: For uniform density Earth, restoring force ∝ r → simple harmonic motion.

Gravitation.question: If mass of Earth were doubled but radius same, surface g would:
Gravitation.comment: g ∝ M, doubling M doubles g (if R unchanged).

Gravitation.question: Apparent weight of a body in an elevator accelerating upward with acceleration a is:
Gravitation.comment: Apparent weight = m(g + a) when elevator accelerates upward.

Gravitation.question: If elevator is in free fall (acceleration = g downward), apparent weight is:
Gravitation.comment: In free fall apparent weight is zero (weightlessness).

Gravitation.question: The gravitational force between electron and proton in hydrogen atom compared to Coulomb force is about:
Gravitation.comment: Gravitational force is ~10^-39 times the electrostatic force — negligible at atomic scale.

Gravitation.question: Force of gravity between two 1 kg masses 1 m apart is approximately:
If you're standing at Earth's poles versus equator, your weight differs because of:
Gravitation.comment: Centrifugal reduction at equator lowers apparent weight slightly.

Gravitation.question: Consider two masses m and 4m separated by distance d. Where from the smaller mass (m) should a test mass be placed so net gravitational force is zero? (measured from m toward 4m)
If gravitational potential at surface of Earth is V, and at infinity is 0, then V is:
Gravitation.comment: Potential at surface is negative; magnitude GM/R.

Gravitation.question: Gravitational field lines around a point mass are:
Gravitation.comment: Field lines point toward mass (inward) for attractive gravity.

Gravitation.question: If a small mass m is at a point where gravitational potential is V and field is g, the relation between them in one dimension is:
Gravitation.comment: g = −dV/dr (field is negative gradient of potential).

Gravitation.question: A planet of mass M orbits a star in a circular orbit radius r with speed v. The centripetal acceleration is provided by gravity: v^2/r equals:
Gravitation.comment: Centripetal acceleration v^2/r = gravitational acceleration GM/r^2.

Gravitation.question: If two planets have same density but planet A has twice the radius of planet B, surface gravity of A compared to B is:
Gravitation.comment: For same density, g ∝ R (since mass ∝ R^3 and g ∝ M/R^2 ∝ R). Twice radius → g doubles; check: actually for same density, g ∝ R — so A with twice radius has twice g compared to B. Correct answer should be b.

Gravitation.question: A correction note: For same density, surface gravity g ∝ R. If planet A has twice the radius of B (same density), g_A = 2 g_B. (Which option matches?)
Gravitation.comment: Confirmed: for equal density, g ∝ R, so doubling R doubles g.

Gravitation.question: Work required to bring unit mass from Earth surface (radius R) to infinity against gravity is equal to:
Gravitation.comment: Work = difference in potential = 0 − (−GM/R) = GM/R (per unit mass).

Gravitation.question: If gravitational potential energy of Earth–Moon system is U, doubling distance between them changes U by factor:
Gravitation.comment: U = −G M1 M2 / r, doubling r → U halves in magnitude (becomes −1/2 original).

Gravitation.question: If two identical spheres of mass m are held in contact, the force between them is:
Gravitation.comment: Center-to-center distance = 2R, so F = G m^2/(2R)^2.

Gravitation.question: Gravitational potential due to thin spherical shell (inside region) is:
Gravitation.comment: Potential inside a shell is constant and equal to value at surface (−GM/R).

Gravitation.question: Gravitational field at very large distance from a system of masses depends mainly on:
Gravitation.a: Total mass and its multipole moments; leading term is total mass concentrated at CM
Gravitation.comment: At large distances, leading behavior is as if total mass concentrated at center of mass.

Gravitation.question: If a planet's rotation increases, apparent weight at equator is reduced because of:
Gravitation.comment: In rotating frame, centrifugal pseudo-force reduces apparent weight.

Gravitation.question: Tidal forces arise due to:
Gravitation.a: Difference in gravitational force over a body
Gravitation.comment: Tides are produced by gradient (difference) of gravitational pull across Earth's diameter.

Gravitation.question: Which body produces largest tidal effect on Earth?
Gravitation.comment: Though Sun is massive, Moon is much closer, so it produces larger tides.

Gravitation.question: The Roche limit is related to:
Gravitation.a: Tidal disruption of a satellite approaching a planet
Gravitation.comment: Roche limit is distance within which tidal forces can tear a satellite apart.

Gravitation.question: Two-body problem can be reduced to motion of reduced mass μ = m1 m2/(m1 + m2) about:
Gravitation.comment: Relative motion reduces to μ moving about center of mass under central force.

Gravitation.question: If gravitational force provides centripetal force for the Moon's circular motion, then the acceleration of Moon toward Earth is:
Gravitation.comment: Centripetal acceleration equals gravitational acceleration: v^2/r = GM/r^2.

Gravitation.question: If gravitational constant G were zero, which would be true?
Gravitation.b: No gravitational attraction; planets would move in straight lines
Gravitation.comment: With G=0, gravity disappears; bodies travel inertially (straight lines).

Gravitation.question: For a mass m at Earth's surface, potential energy mgh (near surface) is an approximation of −GMm/(R+h) − (−GMm/R) for:
Gravitation.comment: Near surface (h<<R) we approximate change in potential as mgh.

Gravitation.question: For a test mass at Earth's center, gravitational potential (taking zero at infinity) is:
Gravitation.comment: For a uniform sphere, potential at center = −3GM/(2R).

Gravitation.question: Which of the following decreases with depth inside a uniform Earth?
Gravitation.c: Gravitational potential (becomes more negative toward center)
Gravitation.comment: Inside, g ∝ r (decreases toward center) and potential becomes more negative until center (minimum).

Gravitation.question: If orbital radius of satellite is doubled, its orbital speed becomes:
Gravitation.comment: v ∝ 1/√r for circular orbit (v = sqrt(GM/r)), doubling r → v/√2.

Gravitation.question: For a particle moving between two masses in stable equilibrium under gravity, small displacement leads to:
Gravitation.a: Stable equilibrium if potential has minimum
Gravitation.d: Any of the above depending on location
Gravitation.comment: Stability depends on curvature of potential at the point (min → stable, max → unstable).

Gravitation.question: The gravitational binding energy of a uniform sphere of mass M and radius R is:
Gravitation.comment: Binding energy (work to disperse) = 3GM^2/(5R) (positive magnitude) so total gravitational energy is −3GM^2/(5R).

Gravitation.question: If gravitational force acting on a particle is conservative, then:
Gravitation.c: Work done depends only on end points
Gravitation.comment: Conservative forces imply path independence; gravitational force is conservative.

Gravitation.question: In gravitational two-body problem, total linear momentum is conserved because:
Gravitation.comment: In isolated two-body system, internal forces sum to zero; external force is zero so momentum conserved.

Gravitation.question: A body experiences weight W on Earth's surface. If Earth were instantaneously shrunk without changing mass to half its radius, its weight would become:
Gravitation.comment: g ∝ 1/R^2; halving R → g increases by 4, so weight quadruples.

Gravitation.question: A satellite's kinetic energy is K and potential energy U (U negative). If altitude increases slowly to infinity, final kinetic energy tends to:
Gravitation.comment: At infinity potential and kinetic → 0 for barely escaping; need initial E≥0 to escape.

Gravitation.question: Which of the following best describes gravitational potential at a point inside a hollow shell of mass?
Gravitation.comment: Potential inside shell is constant (equal to surface value).

Gravitation.question: A point mass is located at distance r from center of a uniform solid sphere radius R. For r>R, field is GM/r^2; for r<R it is:
Gravitation.comment: Inside uniform sphere, g(r) = (GM/R^3) r (linear in r).

Gravitation.question: Consider three equal masses at vertices of an equilateral triangle. The net gravitational force on one mass due to the other two points toward:
Gravitation.comment: Symmetry: resultant points toward centroid (center) of triangle.

Gravitation.question: Which quantity remains constant for a planet under central gravitational force?
Gravitation.comment: Central forces conserve angular momentum about center.

Gravitation.question: If distance between Earth and Sun increased, Earth's year (orbital period) would:
Gravitation.comment: By Kepler's third law T ∝ a^(3/2); larger radius → longer period.

Gravitation.question: Consider two masses m and 2m placed at distance d apart. A point between them where net gravitational potential is zero lies:
Gravitation.b: Between them closer to smaller mass
Gravitation.d: Between them closer to larger mass
Gravitation.comment: Potentials (scalars) of same sign (negative) cannot cancel between them; zero potential point is outside nearer the smaller mass on extension.

Gravitation.question: Total mechanical energy of a planet in a stable circular orbit is negative because:
Gravitation.b: Potential energy negative and twice kinetic in magnitude
Gravitation.comment: For circular orbit U = −2K → E = K + U = −K (negative).

Gravitation.question: If a geostationary satellite runs out of fuel and its orbit decays slightly inward, it will:
Gravitation.comment: If orbital radius decreases, orbital period becomes less than 24 h → satellite drifts west relative to ground.

Gravitation.question: The gravitational potential energy of two 1 kg masses separated by 1 m is approximately:
Gravitation.comment: U = −G m1 m2 / r = −6.674×10^-11 J for two 1 kg at 1 m.

Gravitation.question: A meteorite hits Earth adding mass ΔM (ΔM << M). Earth's surface gravity g changes approximately by:
Gravitation.a: ΔM/M times g (i.e., fractional change ΔM/M)
Gravitation.comment: Small fractional change in mass changes g by roughly same fractional amount (g∝M).

Gravitation.question: Which of these is NOT a consequence of inverse-square law?
Gravitation.comment: Centrifugal force direction is unrelated to inverse-square property.

Gravitation.question: A spacecraft in a stable circular orbit around Earth at 300 km altitude has orbital speed slightly less than first cosmic speed at surface. Reason:
Gravitation.a: Because orbital radius is larger than Earth's radius
Gravitation.comment: Orbital speed decreases with sqrt(1/r); at 300 km altitude r>R so v slightly less than surface orbital speed.

Gravitation.question: Gravitational redshift and bending of light are predicted by:
Gravitation.comment: Relativistic effects (e.g., light bending) require General Relativity, not Newtonian gravity.

Gravitation.question: In SI units the value of G is approximately:
Gravitation.comment: G ≈ 6.67430×10^-11 N·m^2·kg^-2 (standard constant).

Gravitation.question: If a planet with mass M and radius R has surface escape speed equal to orbital speed (at the surface), then escape/orbital ratio is:
Gravitation.comment: Escape speed / orbital speed = sqrt(2GM/R)/sqrt(GM/R) = √2.

Gravitation.question: Which of the following is true regarding gravitational potential inside a uniform spherical shell (thin) at interior points?
Gravitation.b: Potential equals potential at surface (constant negative)
Gravitation.comment: Inside a shell potential is uniform and equals surface value (−GM/R).

Gravitation.question: The gravitational force is always:
Gravitation.comment: Gravity between masses is always attractive in classical physics.

Gravitation.question: If the Moon were twice as far from Earth, the gravitational force between Earth and Moon would be:
Gravitation.comment: Force ∝ 1/r^2; doubling r → force becomes 1/4.

Gravitation.question: The energy required to remove satellite of mass m from orbit of radius r to infinity equals:
Gravitation.comment: Total energy of satellite = −GMm/(2r); to bring to zero energy (infinity) need +GMm/(2r).

Gravitation.question: If a point mass is located inside a spherical shell at off-center point, gravitational field inside is:
Gravitation.comment: Zero field applies only for massless test particle due to shell; if a point mass is inside it experiences zero force from the shell but if you place a mass off-center its self-interaction doesn't affect shell theorem — test mass sees zero field from shell. Clarify: test mass inside shell feels zero field from shell irrespective of position.

Gravitation.question: Clarification note: A test mass placed anywhere inside a thin spherical shell experiences:
Gravitation.a: No net gravitational force from the shell
Gravitation.comment: Shell theorem: gravitational field inside thin spherical shell due to shell = 0 everywhere inside.

Gravitation.question: A mass m is at Earth's surface. The escape velocity from Earth (numerical) is approximately (in km/s):
Gravitation.comment: Escape velocity ≈ 11.2 km/s (≈ 1.1186×10^4 m/s).

Gravitation.question: The first cosmic velocity (circular orbital speed near surface) is approximately (in km/s):
Gravitation.comment: First cosmic speed ≈ 7.91 km/s.

Gravitation.question: Geostationary orbit altitude above Earth's surface (approx) is:
Gravitation.comment: Geostationary altitude ≈ 3.587×10^4 km (~35,786 km).

Gravitation.question: Which of these is a direct consequence of conservation of angular momentum for planets?
Gravitation.a: Planets always move at same speed
Gravitation.b: Kepler's second law (equal areas in equal times)
Gravitation.comment: Conservation of angular momentum leads to equal area law (Kepler II).

Gravitation.question: For two masses interacting only via gravity, the center of mass moves:
Gravitation.comment: If no external forces, center of mass moves with constant velocity (momentum conserved).

Pressure.question: Pressure is defined as:
Pressure.comment: Pressure p = F / A (force normal to surface per unit area).

Pressure.question: SI unit of pressure is:
Pressure.comment: 1 Pascal = 1 N/m^2 is the SI unit of pressure.

Pressure.question: Which of the following equals 1 Pascal (Pa)?
Pressure.comment: 1 Pa = 1 N per square metre.

Pressure.question: Atmospheric pressure at sea level (approx) is:
Pressure.comment: Standard atmospheric pressure ≈ 101325 Pa ≈ 1.013×10^5 Pa.

Pressure.question: Gauge pressure is defined as:
Pressure.c: Difference between absolute pressure and atmospheric pressure
Pressure.comment: Gauge pressure = p_absolute − p_atm.

Pressure.question: Absolute pressure equals:
Pressure.comment: Absolute = gauge + atmospheric (absolute measures from vacuum).

Pressure.question: Pressure at a point in a fluid at rest depends on:
Pressure.comment: Hydrostatic pressure depends only on depth, fluid density and gravity (not container shape).

Pressure.question: Hydrostatic pressure at depth h in a fluid of density ρ is given by:
Pressure.comment: Hydrostatic pressure increment p = ρ g h (measured relative to surface pressure).

Pressure.question: Total pressure at depth h below the free surface (taking atmospheric pressure p0) is:
Pressure.comment: Absolute pressure at depth = atmospheric pressure + hydrostatic head ρ g h.

Pressure.question: If density of water is 1000 kg/m^3 and g = 9.8 m/s^2, pressure at 10 m depth (ignoring atmospheric) is:
Pascal's law states that pressure applied to a confined incompressible fluid is transmitted:
Pressure.c: Undiminished to every part of fluid and to container walls
Pressure.comment: Pascal's principle: pressure change at one point transmits undiminished throughout confined fluid.

Pressure.question: A hydraulic press works on the principle of:
Pressure.comment: Hydraulic machines use Pascal's law: F1/A1 = F2/A2.

Pressure.question: In a hydraulic lift with small piston area A1 and large piston area A2, if a force F1 is applied on small piston, output force F2 is:
Pressure.comment: Pressure equal: F1/A1 = F2/A2 → F2 = F1 × (A2/A1).

Pressure.question: A sealed container filled with liquid is subjected to a small pressure at one point. According to Pascal's law, where does that extra pressure appear?
Pressure.a: Only near the point of application
Pressure.c: Everywhere in the liquid and on container walls equally
Pressure.comment: Pascal: extra pressure transmits uniformly across the fluid and walls.

Pressure.question: A U-tube manometer contains mercury (density 13600 kg/m^3). If one limb is open to atmosphere and the other connected to a vessel at pressure higher than atmosphere, the mercury level in the open limb will be:
Pressure.comment: Higher vessel pressure pushes mercury down in connected limb, raising level in open limb.

Pressure.question: For a liquid of density ρ, pressure difference between two points at depths h1 and h2 is:
Pressure.comment: p(h1) − p(h2) = ρ g (h1 − h2) (deeper point has larger pressure).

Pressure.question: Hydrostatic paradox says that pressure on a given base depends on:
Pressure.c: Height of fluid above the base, not on total mass or shape
Pressure.comment: Hydrostatic paradox: pressure on base depends only on depth (height) of fluid column and base area.

Pressure.question: A ship floats because of which principle?
Pressure.comment: Archimedes: buoyant force equals weight of displaced fluid, enabling flotation.

Pressure.question: Buoyant force (upthrust) on a body immersed in fluid is equal to:
Pressure.b: Weight of fluid displaced by the body
Pressure.c: Product of density and volume of body
Pressure.comment: Buoyant force = ρ_fluid × V_displaced × g (weight of displaced fluid).

Pressure.question: A block of density 600 kg/m^3 floats in water (ρ = 1000 kg/m^3). Fraction of its volume submerged is:
Pressure.comment: Fraction submerged = ρ_object / ρ_fluid = 600/1000 = 0.6.

Pressure.question: If an object sinks in a fluid, its density is:
Pressure.comment: Object sinks if its density > fluid density (weight > buoyant force).

Pressure.question: A body lighter than fluid will:
Pressure.comment: If density of body < fluid, it floats with part submerged such that buoyancy = weight.

Pressure.question: A hot-air balloon rises because:
Pressure.a: Hot air has higher density than cold air
Pressure.b: Hot air has lower density than cold air and buoyant force lifts balloon
Pressure.c: Pressure inside is greater producing upward thrust
Pressure.comment: Heating air lowers its density so the balloon displaces heavier cold air; buoyancy lifts it.

Pressure.question: The pressure at the same horizontal level in a continuous connected fluid is:
Pressure.b: Same (if fluid is continuous and at rest)
Pressure.comment: At equal depths in connected fluid at rest, pressure is same (communicating vessels).

Pressure.question: A column of mercury stands at 760 mm in a barometer at sea level. If mercury density is 13600 kg/m^3 and g = 9.8 m/s^2, the atmospheric pressure is approximately:
A manometer measures pressure difference of 2000 Pa using a liquid of density 800 kg/m^3. The column difference in height Δh is approximately:
If a small hole is made on the side of a container filled with liquid, the efflux (horizontal) speed of the liquid at depth h (below free surface) is given by Torricelli's theorem as:
Pressure.comment: Torricelli: efflux speed v = √(2 g h) (as if falling through height h).

Pressure.question: Bernoulli's equation relates pressure, kinetic energy per unit volume and potential energy per unit volume along a streamline. For ideal incompressible non-viscous steady flow it is:
Pressure.a: p + 1/2 ρ v^2 + ρ g h = constant
Pressure.b: p × 1/2 ρ v^2 + ρ g h = 0
Pressure.c: p + ρ v + ρ g h = 0
Pressure.d: p − 1/2 ρ v^2 − ρ g h = constant
Pressure.comment: Bernoulli's principle: p + ½ρv^2 + ρgh = constant along a streamline.

Pressure.question: Which of the following is a direct consequence of Bernoulli's principle?
Pressure.a: Pressure increases where fluid speed increases
Pressure.b: Pressure decreases where fluid speed increases
Pressure.comment: Bernoulli implies increased speed corresponds to decreased static pressure (for same height).

Pressure.question: A submerged object is attached to spring scale and weighed underwater. The apparent loss in weight equals:
Pressure.comment: Apparent weight loss equals buoyant force (weight of displaced fluid).

Pressure.question: If two immiscible liquids of densities ρ1 and ρ2 are in layers, pressure at a given depth depends on:
Pressure.c: Sum of ρ g h of layers above that depth
Pressure.comment: Pressure sums contributions ρ g h of each layer above the point.

Pressure.question: A mercury barometer reads 76 cm. If mercury replaced by water (ρ_water ≈ 1000 kg/m^3) and atmospheric pressure unchanged, approximate height of water column will be (ρ_Hg ≈ 13.6×10^3 kg/m^3):
Pressure at the bottom of a cylindrical tank depends on:
Pressure.a: Total mass of liquid in tank
Pressure.b: Height of liquid column above the bottom
Pressure.comment: Pressure at a point depends on depth (height of liquid); not on total mass or tank shape.

Pressure.question: Two containers A and B are connected and contain the same liquid. Container A is wide and shallow; B is narrow and tall. If liquid is poured into A, where will levels equalize?
Pressure.a: Level will be higher in B always
Pressure.c: Higher in A only if volume large
Pressure.comment: Connected containers at equilibrium have same free surface height for same fluid.

Pressure.question: A diver experiences ear 'squeezing' as he descends due to:
Pressure.comment: Pressure increases with depth (ρ g h), creating differential pressures on body cavities.

Pressure.question: Which instrument measures atmospheric pressure directly?
Pressure.comment: A barometer (mercury or aneroid) measures atmospheric pressure.

Pressure.question: An aneroid barometer measures pressure using:
Pressure.b: A sealed flexible metal box (capsule) that expands/contracts
Pressure.comment: Aneroid barometer uses evacuated, flexible metal capsule; no liquid.

Pressure.question: If absolute pressure inside a tyre is 2.0×10^5 Pa and atmospheric pressure is 1.0×10^5 Pa, the gauge pressure is:
Pressure.comment: Gauge = absolute − atmospheric = 2.0×10^5 − 1.0×10^5 = 1.0×10^5 Pa.

Pressure.question: The pressure in liquid at a point is isotropic. 'Isotropic' here means:
Pressure.b: Pressure acts equally in all directions
Pressure.comment: In a static fluid, pressure at a point is same in all directions (isotropic).

Pressure.question: Consider two points at the same depth in two different connected containers containing same fluid. Their pressures are:
Pressure.a: Different if containers have different shapes
Pressure.comment: Equal depths in same fluid at rest have equal pressure regardless of shape (communicating vessels).

Pressure.question: A balloon is inflated at sea-level and taken up to high altitude where atmospheric pressure is much lower. The volume of balloon (assuming temperature roughly constant) will:
Pressure.comment: Lower external pressure allows balloon to expand (if elastic limits allow).

Pressure.question: If the pressure on all sides of a small cube of fluid increases by Δp uniformly, the net force on the cube is:
Pressure.comment: Uniform pressure increase produces equal forces in opposite directions → net zero.

Pressure.question: Which of these quantities is dimensionally equivalent to pressure?
Pressure.comment: Pressure [M L^−1 T^−2] = energy density (J/m^3).
