Scientific Instruments.comment: Monochromatic light passes through sample; detector measures transmitted intensity to compute absorbance A = −log₁₀(T).

Scientific Instruments.question: A photomultiplier tube (PMT) is most suitable when:
Scientific Instruments.a: Very weak light detection with high gain and fast response is required
Scientific Instruments.comment: PMT multiplies electrons via dynodes giving gains up to 10⁶–10⁷; sensitive to single photons in many setups.

Scientific Instruments.question: Lock-in detection requires a reference signal. To measure amplitude at frequency f, the reference is:
Scientific Instruments.a: A phase-stable signal at same frequency f (phase information allows quadrature detection)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Phase-stable reference ensures only components at that frequency contribute to DC after mixing and filtering.

Scientific Instruments.question: A thermocouple measures temperature by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Seebeck effect (voltage generated at junction of two different metals is proportional to temperature difference)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Thermocouple output small mV per °C; cold-junction compensation required for absolute temperature reading.

Scientific Instruments.question: A resistance thermometer (RTD) typically uses which metal?
Scientific Instruments.a: Platinum (Pt) due to linear and stable resistance–temperature characteristic
Scientific Instruments.comment: Pt100, Pt1000 are common RTDs (100 Ω at 0 °C); high accuracy over wide range compared to thermistors in some ranges.

Scientific Instruments.question: A thermistor (NTC) is best used for:
Scientific Instruments.a: Fast response temperature sensing in limited range thanks to steep resistance–temperature dependence
Scientific Instruments.comment: NTC (negative temp coefficient) has high sensitivity but nonlinear response; good for control and compensation.

Scientific Instruments.question: A standard mercury-in-glass thermometer measures temperature by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Thermal expansion of mercury producing a length change proportional to temperature
Scientific Instruments.comment: Mercury expands uniformly with temperature; glass capillary translates volume change to height for reading.

Scientific Instruments.question: A barometer measures atmospheric pressure commonly using:
Scientific Instruments.a: Mercury column height (Torricelli barometer) or aneroid capsule
Scientific Instruments.comment: Mercury column height h satisfies p_atm = ρ g h; aneroid uses evacuated capsule and mechanical linkage.

Scientific Instruments.question: Seismograph records:
Scientific Instruments.a: Ground motion (seismic waves) vs time, commonly using mass–spring or electromagnetic transducers
Scientific Instruments.comment: Seismometers measure vertical and horizontal components; output used to compute magnitudes and epicenters.

Scientific Instruments.question: An LCR meter measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Inductance (L), capacitance (C) and resistance (R) often over a range of frequencies
Scientific Instruments.comment: LCR meters apply AC test signal and compute impedance phase and magnitude to extract L, C, R.

Scientific Instruments.question: A gaussmeter measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Magnetic flux density B (in tesla or gauss) often using Hall-effect sensors
Scientific Instruments.comment: Gaussmeters use Hall probes or fluxgate sensors for DC/low-frequency fields measurement.

Scientific Instruments.question: A Hall-effect sensor output voltage V_H ∝ I B / (n q t). Therefore it can be used to measure:
Scientific Instruments.a: Magnetic field magnitude and polarity, or as current sensor (via field)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Hall voltage depends on carrier density n and thickness t; calibration required for quantitative measurement.

Scientific Instruments.question: A fluxgate magnetometer is valued for:
Scientific Instruments.a: High sensitivity to DC and low-frequency magnetic fields (used in geophysics and space missions)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Fluxgate uses driven ferromagnetic core and detection of induced harmonics to sense ambient DC field.

Scientific Instruments.question: A lock-in amplifier improves signal-to-noise ratio by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Synchronous detection—mixing with reference and low-pass filtering to select only the component at reference frequency
Scientific Instruments.comment: Lock-in can measure microvolt-level signals buried in noise when reference frequency known and stable.

Scientific Instruments.question: An electron microscope obtains higher resolution than optical microscopes because:
Scientific Instruments.a: Electrons have much shorter de Broglie wavelength than visible light for comparable energies
Scientific Instruments.c: Electron microscopes use more powerful lenses than optics
Scientific Instruments.comment: Electron wavelength λ ≈ h/p can be orders of magnitude smaller than optical λ, enabling nm-scale resolution.

Scientific Instruments.question: Transmission electron microscope (TEM) forms image by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Electrons transmitted through thin specimen and focused by electromagnetic lenses
Scientific Instruments.comment: TEM requires very thin samples (<100 nm); forms projections and diffraction patterns for structural study.

Scientific Instruments.question: Scanning electron microscope (SEM) forms images by detecting:
Scientific Instruments.a: Secondary or backscattered electrons emitted from specimen surface giving topographic contrast
Scientific Instruments.comment: SEM gives surface morphology with depth of field; complementary detectors include EDX for elemental analysis.

Scientific Instruments.question: A spectrometer using diffraction grating and photodetector array (CCD) is called:
Scientific Instruments.a: A digital/array spectrometer or spectrograph
Scientific Instruments.comment: Grating disperses spectrum across CCD; each pixel measures intensity at different λ enabling fast spectral capture.

Scientific Instruments.question: A lock-in amplifier uses phase-sensitive detection to measure both:
Scientific Instruments.a: In-phase (X) and quadrature (Y) components → magnitude R = √(X²+Y²) and phase φ = arctan(Y/X)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Quadrature detection allows simultaneous amplitude and phase measurement relative to reference.

Scientific Instruments.question: A particle counter measuring aerosol concentration often uses:
Scientific Instruments.a: Light scattering/optical detection correlated to particle size and count
Scientific Instruments.comment: Laser scattering intensity and pulse height analysis give size distribution and counts in air monitoring.

Scientific Instruments.question: A dosimeter used to measure cumulative ionizing radiation exposure is commonly:
Scientific Instruments.a: Film badge, TLD (thermoluminescent dosimeter) or electronic personal dosimeter
Scientific Instruments.comment: Dosimeters record integrated dose for personnel safety; TLDs store energy and release light on heating proportional to dose.

Scientific Instruments.question: In X-ray spectroscopy, a proportional counter detects X-rays by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Ionization in gas causing proportional pulses whose amplitude is related to photon energy
Scientific Instruments.comment: Proportional counters allow energy discrimination and counting; semiconductor detectors (Si, Ge) give better resolution.

Scientific Instruments.question: A debye (Debye) meter measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Dipole moment of molecules in electrostatic experiments (unit: Debye) — less common instrument name
Scientific Instruments.comment: Specialized lab setups measure dielectric properties and molecular dipole moments.

Scientific Instruments.question: A capacitance bridge measures small capacitances by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Balancing a bridge circuit and detecting null with sensitive detector
Scientific Instruments.comment: Bridge methods provide high accuracy by comparison with known standards and null detection.

Scientific Instruments.question: A Wheatstone bridge balance condition is:
Scientific Instruments.comment: Balance eliminates current through galvanometer; used to measure unknown resistance precisely.

Scientific Instruments.question: An impedance analyzer measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Complex impedance Z = R + jX as a function of frequency
Scientific Instruments.comment: Impedance analyzers are instrumental for component characterization (capacitors, inductors) across frequency range.

Scientific Instruments.question: An anemometer measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Air velocity (wind speed) using cup, vane, hot-wire or ultrasonic sensors
Scientific Instruments.comment: Hot-wire anemometers infer speed from convective cooling of heated wire; cup/vane measure mechanical rotation rate.

Scientific Instruments.question: A hygrometer measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Relative humidity or moisture content in air (various types: psychrometer, capacitive, chilled mirror)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Psychrometers use wet- and dry-bulb temperatures; chilled-mirror gives dew-point measurement for accurate humidity.

Scientific Instruments.question: A calorimeter measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Heat (thermal energy) exchanged in chemical/physical processes
Scientific Instruments.comment: Types include bomb calorimeter for combustion and differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) for material transitions.

Scientific Instruments.question: A lock-in amplifier's output after mixing and low-pass filtering is proportional to:
Scientific Instruments.a: Amplitude of input component at reference frequency times cos(phase difference)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Synchronous detection recovers coherent component; phase-sensitive detection allows quadrature channels.

Scientific Instruments.question: A frequency counter measures frequency by:
Scientific Instruments.a: Counting cycles of signal during a known gate time using a stable timebase
Scientific Instruments.comment: Accuracy depends on timebase stability; frequency = counted cycles / gate time.

Scientific Instruments.question: A function generator typically provides:
Scientific Instruments.a: Sine, square, triangle waveforms with adjustable frequency and amplitude for testing circuits
Scientific Instruments.comment: Modern generators offer modulation, sweep, and arbitrary waveform features for lab testing.

Scientific Instruments.question: A lock-in amplifier is particularly powerful when signal is:
Scientific Instruments.a: Weak and at a known modulation frequency buried in broadband noise
Scientific Instruments.d: Completely random with no periodic component
Scientific Instruments.comment: By referencing the known modulation, lock-in recovers the coherent response with high SNR improvement.

Scientific Instruments.question: An integrating sphere is used to:
Scientific Instruments.a: Measure total luminous flux or reflectance by multiple scattering to produce uniform output
Scientific Instruments.comment: Integrating spheres collect all scattered light making measurement independent of beam shape or sample orientation.

Scientific Instruments.question: A calorimetric thermometer (e.g., platinum resistance) relies on which property?
Scientific Instruments.a: Change of electrical resistance with temperature (for PT100 etc.)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Resistance thermometers have stable and well-characterized R–T relationships used for precise temperature measurement.

Scientific Instruments.question: A dielectric constant meter measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Permittivity (ε_r) of materials by measuring capacitance of sample-filled capacitor
Scientific Instruments.comment: Dielectric properties measured vs frequency give insight into polarization mechanisms and losses (tan δ).

Scientific Instruments.question: Which instrument is used to visualize charged particle tracks and used historically in particle discovery?
Scientific Instruments.a: Cloud chamber or bubble chamber
Scientific Instruments.comment: Cloud/bubble chambers reveal ionization tracks enabling identification of particle type and interactions.

Scientific Instruments.question: A pH meter measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Hydrogen ion activity (pH) using a glass electrode producing voltage proportional to pH (Nernst equation)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Glass electrode voltage E ≈ (2.303 RT/F) (pH_ref − pH_sample) plus reference offset.

Scientific Instruments.question: Which characteristic of a measurement instrument indicates smallest change it can reliably detect?
Scientific Instruments.a: Resolution (or least count)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Resolution (or least count) is smallest measurable increment; different from accuracy and precision.

Scientific Instruments.question: Which term denotes closeness of repeated measurements to each other (scatter)?
Scientific Instruments.a: Precision
Scientific Instruments.comment: Precision = repeatability; accuracy = closeness to true value.

Scientific Instruments.question: Which term denotes closeness of measured value to the true or accepted standard?
Scientific Instruments.a: Accuracy
Scientific Instruments.comment: An instrument can be precise but not accurate if systematic error exists.

Scientific Instruments.question: Calibration of an instrument is the process of:
Scientific Instruments.a: Comparing and adjusting instrument response to known standards to minimize systematic errors
Scientific Instruments.comment: Calibration establishes the relation between instrument reading and known reference values and may include adjustment.

Scientific Instruments.question: Linearity of an instrument indicates:
Scientific Instruments.a: Output is proportional to input across its specified range
Scientific Instruments.comment: Nonlinearity requires correction or limits usefulness for accurate measurement across range.

Scientific Instruments.question: Hysteresis error of measuring instrument arises from:
Scientific Instruments.a: Different output when input is approached from increasing vs decreasing direction (due to internal friction, magnetic domains, etc.)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Hysteresis affects repeatability and is important in mechanical and magnetic sensors.

Scientific Instruments.question: Zero error (offset) in a measuring device should be:
Scientific Instruments.a: Determined and corrected for accurate measurement
Scientific Instruments.comment: Zero error is systematic and must be subtracted (or instrument adjusted) before taking readings.

Scientific Instruments.question: Sensitivity of an instrument is defined as:
Scientific Instruments.a: Change in output per unit change in input (slope of input–output curve)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Higher sensitivity means small input changes produce larger output changes, but may increase noise susceptibility.

Scientific Instruments.question: Which instrument uses polarized light to measure optical rotation of chiral substances?
Scientific Instruments.a: Polarimeter
Scientific Instruments.comment: Polarimeter measures angle of rotation caused by optically active solutes; used in chemistry/biology.

Scientific Instruments.question: A pH electrode requires calibration because:
Scientific Instruments.a: Glass electrode slope and offset vary over time and with temperature; calibration uses standard buffers
Scientific Instruments.b: It measures voltage only without temperature dependence
Scientific Instruments.c: It does not require any calibration
Scientific Instruments.comment: Calibration with pH 4, 7, 10 buffers sets slope and offset compensating for electrode drift and temperature.

Scientific Instruments.question: Dynamic range of a detector indicates:
Scientific Instruments.a: Ratio between maximum and minimum detectable signal levels (before saturation and above noise floor)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Large dynamic range is desirable to handle signals varying over many orders of magnitude.

Scientific Instruments.question: An integrating radiometer measures:
Scientific Instruments.a: Total radiant energy over time (integrated power), useful for dosimetry or photometry
Scientific Instruments.comment: Integrating detectors sum energy over exposure period; contrast with power meters measuring instantaneous flux.

Scientific Instruments.question: Which device converts a small current from a sensor (e.g., photodiode) into a voltage with low noise?
Scientific Instruments.a: Transimpedance amplifier (op-amp with feedback resistor)
Scientific Instruments.comment: Transimpedance amplifiers provide low-noise current-to-voltage conversion with bandwidth determined by feedback and input capacitances.

Scientific Instruments.question: Which instrument is best for measuring small capacitances (few pF)?
Scientific Instruments.a: LCR meter with appropriate low-parasitic fixture or bridge methods
Scientific Instruments.comment: Fast LCR meters and impedance analyzers with short leads and guard shielding measure pF-range capacitances accurately.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who is credited with formulating the three laws of motion and universal gravitation?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Newton (1687) published the laws of motion and law of universal gravitation in the Principia.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who performed the classical experiments on falling bodies and inclined planes that supported laws of motion?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Galileo's experiments (leaning tower, inclined plane) established uniform acceleration concepts.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered that light undergoes interference, supporting wave theory of light?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Young's double-slit experiment (1801) demonstrated interference, favoring wave nature of light.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Huygens is known for which principle in optics?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Huygens' principle treats every point on wavefront as source of secondary waves; useful in wave optics.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the law of refraction (Snell's law) linking angles and refractive index?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Snell's law: n₁ sin θ₁ = n₂ sin θ₂; historically attributed to Snell (17th century).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Which scientist discovered X-rays in 1895?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Röntgen observed unknown rays (X-rays) producing photographic effects and penetrating matter.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered radioactivity (spontaneous emission from uranium salts) in 1896?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Becquerel observed photographic plate fogging by uranium salts leading to discovery of natural radioactivity.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Which two scientists isolated polonium and radium and advanced radioactivity research?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: The Curies purified radioactive elements and studied radiation properties (late 1890s–early 1900s).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the electron (as a particle) in cathode-ray experiments in 1897?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Thomson measured charge-to-mass ratio e/m showing cathode rays are particles (electrons).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who measured the elementary charge of the electron (e) using the oil-drop experiment?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Millikan's oil-drop experiment (~1909) measured e and confirmed quantization of charge.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the atomic nucleus by α-particle scattering (gold foil experiment) in 1911?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Rutherford concluded atoms have small dense positive nucleus after large-angle α scattering.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the neutron in 1932?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Chadwick identified neutral massive particle (neutron), completing nucleon picture.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who formulated the planetary model of the atom with quantized orbits for electrons (1913)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Bohr introduced quantized angular momentum L = n ħ leading to discrete energy levels for hydrogen.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who proposed quantization of energy (E = h ν) to explain blackbody radiation, founding quantum theory?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Planck (1900) introduced quantum of action ħ (h) to derive blackbody spectrum.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who explained the photoelectric effect using light quanta (photons) in 1905?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Einstein proposed photons with energy E = h ν; awarded Nobel Prize for photoelectric explanation.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered Compton scattering (photon wavelength shift by electron) demonstrating particle nature of light?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Compton effect (1923) showed photon momentum transfer to electrons proving light has particle aspects.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who proposed de Broglie’s matter-wave hypothesis λ = h/p?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: De Broglie (1924) associated wavelength λ with particle momentum p, leading to electron diffraction experiments.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Which experiment confirmed electron wave nature via diffraction?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Davisson and Germer (1927) observed electron diffraction from crystal planes supporting de Broglie waves.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who developed wave mechanics (Schrödinger equation) in quantum theory?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Schrödinger (1926) formulated wave equation describing quantum states via wavefunctions ψ.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who formulated matrix mechanics and uncertainty principle in quantum mechanics?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Heisenberg introduced matrix formulation; his uncertainty principle Δx Δp ≥ ħ/2 is fundamental.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who predicted antimatter (positron) theoretically and who discovered it experimentally?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Dirac predicted; Carl D. Anderson discovered positron
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Dirac's relativistic equation (1928) implied antiparticles; Anderson observed positron in cosmic rays (1932).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who explained the origin of spectral lines of hydrogen using quantized orbits?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Bohr derived Rydberg formula for hydrogen energy levels E_n = −13.6 eV / n².

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the law of conservation of energy in mechanical and heat forms (Joule’s mechanical equivalent of heat)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Joule's experiments quantified conversion between mechanical work and heat (Joule ≈ 4.186 J/cal).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who is credited with founding thermodynamics via analysis of heat engines and Carnot cycle?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Carnot (1824) described ideal reversible heat engine and maximum efficiency dependent on temperatures.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who introduced the concept of entropy and formulated the second law of thermodynamics?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Clausius formalized entropy S and stated that for irreversible processes ΔS > 0; Kelvin also contributed first/second laws.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who developed statistical mechanics relating microscopic states to thermodynamic quantities (Boltzmann constant k_B)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Boltzmann linked entropy to microstates S = k_B ln Ω and pioneered statistical interpretation of thermodynamics.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the electron charge–mass ratio (e/m) and contributed to electron identification?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Thomson measured e/m using deflection in E and B fields; showed particles much lighter than atoms.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the law linking electric current and magnetic field (Oersted’s experiment)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Ørsted (1820) observed compass needle deflection due to current, revealing electricity–magnetism link.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who formulated Ampère’s force law relating currents and magnetic forces?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Ampère quantified interaction between currents; Biot–Savart and Ampère’s law are classic magnetostatics results.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered electromagnetic induction (changing magnetic flux produces emf)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Faraday (1831) demonstrated induced emf in coil when magnetic flux changes — basis of generators and transformers.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who unified electricity and magnetism into Maxwell's equations and predicted electromagnetic waves?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Maxwell's equations (mid-19th century) predicted EM waves that travel at speed c.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who experimentally demonstrated radio (electromagnetic) waves confirming Maxwell's prediction?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Hertz produced and detected radio waves (late 1880s), verifying Maxwell’s theory; Marconi later developed radio communication.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who invented the first practical radio communication system and received recognition for wireless telegraphy?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Marconi developed long-distance wireless telegraphy and won Nobel Prize-related recognition; historical credit has nuances.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the electron spin concept (intrinsic angular momentum) in atoms?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Uhlenbeck & Goudsmit (1925) proposed electron spin; Stern–Gerlach experiment demonstrated space quantization.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who performed the Stern–Gerlach experiment demonstrating space quantization of atomic magnetic moments?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Stern–Gerlach (1922) split silver atom beam into discrete spots showing quantized magnetic moment projection.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered superconductivity (zero resistance) in 1911?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Onnes observed Hg resistance drop to zero at ~4.2 K; BCS theory (Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer) explained mechanism later.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who formulated the photoelectric effect explanation that led to concept of photons and won a Nobel Prize in 1921?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Einstein's 1905 paper proposed quantized light energy E = h ν; Nobel recognized this contribution (not relativity).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the Compton wavelength shift formula for X-rays scattering off electrons (Compton effect)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Compton effect confirmed particle-like collisions between photons and electrons.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered Bragg diffraction (X-ray crystallography) establishing that crystals diffract X-rays?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: William Henry Bragg and William Lawrence Bragg
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Braggs developed X-ray crystallography; Laue earlier observed X-ray diffraction from crystals (Laue experiment).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the Compton effect, and what did it demonstrate about light?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Arthur H. Compton; it demonstrated the particle aspects of light (photon momentum)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Compton scattering shows photon momentum p = h/λ is exchanged with electrons producing wavelength shift.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the relativistic relation E = m c² and developed special relativity?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Einstein's 1905 special relativity linked energy and mass: E = m c² and introduced frame-independent laws for light speed c.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who measured the speed of light with high accuracy using rotating mirror method?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Fizeau and later Foucault with improved methods; Michelson made precise measurements
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Fizeau and Foucault measured c in 19th century; Michelson later made precise terrestrial measurements.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who first measured speed of light from astronomical observations of Jupiter's moons?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Rømer (1676) inferred finite light speed from timing discrepancies of Io's eclipses.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the law of electromagnetic induction (Faraday's law) relating emf to rate of change of magnetic flux?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Faraday's experiments showed changing magnetic flux induces emf; Maxwell gave differential form.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the electron diffraction by crystals that confirmed de Broglie hypothesis experimentally?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Davisson–Germer experiment (1927) provided direct evidence for matter waves.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the phenomenon of nuclear fission (splitting of heavy nucleus) experimentally?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Otto Hahn and Fritz Strassmann (with interpretation by Lise Meitner and Otto Frisch)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Hahn & Strassmann observed barium after neutron irradiation of uranium; Meitner/Frisch explained fission mechanism (1938–1939).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB) accidentally, giving evidence for Big Bang cosmology?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Penzias & Wilson (1965) detected isotropic microwave background at ~2.7 K confirming cosmological predictions.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who formulated Hubble's law (relation between galaxy recession speed and distance), establishing cosmic expansion?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Edwin Hubble (building on earlier theoretical and observational work)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Hubble (1929) empirically found v ∝ d; Lemaître and Friedmann had theoretical/earlier observational contributions.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the quantization of angular momentum and energy levels in atoms (Bohr model), explaining hydrogen spectrum?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Bohr postulated angular momentum L = n ħ and derived spectral lines consistent with Rydberg formula.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the Hall effect (transverse voltage in current-carrying conductor in B field)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Hall (1879) measured transverse voltage enabling determination of carrier sign and density.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the Zeeman effect (splitting of spectral lines in magnetic field)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Zeeman effect (1896) showed magnetically induced splitting; important for atomic structure and magnetic measurements.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the Stark effect (splitting of spectral lines in electric field)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Stark effect complements Zeeman and provided insight into atomic energy shifts under external fields.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered Raman scattering (inelastic scattering of light revealing vibrational modes)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Raman (1928) observed wavelength-shifted scattered light giving molecular vibrational information; Nobel Prize in 1930.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who introduced the concept of special relativity prior to general relativity and postulated constancy of speed of light?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Einstein's 1905 special relativity postulates constancy of c and equivalence of inertial frames, leading to time dilation/length contraction.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who developed general theory of relativity, describing gravity as curvature of spacetime?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Einstein (1915) formulated GR; Hilbert and others worked on mathematical foundations; prediction include light bending, perihelion precession.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the muon in cosmic rays (initially called 'mesotron')?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Carl D. Anderson and Seth Neddermeyer observed muon (1936)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Anderson & Neddermeyer observed a particle heavier than electron but lighter than proton; named muon later.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who predicted and who discovered the neutrino concept to save energy conservation in β-decay?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Pauli proposed neutrino; Reines & Cowan detected it experimentally
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Pauli (1930) proposed neutral particle; Reines & Cowan detected antineutrino in 1956.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who developed quantum electrodynamics (QED) incorporating relativity and quantum theory for EM interactions?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Richard Feynman, Julian Schwinger and Sin-Itiro Tomonaga (independently developed formulations)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Feynman diagrams and renormalized QED provided precise predictions; all three shared Nobel Prize (1965).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who invented the transistor (solid-state amplifier/switch) at Bell Labs in 1947?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: John Bardeen, Walter Brattain and William Shockley
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Point-contact transistor (Bardeen & Brattain) and subsequent junction transistor (Shockley) revolutionized electronics.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who demonstrated stimulated emission (basis for lasers) and who built the first working laser?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Einstein predicted stimulated emission; Theodore Maiman built first laser (1960)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Einstein introduced stimulated emission concept (1917); Maiman built first ruby laser; Townes and Schawlow also pivotal.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the Josephson effect (supercurrent tunneling) and its use in precision voltage standards?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Josephson predicted Cooper pair tunneling leading to quantized voltage steps; confirmed experimentally (Nobel 1973).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) independently and laid foundation for MRI?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Bloch and Purcell (1946) developed NMR techniques; Rabi earlier developed molecular beam resonance methods.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the tunnel effect phenomenon in quantum mechanics (electron tunneling) and applied it to devices (tunnel diode)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Leo Esaki observed tunneling in semiconductors (Esaki diode)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Esaki (1958) observed negative differential resistance due to tunneling; foundational to tunneling devices.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the photovoltaic effect (conversion of light to electricity) leading to solar cells?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Edmond Becquerel (early observation); later selenium/Si solar cell developments credited to others (e.g., Bell Labs)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Becquerel observed photoelectric effect in electrolytes (1839); modern solid-state solar cells developed in 20th century (Bell Labs, Chapin et al.).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the phenomenon of Cherenkov radiation (blue glow in nuclear reactors)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Pavel A. Cherenkov (with Frank and Tamm explaining theory)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Cherenkov radiation occurs when charged particles travel faster than phase velocity of light in medium; Frank and Tamm provided theory.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the cosmic-ray particles and initiated cosmic-ray physics?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Victor Hess (balloon experiments showing ionizing radiation increases with altitude)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Hess (1912) showed ionizing radiation originates from above atmosphere, leading to cosmic-ray studies.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the magnetoresistance giant effect (GMR) that revolutionized hard-drive read heads?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Albert Fert and Peter Grünberg independently discovered GMR
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Fert and Grünberg (1988) found large resistance changes in magnetic multilayers; led to advances in data storage (Nobel 2007).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who first demonstrated superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) sensitivity using Josephson junctions?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Developed by multiple researchers building on Josephson effect; SQUIDs realize extreme magnetic sensitivity
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: SQUIDs exploit Josephson junctions and flux quantization for ultra-sensitive magnetometry; many contributors across labs.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the lack of ether by the Michelson–Morley experiment, influencing relativity?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Albert A. Michelson and Edward W. Morley
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Michelson–Morley (1887) null result contradicted luminiferous ether hypothesis, paving way for special relativity.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the phenomenon of electron-positron pair production from high-energy photons?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Observed by experiments following theoretical proposals; concept stems from Dirac's theory and experiments in 1930s/40s
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Dirac predicted antiparticles; pair production observed in high-energy photon interactions with nuclei (requires ≥2 m_e c²).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who developed the first practical X-ray crystallography method for determining crystal structures?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Bragg's law (n λ = 2 d sin θ) relates X-ray wavelength to lattice spacing enabling structure determination.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who developed the first electrical generator principle converting mechanical rotation to electricity (dynamo principle)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Michael Faraday (Faraday disk and induction principles)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Faraday's experiments and Faraday disk showed how motion in magnetic field produces emf; later designs improved practicality.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the law of conservation of charge (electric charge conservation) in circuits and conductors?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Charge conservation is fundamental; formal continuity equation derived later, but principle recognized via experiments (early work by Coulomb and others)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Conservation of charge follows from observations and Maxwell's equations (∇·J + ∂ρ/∂t = 0) — not a single-person discovery.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered radioactive decay law (exponential decay) and concept of half-life?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Ernest Rutherford and Frederick Soddy formalized decay law; earlier work by Becquerel and Curie identified radioactivity
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Rutherford and Soddy developed mathematical description of decay and concept of half-life and transmutation.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the origin of X-ray diffraction patterns and used them to study crystal structure?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Max von Laue (Laue diffraction) and Braggs developed methods
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Laue first observed X-ray diffraction by crystals; Braggs interpreted patterns for structure determination.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the effect of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) that later led to MRI in medicine?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Bloch and Purcell independently observed NMR signals; MRI uses NMR principles for imaging tissues.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the quantum Hall effect (precision quantization of Hall resistance)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Von Klitzing (1980) found quantized Hall resistance R_H = h/(e² ν) enabling resistance standards (Nobel 1985).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered Bose–Einstein statistics and predicted Bose–Einstein condensation?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Satyendra Nath Bose and Albert Einstein (Bose's paper generalized, Einstein extended to condensation)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Bose derived photon statistics; Einstein applied ideas to atoms predicting condensation at low T (observed experimentally much later).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered Fermi–Dirac statistics describing fermions with Pauli exclusion?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Enrico Fermi and Paul Dirac independently developed Fermi–Dirac statistics
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Fermi–Dirac distribution applies to particles with half-integer spin obeying exclusion principle.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered that cosmic rays include muons and pions which opened particle physics era?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Multiple experimenters (Anderson, Neddermeyer, Powell et al.) studied cosmic-ray particles revealing new particles
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Cosmic-ray studies led to discovery of new particles (positron, muon, pion) before accelerator era.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the photoelectric effect in metals leading to quantum theory of light energy transfer?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Heinrich Hertz observed effect; Einstein explained it theoretically
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Hertz observed emission; Einstein proposed quantization explaining kinetic energy of emitted electrons; Millikan experimentally verified Einstein's relation.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who established the concept of wave–particle duality and advanced quantum interpretation?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Louis de Broglie & later complementarity by Niels Bohr; many contributed (Einstein, Schrödinger, Heisenberg)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Wave–particle duality is cornerstone of quantum mechanics; de Broglie proposed matter waves, Bohr proposed complementarity principle.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the law of electrostatics (Coulomb's law) by torsion balance measurements?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Coulomb (1785) measured force between charges ∝ 1/r² using torsion balance, analogous to Newton's law of gravitation.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who developed the theory of chemical bonds and valence via quantum mechanics (valence bond / molecular orbital ideas)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Linus Pauling and others applied quantum principles to chemistry
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Pauling (and Mulliken, Hund) applied quantum concepts to explain covalent/ionic bonding; important interdisciplinary discovery.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered that the charge carriers in metals are electrons and quantified electron contribution to conductivity (Drude/ Sommerfeld models)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Paul Drude proposed electron conduction model; Arnold Sommerfeld added quantum corrections
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Drude (classical) and Sommerfeld (quantum free-electron) models explain metallic conductivity and heat capacity approximations.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who introduced the concept of quantized conductance and single-electron phenomena in mesoscopic physics?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Multiple contributors; Landauer and others developed theory; experimental quantized conductance observed later (van Wees, Wharam)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Mesoscopic discoveries emerged in late 20th century; quantized conductance steps observed in quantum point contacts.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the principle behind the atomic bomb via chain reaction (critical mass & fission) in theoretical/experimental works?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Scientific discoveries by many (Hahn/Strassmann/Meitner/Frisch discovered fission; chain reaction analysis by Szilárd and others led to reactors/weapons)
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Multiple scientists contributed to fission discovery and chain reaction concepts; Szilárd, Fermi, and others built the first reactor.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the phenomenon of blackbody radiation and formulated the classical Rayleigh–Jeans law that failed at short wavelengths (ultraviolet catastrophe)?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Lord Rayleigh and James Jeans developed classical law; Planck resolved UV catastrophe with quantization
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Rayleigh–Jeans matched long wavelengths but diverged at short; Planck's quantization corrected spectrum.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who experimentally verified time dilation using precise clocks on fast-moving aircraft or satellites?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Hafele–Keating experiment and GPS system observations confirmed relativistic time dilation
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Hafele & Keating (1971) flew atomic clocks; GPS routinely applies special and general relativity corrections.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the electron's magnetic moment anomaly and gave precise QED tests?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Precision measurements by many; theoretical QED predictions by Schwinger, Feynman, etc. matched experiments
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Electron g-2 measurements are sensitive tests of QED with extremely precise agreement between theory and experiment.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered that light pressure exists (radiation pressure) and helped quantify it theoretically/experimentally?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: James Clerk Maxwell predicted radiation pressure; Lebedev and Nichols–Hull measured it experimentally
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Maxwell's EM theory predicted momentum in EM waves; experimental verification by Lebedev (Russia) and Nichols & Hull (USA).

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who discovered the phenomenon of electron capture and positron emission as nuclear processes?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Electron capture and β⁺/β⁻ processes were observed and explained through weak interaction theory; specifics by many researchers
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Beta processes required weak interaction theory (Fermi) and later electroweak unification; many experimental discoverers.

Invention and Important Discoveries in P.question: Who first observed the effect of superconducting flux quantization and persistent currents in superconducting rings?
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.a: Experiments by Deaver & Fairbank and Doll & Näbauer observed flux quantization confirming quantum nature of superconductivity
Invention and Important Discoveries in P.comment: Flux quantization (h/2e) confirmed pairing of electrons (Cooper pairs) in superconductors.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Chemistry is best defined as the science that studies:
Introduction to Chemistry.b: The composition, structure, properties and changes of matter
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Chemistry focuses on matter and the transformations it undergoes (atoms, molecules, reactions).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which branch of chemistry deals with carbon-containing compounds?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Organic chemistry studies carbon compounds, especially hydrocarbons and their derivatives.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which is the correct SI base unit for amount of substance?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Mole (mol) is the SI unit for amount of substance (6.022×10²³ entities per mole).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Avogadro's number is approximately:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Avogadro's number (N_A) is ≈ 6.02214076×10²³ entities·mol⁻¹.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which law states that mass is neither created nor destroyed in a chemical reaction?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Lavoisier's law: total mass of reactants = total mass of products in a chemical reaction (closed system).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: The law of definite proportions (or constant composition) states that:
Introduction to Chemistry.a: A compound always contains elements in the same mass ratio
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Volume of gases combine in simple ratios
Introduction to Chemistry.d: All atoms of an element have same mass
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: A given chemical compound always contains the same proportion by mass of its constituent elements.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which statement is a postulate of Dalton's atomic theory (as originally stated)?
Introduction to Chemistry.b: All atoms of an element are identical in every respect (modernly refined due to isotopes)
Introduction to Chemistry.c: Compounds are formed by combinations of atoms in small whole-number ratios
Introduction to Chemistry.d: All of the above (original Daltonian form)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Dalton proposed atoms as indivisible particles combining in whole-number ratios; later refinements introduced isotopes and subatomic structure.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which subatomic particle has a negative charge?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Electrons (e⁻) are negatively charged; protons (p⁺) are positive; neutrons (n⁰) are neutral.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: The atomic number (Z) of an element equals the number of:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Atomic number Z equals number of protons and defines the element. For neutral atoms, electrons = Z.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Isotopes are atoms of the same element that differ in:
Introduction to Chemistry.c: Number of neutrons (hence different mass numbers)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Isotopes have same Z (protons) but different neutron counts (different mass numbers).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following is an example of an isotope pair?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: ³⁵Cl and ³⁷Cl are isotopes of chlorine (same Z = 17, different mass numbers).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: The mass number (A) of an atom equals:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Mass number A = protons + neutrons in nucleus (approximately nucleon count).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which model proposed a dense positively charged nucleus with electrons orbiting around it?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Rutherford's α-particle scattering experiment led to nuclear model (dense nucleus, electrons outside).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Bohr's model explained which experimental observation for hydrogen-like atoms?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Bohr quantized electron orbits to explain discrete spectral lines of hydrogen (Rydberg formula).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which principle states that it is impossible to simultaneously know both the exact position and exact momentum of an electron?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Heisenberg uncertainty principle is fundamental to quantum mechanics.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Pauli exclusion principle states that:
Introduction to Chemistry.a: No two electrons in an atom can have the same set of four quantum numbers
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Electrons can share same quantum state freely
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Pauli principle explains electron configuration limits (max two electrons per orbital with opposite spins).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which quantum number describes the shape of an atomic orbital?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: l determines orbital shape: s (l=0), p (l=1), d (l=2), f (l=3).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: What is the electronic configuration shorthand for oxygen (Z = 8)?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Oxygen has 8 electrons: fills 1s, 2s and 2p (2p⁴).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which orbitals are being filled in the 3rd period elements after argon (in Aufbau sequence)?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Period 3 filling: 3s → 3p (3p completes at Ar). 3d filling begins in period 4 elements (Sc onward).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following best describes an atom in its ground state?
Introduction to Chemistry.a: All electrons in lowest possible energy levels
Introduction to Chemistry.b: One electron excited to higher level
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Ground state = lowest energy electron configuration.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: An ion with symbol Na⁺ has:
Introduction to Chemistry.a: One extra electron compared to neutral Na
Introduction to Chemistry.b: One fewer electron than neutral Na (11 protons, 10 electrons)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Na⁺ results from loss of one electron; protons remain unchanged.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which is a chemical formula for table salt?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Sodium chloride (NaCl) is common table salt.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Molar mass of water (H₂O) in g·mol⁻¹ is approximately:
How many moles are there in 44.01 g of CO₂ (M = 44.01 g·mol⁻¹)?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Moles = mass / molar mass = 44.01 / 44.01 = 1.0 mol.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which term describes a mixture that is uniform throughout and has only one phase?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Homogeneous mixtures (solutions) have uniform composition (e.g., salt in water).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which separation technique is based on different boiling points of components?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Distillation separates volatile components by selective vaporization and condensation.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which technique separates components of a mixture based on differential adsorption on a stationary phase?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Chromatography (paper, TLC, column) uses stationary and mobile phases to separate analytes.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which property is defined as mass per unit volume?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Density ρ = mass / volume (e.g., g·cm⁻³ or kg·m⁻³).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: What is the molarity (M) of a solution containing 1.0 mol solute in 2.0 L solution?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Molarity = moles solute / liters solution = 1.0 / 2.0 = 0.5 M.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Molality (m) differs from molarity (M) because molality is defined per:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Molality = moles solute / kg solvent; useful as it is temperature independent.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: A soluble ionic compound that dissociates into ions in water is called a:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Strong electrolytes (e.g., NaCl, HCl) dissociate into ions and conduct electricity in solution.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which pH value corresponds to a neutral solution at 25 °C?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Pure water at 25 °C has [H⁺] = 1×10⁻⁷ M → pH = 7 (neutral).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following is a Bronsted–Lowry acid?
Introduction to Chemistry.c: Species that accepts an electron pair
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Bronsted–Lowry acid = proton donor; base = proton acceptor.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of these is a Lewis acid?
Introduction to Chemistry.a: Species that donates an electron pair
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Species that accepts an electron pair (e.g., BF₃)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Lewis acid accepts electron pair; Lewis base donates pair (wider definition than Bronsted).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which is the correct balanced chemical equation for combustion of methane?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Complete combustion: CH₄ + 2O₂ → CO₂ + 2H₂O (balanced for atoms).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: In a redox reaction, oxidation is defined as:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Oxidation = loss of electrons; reduction = gain of electrons (OIL RIG mnemonic).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which element generally acts as the oxidizing agent in redox reactions?
Introduction to Chemistry.b: The species that is reduced (accepts electrons)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Oxidizing agent oxidizes another species by being reduced itself (accepts electrons).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following is a sign of a chemical change?
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Color change, gas evolution, precipitation or heat change
Introduction to Chemistry.d: Simple mixing with no new substance formed
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Observables like gas evolution, precipitate formation, color or temperature change often indicate chemical reaction.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which factor does NOT generally affect the rate of a chemical reaction?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Reaction rate depends on concentration, temperature, surface area, catalysts; color of container is irrelevant unless it affects light exposure.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: A catalyst functions by:
Introduction to Chemistry.a: Being consumed permanently in the reaction
Introduction to Chemistry.c: Lowering activation energy and providing an alternative pathway
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Catalysts accelerate reaction kinetics by lowering activation energy; they are not consumed in net reaction.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which statement best describes chemical equilibrium in a closed system?
Introduction to Chemistry.a: All reactants are completely converted to products
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Forward and reverse reaction rates are equal and macroscopic properties remain constant
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: At equilibrium, concentrations can be constant while reactions continue at equal forward and reverse rates.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Le Chatelier's principle predicts that if a system at equilibrium is subjected to stress (change in concentration, pressure or temperature), the system will:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: System shifts to partially counteract imposed change to re-establish equilibrium.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which gas law relates pressure and volume at constant temperature (P₁V₁ = P₂V₂)?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Boyle's law: P ∝ 1/V at constant T and amount of gas.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which law states that equal volumes of gases at same temperature and pressure contain equal numbers of molecules?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Avogadro's hypothesis: V ∝ n (at constant T and P).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which unit is commonly used for atmospheric pressure at sea level approximately?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Standard atmospheric pressure is 101.325 kilopascals (kPa) ≈ 1 atm.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of these laboratory glassware gives the most accurate single-volume measurement?
Introduction to Chemistry.d: Graduated cylinder (least accurate compared to volumetric pipette)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Volumetric pipettes/flasks are calibrated for high accuracy for a single volume; graduated cylinders are less precise.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which chemical safety symbol indicates a substance that is corrosive to skin and metals?
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Corrosion (test tube and hand/metal being corroded)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Corrosive pictogram warns of acids/alkalis that can destroy tissue and metals.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which procedure is correct if concentrated acid spills on the skin?
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Rinse immediately with plenty of water and seek medical attention
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Immediate flushing with water is critical; neutralization should be done by professionals if needed.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which statement about experimental error is correct?
Introduction to Chemistry.a: Systematic errors affect accuracy and can often be corrected
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Random errors affect precision and are unpredictable
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Systematic errors bias results; random errors cause scatter—both are important in measurements.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following is an extensive property (depends on amount of matter)?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Mass and volume are extensive; density and temperature are intensive (independent of amount).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following is an intensive property?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Intensive properties (e.g., density, temperature, color) do not depend on sample size.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which type of bond is formed by sharing of electron pairs between atoms?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Covalent bonds involve pair(s) of electrons shared by atoms to achieve octet configurations.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Ionic compounds typically:
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Conduct electricity when molten or dissolved in water (ions mobile)
Introduction to Chemistry.c: Are malleable and ductile like metals
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Ionic solids conduct when ions are free to move (molten or aqueous); solids are brittle and insulating.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following is the correct empirical formula for a compound with 40% C, 6.7% H, 53.3% O by mass?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Convert % to relative moles: C 40/12=3.33, H 6.7/1=6.7, O 53.3/16=3.33 → ratio ≈ 1:2:1 → CH₂O.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of the following is NOT a physical change?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Combustion is a chemical change producing new substances; the others are physical changes.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: The term 'stoichiometry' in chemistry refers to:
Introduction to Chemistry.b: Quantitative relationship between reactants and products in chemical reactions
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Stoichiometry uses balanced chemical equations to relate moles and masses of substances.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which concept best describes 'limiting reagent' in a chemical reaction?
Introduction to Chemistry.b: The reagent that is completely consumed first, limiting the amount of product
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Limiting reagent determines theoretical yield because it runs out before others.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Percent yield is calculated as:
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Percent yield measures efficiency of reaction compared to stoichiometric maximum (theoretical yield).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which quantity is conserved in a chemical reaction (assuming closed system) besides mass?
Introduction to Chemistry.a: Charge and number of each element (atoms)
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: In chemical equations, atoms of each element and net electric charge are conserved; electrons accounted in redox.

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which term describes a homogeneous mixture of two or more substances?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Solution is a homogeneous mixture (solute dispersed uniformly in solvent).

Introduction to Chemistry.question: Which of these is an example of a heterogeneous mixture?
Introduction to Chemistry.comment: Oil and water form two separate phases (heterogeneous). Air and vinegar are homogeneous mixtures.

States of Matter.question: Which of the following is not a state of matter?
States of Matter.comment: Heat is energy, not a physical state.

States of Matter.question: Which state of matter has a definite shape and definite volume?
States of Matter.comment: Solids retain both shape and volume.

States of Matter.question: Which state of matter has particles with the highest kinetic energy?
States of Matter.comment: Plasma contains ionized particles with extremely high kinetic energy.

States of Matter.question: In which state are intermolecular forces maximum?
States of Matter.comment: Strong forces hold particles tightly in solids.

States of Matter.question: Which of the following states of matter is known as the fourth state?
States of Matter.comment: Plasma is considered the fourth state of matter.

States of Matter.question: Which law states that pressure is inversely proportional to volume?
States of Matter.comment: Boyle's Law: P ∝ 1/V at constant temperature.

States of Matter.question: Which law states that volume is directly proportional to temperature?
States of Matter.comment: Charles' Law: V ∝ T at constant pressure.

States of Matter.question: Which of the following is an example of sublimation?
States of Matter.comment: Dry ice directly becomes CO₂ gas.

States of Matter.question: The SI unit of pressure is:
States of Matter.comment: Pascal (Pa) is the SI unit of pressure.

States of Matter.question: Which state of matter has no definite shape but definite volume?
States of Matter.comment: Liquids have fixed volume but take shape of the container.

States of Matter.question: Which state of matter is most compressible?
Which gas law relates volume and number of moles?
States of Matter.comment: Avogadro's Law: V ∝ n at constant T, P.

States of Matter.question: What is the temperature at which solid changes to liquid called?
States of Matter.comment: Melting point is solid → liquid transition temperature.

States of Matter.question: Which property is the measure of the random motion of molecules?
In which process does a gas convert directly into a solid?
Which state of matter has the strongest intermolecular attraction?
At constant pressure, the volume of a gas is proportional to:
Which law states that equal volumes of gases contain equal number of molecules?
Which property do gases exhibit significantly more than solids?
Plasma is electrically:
States of Matter.comment: Plasma overall is neutral but contains charged particles.

States of Matter.question: What is the SI unit of volume?
Which state of matter is found in stars?
Solid CO₂ is also called:
Which of the following decreases with increase in temperature?
Which of the following has the least intermolecular space?
Which process involves liquid → gas at any temperature?
Boiling point of a liquid increases when:
The temperature at which liquid converts to gas throughout the liquid is:
Gases can be liquefied by:
States of Matter.comment: High pressure + low temperature liquefies gases.

States of Matter.question: Which factor increases the rate of evaporation?
States of Matter.comment: Wind removes vapor quickly increasing evaporation.

States of Matter.question: Which of the following is the slowest process?
Which property of gases explains why they fill the entire container?
States of Matter.comment: Gases diffuse rapidly to fill space.

States of Matter.question: Which of the following is used to measure pressure of gas?
Which gas law combines Boyle’s and Charles' laws?
States of Matter.comment: Combined gas law relates P, V and T.

States of Matter.question: At which temperature is absolute zero?
Which state of matter has the ability to flow?
Which of the following is not a property of solids?
Which of the following states can conduct electricity?
Which property is maximum in solids?
Rate of diffusion is highest in:
Intermolecular space is highest in:
What is the unit of gas constant R in SI?

Atomic Structure.question: Who proposed the indivisible, smallest particle called 'atom'?
Atomic Structure.comment: Dalton proposed that matter is made of indivisible atoms (early atomic theory).

Atomic Structure.question: Which experiment led to the discovery of the nucleus?
Atomic Structure.comment: Rutherford's gold foil experiment revealed a small dense, positively charged nucleus.

Atomic Structure.question: Who discovered the electron?
Atomic Structure.comment: J.J. Thomson discovered the electron from cathode ray experiments.

Atomic Structure.question: Which scientist measured the charge of the electron using oil drop experiment?
Atomic Structure.comment: Millikan's oil-drop experiment measured the electron's charge.

Atomic Structure.question: Who discovered the neutron?
Atomic Structure.comment: James Chadwick discovered the neutron in 1932.

Atomic Structure.question: The mass number of an atom is the sum of:
Atomic Structure.comment: Mass number A = Z (protons) + N (neutrons).

Atomic Structure.question: Atomic number (Z) of an element equals the number of:
Atomic Structure.comment: Atomic number = number of protons (and for neutral atom, electrons).

Atomic Structure.question: Isotopes are atoms of the same element that differ in:
Atomic Structure.comment: Isotopes have same Z but different N (different mass numbers).

Atomic Structure.question: Isobars are species having the same:
Atomic Structure.comment: Isobars have different Z but same mass number A.

Atomic Structure.question: Which model introduced quantized electron orbits with fixed energies?
Atomic Structure.comment: Bohr model (for hydrogen-like atoms) proposed quantized circular orbits.

Atomic Structure.question: According to Bohr’s model, emission of light occurs when an electron:
Atomic Structure.a: Moves from lower to higher orbit
Atomic Structure.c: Moves from higher to lower orbit
Atomic Structure.comment: Emission occurs when electron falls to a lower energy level (releasing photon).

Atomic Structure.question: Which of the following is not explained by Bohr’s model?
Atomic Structure.d: Quantization of angular momentum (in Bohr's assumption)
Atomic Structure.comment: Bohr’s model fails for multi-electron atoms and fine structure details.

Atomic Structure.question: Quantum numbers describe the distribution of electrons. The principal quantum number 'n' indicates:
Atomic Structure.comment: 'n' denotes the principal energy level (shell) and size of orbital.

Atomic Structure.question: The azimuthal (angular momentum) quantum number 'l' determines:
Atomic Structure.b: Shape of the orbital (s, p, d, f)
Atomic Structure.comment: l = 0,1,2,3 correspond to s, p, d, f orbital shapes respectively.

Atomic Structure.question: Magnetic quantum number 'm_l' indicates:
Atomic Structure.comment: m_l ranges from -l to +l and gives orbital orientation.

Atomic Structure.question: The spin quantum number 'm_s' for electrons can have values:
Atomic Structure.comment: Electron spin is +1/2 or −1/2 according to Pauli spin quantum number.

Atomic Structure.question: Pauli exclusion principle states that:
Atomic Structure.a: No two electrons in an atom can have same set of four quantum numbers
Atomic Structure.c: Total charge of atom is zero
Atomic Structure.comment: Pauli principle restricts occupancy: unique set of quantum numbers per electron.

Atomic Structure.question: Hund’s rule states that for degenerate orbitals, electrons fill to:
Atomic Structure.b: Maximize total spin (one electron per orbital first)
Atomic Structure.comment: Hund's rule: maximize unpaired electrons with parallel spins in degenerate orbitals.

Atomic Structure.question: Aufbau principle is used to determine:
Atomic Structure.a: Order of electron filling into atomic orbitals
Atomic Structure.comment: Aufbau (building-up) principle prescribes filling lowest energy orbitals first.

Atomic Structure.question: Which orbital has spherical shape?
Atomic Structure.comment: s orbitals are spherical around the nucleus.

Atomic Structure.question: Which orbital has a dumbbell shape?
Atomic Structure.comment: p orbitals have two lobes (dumbbell-shaped).

Atomic Structure.question: Maximum number of electrons that can occupy an energy level with principal quantum number n is:
Atomic Structure.comment: Each shell can hold 2n² electrons (sum of electrons in all subshells).

Atomic Structure.question: Which of the following gives the probability distribution of an electron around the nucleus?
Atomic Structure.comment: Quantum mechanics describes electron by wavefunction ψ; |ψ|² is probability density.

Atomic Structure.question: The term 'orbital' in modern atomic theory refers to:
Atomic Structure.b: Region of space with high probability of finding an electron
Atomic Structure.comment: Orbital = region where electron presence is most probable.

Atomic Structure.question: Which of these is a correct electronic configuration for ground state of carbon (Z=6)?
Atomic Structure.comment: Carbon: 6 electrons → 1s² 2s² 2p².

Atomic Structure.question: Which notation correctly denotes an alpha particle?
Atomic Structure.comment: Alpha particle is a helium nucleus: mass 4, charge +2 (⁴₂He).

Atomic Structure.question: Beta radiation (β⁻) consists of:
Atomic Structure.comment: β⁻ decay emits electrons and an antineutrino.

Atomic Structure.question: Which particle has no charge and about the same mass as proton?
Atomic Structure.comment: Neutron is neutral and similar mass to proton (~1 u).

Atomic Structure.question: Relative atomic mass of an atom compared to 1/12 mass of carbon-12 is called:
Atomic Structure.comment: Ar is weighted average of isotopic masses relative to 1/12 C-12.

Atomic Structure.question: Which of the following best describes 'isotones'?
Atomic Structure.a: Same atomic number, different mass numbers
Atomic Structure.b: Same neutron number, different proton number
Atomic Structure.c: Same mass number, different atomic number
Atomic Structure.comment: Isotones share same N (neutron number) but different Z.

Atomic Structure.question: What is the correct symbol for an electron?
Atomic Structure.comment: Electron often denoted as ⁰₋₁e (mass number 0, charge −1).

Atomic Structure.question: Which experimentally observed phenomenon supports particle nature of light?
Atomic Structure.comment: Photoelectric effect demonstrates light quanta (photons).

Atomic Structure.question: Planck introduced the idea of quantization to explain:
Atomic Structure.comment: Planck proposed energy quanta (E= hν) to resolve ultraviolet catastrophe.

Atomic Structure.question: Which constant is Planck's constant?
Atomic Structure.comment: Planck's constant h ≈ 6.626×10⁻³⁴ J·s.

Atomic Structure.question: The de Broglie relation associates wavelength λ with momentum p by:
Atomic Structure.comment: de Broglie wavelength λ = h/p (h = Planck's constant).

Atomic Structure.question: Which of the following is true about electrons in the quantum model?
Atomic Structure.a: They orbit nucleus in fixed circular paths only
Atomic Structure.b: They have wave–particle duality and are described by orbitals
Atomic Structure.d: They have definite position and momentum simultaneously
Atomic Structure.comment: Quantum model treats electrons as wave–particle with probabilistic orbitals.

Atomic Structure.question: Emission spectrum consisting of discrete lines indicates that:
Atomic Structure.comment: Discrete spectral lines arise from transitions between quantized energy levels.

Atomic Structure.question: Which series in hydrogen spectrum corresponds to transitions ending at n=2?
Atomic Structure.comment: Balmer series: transitions to n=2 (visible region).

Atomic Structure.question: Lyman series lines in hydrogen are in which region of electromagnetic spectrum?
Atomic Structure.comment: Lyman (to n=1) lies in ultraviolet region.

Atomic Structure.question: Which of the following is the value of Avogadro's number (approx)?
Atomic Structure.comment: Avogadro's number ≈ 6.022×10²³ entities per mole.

Atomic Structure.question: 1 atomic mass unit (u) is defined as 1/12th mass of which isotope?
Atomic Structure.comment: 1 u = 1/12 mass of carbon-12 atom.

Atomic Structure.question: Which of the following is used to represent average atomic mass of an element?
Atomic Structure.comment: Ar denotes relative (average) atomic mass.

Atomic Structure.question: Atomic emission occurs when:
Atomic Structure.a: An electron absorbs a photon and moves to higher energy
Atomic Structure.b: An electron falls to lower energy emitting a photon
Atomic Structure.comment: Emission: electron transition to lower level with photon release.

Atomic Structure.question: Which of these is NOT a valid set of quantum numbers for an electron?
Atomic Structure.comment: For n=3, l can be 0,1,2 only; l=3 is invalid.

Atomic Structure.question: Which principle states that position and momentum cannot be simultaneously known exactly?
