Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Primary alcohol: −OH attached to a carbon bonded to at most one other carbon (ethanol).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which is the main product when 2-methylpropene (isobutene) undergoes HBr addition in presence of peroxides?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Peroxide effect gives anti-Markovnikov addition via radical mechanism.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is the test for unsaturation in an organic compound?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Bromine decolorization indicates presence of C=C or C≡C (unsaturation).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Polyethylene is formed by polymerization of monomer:
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Polymerization of ethene (addition polymerization) yields polyethylene (–CH₂–CH₂–)_n.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which type of polymerization produces nylon 6,6 from hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Nylon 6,6 forms via condensation polymerization with elimination of water (amide linkage formation).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which compound is produced by complete combustion of hydrocarbons?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Complete combustion in presence of excess O₂ yields CO₂ (carbon oxidized) and H₂O (hydrogen oxidized).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is an example of functional isomerism?
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Butane and isobutane (constitutional isomers same functional group)
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Ethanol (alcohol) and dimethyl ether (ether) have same molecular formula but different functional groups → functional isomerism.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which isomerism is shown by 1-butene and 2-butene?
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Position isomerism (positional isomers of double bond)
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Double bond position differs (1-butene vs 2-butene) → positional isomerism.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which compound undergoes Markovnikov hydration to give 2-propanol from propene?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Acid-catalyzed hydration (H⁺/H₂O) adds H to less substituted C, giving more substituted alcohol (Markovnikov).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent can convert an alkene into a diol (vicinal diol) via syn addition?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Cold, dilute KMnO₄ (oxidative but mild) converts alkenes to cis-vicinal diols (syn addition).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following organic compounds gives a yellow precipitate with 2,4-dinitrophenylhydrazine (2,4-DNP)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: 2,4-DNP reacts with carbonyl compounds (aldehydes/ketones) forming hydrazones (yellow/orange precipitates).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which compound has the highest boiling point among isomeric C₄H₁₀O species: butan-1-ol, butan-2-ol, diethyl ether (C₂H₅–O–C₂H₅)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Primary alcohols (butan-1-ol) can hydrogen bond more effectively giving higher b.p. than ethers or secondary alcohols (butan-2-ol slightly lower).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which class of compounds undergoes saponification (base-catalyzed hydrolysis) to give soap (salt of fatty acid)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Esters (fats/oils) hydrolyze under base to glycerol and fatty acid salts (soaps).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: What is produced when an ester (R–COOR') is hydrolyzed in acid medium?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Acid-catalyzed hydrolysis of ester regenerates carboxylic acid and alcohol.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent oxidizes primary alcohols to carboxylic acids (strong oxidizer)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Strong oxidants (acidic KMnO₄, K₂Cr₂O₇) oxidize primary alcohols fully to carboxylic acids.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is a carboxylic acid?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: CH₃COOH is acetic acid (contains −COOH group).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is true about carboxylic acids?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: They are weaker acids than alcohols
Carbon and its Compounds.b: They are stronger acids than alcohols due to resonance stabilization of carboxylate anion
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Carboxylate anion (RCOO⁻) is resonance-stabilized, making carboxylic acids relatively acidic.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent is typically used for esterification of a carboxylic acid with an alcohol (Fischer esterification)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Fischer esterification (acid-catalyzed) converts R–COOH + R'–OH ⇌ R–COOR' + H₂O.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is a reducing agent used to reduce aldehydes/ketones to alcohols?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: NaBH₄ selectively reduces carbonyls to alcohols under mild conditions; LiAlH₄ is stronger.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which bond formation is characteristic of amines?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Amines contain nitrogen bonded to carbon and/or hydrogen (basic nitrogen center).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is TRUE about amines?
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Amines are basic due to lone pair on nitrogen and can accept a proton
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Amines act as Brønsted–Lowry bases by accepting protons on nitrogen lone pair.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent would convert a primary amine to a diazonium salt (Ar–N₂⁺Cl⁻) under cold acidic conditions?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: NaNO₂ + HCl (nitrous acid generated in situ)
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Aromatic primary amines (ArNH₂) react with NaNO₂/HCl at 0–5 °C to form diazonium salts.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reaction is used to prepare alcohols from alkyl halides via nucleophilic substitution?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: RX + OH⁻ → ROH + X⁻ (SN2 or SN1 depending on substrate)
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Nucleophilic substitution of alkyl halide by hydroxide yields alcohols; mechanism depends on substrate structure.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which type of isomerism is shown by cis-2-butene and trans-2-butene?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Restricted rotation about C=C gives stereoisomers (cis/trans) with different physical properties.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following statements about optical isomerism is correct?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: Occurs in molecules having a plane of symmetry
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Occurs when a molecule has an asymmetric carbon (chiral centre) with four different substituents
Carbon and its Compounds.d: Does not affect rotation of plane-polarized light
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Chiral carbon (asymmetric centre) leads to enantiomers that rotate plane-polarized light in opposite directions.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent oxidizes alkenes to diols via anti addition (using epoxidation followed by hydrolysis)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Peracid (m-CPBA) forms epoxide which upon hydrolysis gives vicinal diol with anti stereochemistry.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is commonly used as a solvent and reagent in organic chemistry and is miscible with water and many organics (simple alcohol)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Ethanol is a polar protic solvent, miscible with water and many organics; commonly used in reactions and as solvent.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which compound is commonly used as a catalyst for dehydration of alcohols to alkenes?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Concentrated sulfuric acid (acidic conditions) promotes dehydration (E1/E2) to form alkenes.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following organic reactions increases molecular weight by joining monomers with elimination of small molecules (e.g., water)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Condensation polymerization involves step-growth linking with elimination of small molecules (H₂O, HCl).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which is the IUPAC name of CH₃–CH₂–OH?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Two-carbon alcohol is ethanol (C₂H₅OH).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following types of organic compounds contain carbonyl group (C=O) directly bonded to at least one hydrogen atom?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Aldehydes have form R–CHO where carbonyl carbon is bonded to hydrogen; ketones have R–CO–R'.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent is used for dehydrohalogenation (elimination) to form alkenes from alkyl halides?
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Strong base like KOH (alc) or t-BuOK
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Strong bases abstract β-hydrogen leading to E2 elimination and alkene formation.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following compounds is aromatic and obeys Hückel’s rule?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Benzene with 6 (4n+2, n=1) π electrons is aromatic; cyclobutadiene is antiaromatic; cyclooctatetraene is nonplanar and not aromatic.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which class of compounds are produced when carboxylic acids react with alcohols in presence of acid catalyst?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Esterification (Fischer) produces esters (R–COOR') and water.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is used as a nucleophile in nucleophilic substitution to form amines (Gabriel synthesis alternative)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Ammonia acts as nucleophile attacking alkyl halides to form primary amines (with potential overalkylation).

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which compound gives positive Biuret test (indicates peptide bonds)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Biuret reagent detects peptide bonds (proteins/peptides) not typical in simple carbon compounds chapter but included as functional group test.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is TRUE about saturated fats vs unsaturated fats chemistry-wise?
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Unsaturated fats contain one or more C=C bonds and can be hydrogenated to saturated fats
Carbon and its Compounds.c: Unsaturated fats have higher melting points than saturated fats always
Carbon and its Compounds.d: Saturated fats are liquid at room temperature
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Unsaturated fats have double bonds (cis usually) lowering melting point; hydrogenation adds H across C=C to saturate.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which method is commonly used industrially to convert ethene to ethanol (hydration)?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: Acid-catalyzed hydration (high pressure) or catalytic hydration (phosphoric acid on silica)
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Ethene hydration (industrial) uses catalysts (acid-catalyzed) under controlled conditions to yield ethanol.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following statements about soap molecules is correct?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: Soaps are salts of long-chain fatty acids with a polar head (carboxylate) and nonpolar tail
Carbon and its Compounds.d: Soaps dissolve lipids by covalent bonding
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Soap molecules (R–COO⁻ Na⁺) form micelles solubilizing nonpolar oils in water due to amphiphilic structure.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reaction is characteristic of aldehydes but not of most ketones?
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Oxidation to carboxylic acids (e.g., Tollens' or Fehling's positive)
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Aldehydes are readily oxidized to carboxylic acids; most ketones resist oxidation under mild conditions.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent is typically used to test for phenol (produces violet color with FeCl₃)?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Phenols form colored complexes (e.g., violet) with FeCl₃; useful qualitative test.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following properties is TRUE for benzene compared to cyclohexatriene hypothetical Kekulé structure?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: Benzene has alternating single and double bonds without delocalization
Carbon and its Compounds.b: Benzene is stabilized by resonance (delocalization) leading to equal bond lengths and lower reactivity toward addition
Carbon and its Compounds.c: Benzene readily undergoes addition like alkenes
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Aromatic stabilization (resonance) gives benzene unique stability and equalized C–C bond lengths.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following is NOT a method to prepare carboxylic acids?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Hydrogenation of alkenes gives alkanes, not carboxylic acids; other methods produce acids.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which of the following statements about organic nomenclature is TRUE?
Carbon and its Compounds.a: Longest carbon chain chosen as parent; functional groups get priority as suffixes
Carbon and its Compounds.c: Functional groups are ignored for naming
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: IUPAC rules: choose longest chain including principal functional group; number to give lowest locants and functional group priority.

Carbon and its Compounds.question: Which reagent is commonly used to oxidize alcohols and convert secondary alcohols to ketones?
Carbon and its Compounds.comment: Chromium(VI) reagents (K₂Cr₂O₇/H₂SO₄) oxidize secondary alcohols to ketones; PCC can stop at aldehyde for primaries.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is a primary criterion for classification of fuels?
Fuels.comment: Fuels are commonly classified as solid, liquid or gaseous fuels based on physical state.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is a gaseous fuel?
Fuels.comment: Natural gas is primarily methane (CH₄) and is a major gaseous fuel.

Fuels.question: Which term describes the heat released on complete combustion when water formed is condensed to liquid?
Fuels.b: Gross calorific value (GCV) or Higher heating value (HHV)
Fuels.comment: GCV (HHV) includes latent heat of condensation of water; LCV (net) excludes it.

Fuels.question: Bomb calorimeter is used to measure:
Fuels.b: Calorific value (higher heating value) of a fuel at constant volume
Fuels.comment: Bomb calorimeter measures heat released by complete combustion at constant volume to obtain HHV.

Fuels.question: Which of the following units commonly expresses calorific value of solid fuels?
Fuels.comment: Calorific values for fuels are expressed in energy per mass (kJ·kg⁻¹ or kcal·kg⁻¹).

Fuels.question: Which solid fuel is obtained by destructive distillation of coal and used as fuel and reducing agent?
Fuels.comment: Coke produced from coal by destructive distillation is porous and high-carbon used in metallurgy and as fuel.

Fuels.question: Which analysis determines moisture, volatile matter, fixed carbon and ash content of coal?
Fuels.comment: Proximate analysis gives moisture, volatile matter, fixed carbon and ash — key for fuel evaluation.

Fuels.question: Ultimate analysis of coal provides percentage of:
Fuels.a: C, H, N, S, O and ash on mass basis
Fuels.comment: Ultimate analysis reports elemental composition (carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, sulfur, oxygen) useful for stoichiometry and emissions.

Fuels.question: Which fuel has the highest gravimetric calorific value per kg among common fuels?
Fuels.comment: Hydrogen has very high specific energy per kg (~120–142 MJ·kg⁻¹ LHV/HHV depending on definition).

Fuels.question: Which of the following is an advantage of gaseous fuels like natural gas over coal?
Fuels.b: Cleaner combustion with lower particulate emissions
Fuels.comment: Gaseous fuels typically burn cleaner with lower particulates and SOx compared to many coals.

Fuels.question: The stoichiometric (theoretical) air required for complete combustion depends mainly on:
Fuels.b: Elemental composition (C, H, S) of the fuel
Fuels.comment: Stoichiometric air is calculated from fuel's carbon, hydrogen and sulfur content because O₂ is consumed to form CO₂, H₂O, SO₂.

Fuels.question: Excess air in combustion is used to:
Fuels.b: Ensure complete combustion and reduce CO formation
Fuels.comment: Slight excess air helps avoid incomplete combustion (CO, unburnt hydrocarbons) but too much reduces efficiency.

Fuels.question: Which gaseous fuel is commonly used in domestic cooking and is a mixture of propane and butane?
Fuels.comment: LPG is primarily propane (C₃H₈) and butane (C₄H₁₀) — stored under pressure as liquid for domestic use.

Fuels.question: Which fuel parameter indicates tendency of petrol (gasoline) to resist knocking in spark-ignition engines?
Fuels.comment: Octane number measures anti-knock property — higher octane means greater knock resistance in spark-ignition engines.

Fuels.question: Cetane number is a measure of:
Fuels.a: Ignition quality (ignition delay) of diesel in compression-ignition engines
Fuels.b: Resistance to knocking in petrol engines
Fuels.comment: Higher cetane number means shorter ignition delay and better ignition quality in diesel engines.

Fuels.question: Which fuel property is defined by the lowest temperature at which vapour of a liquid ignites momentarily when exposed to a flame (not sustained)?
Fuels.comment: Flash point is the lowest temperature at which vapour momentarily ignites; fire point is slightly higher where burning is sustained.

Fuels.question: Autoignition temperature of a fuel is:
Fuels.a: Temperature at which fuel spontaneously ignites without an external flame
Fuels.comment: Autoignition or ignition temperature is the temperature at which fuel-air mixture ignites spontaneously.

Fuels.question: Which fuel is commonly used as aviation turbine fuel (Jet-A/Jet A-1) and is essentially a kerosene fraction?
Fuels.comment: Aviation turbine fuels (Jet A, Jet A-1) are kerosene-type fractions with tight specifications for volatility, freezing point and flash point.

Fuels.question: Which process increases the octane rating of petrol by rearranging straight-chain paraffins into branched isomers?
Fuels.comment: Isomerization converts straight-chain paraffins into branched isomers which generally have higher octane numbers.

Fuels.question: Cracking in petroleum refining refers to:
Fuels.a: Splitting heavy hydrocarbon molecules into lighter fractions (e.g., gasoline)
Fuels.b: Combining small hydrocarbons into larger ones
Fuels.comment: Thermal or catalytic cracking breaks large molecules into smaller, more valuable fractions like gasoline and diesel.

Fuels.question: Which additive was historically used to increase octane rating of petrol but is now largely phased out due to toxicity?
Fuels.comment: Tetraethyllead was an effective anti-knock additive but was phased out because of lead toxicity and environmental harm.

Fuels.question: MTBE (methyl tert-butyl ether) and ethanol are examples of:
Fuels.b: Oxygenates used as octane enhancers in gasoline
Fuels.comment: Oxygenates like MTBE or ethanol increase octane rating and help cleaner combustion by providing oxygen in the fuel.

Fuels.question: Which term describes the product gas obtained by passing air over hot coal (partial combustion) and consists mainly of CO and N₂?
Fuels.comment: Producer gas is obtained by air gasification and contains CO, H₂ (small), CO₂ and N₂; composition depends on process.

Fuels.question: Water gas is produced by passing steam over red-hot carbon (C + H₂O → CO + H₂). It is typically rich in:
Fuels.comment: Water gas (synthesis gas) contains H₂ and CO and can be shifted or processed for synthesis of fuels and chemicals.

Fuels.question: Which fuel property describes the maximum size/height of luminous flame that indicates smokiness and tendency to produce soot when burned?
Fuels.comment: Smoke point is used particularly for aviation fuels and kerosene to indicate tendency to produce smoke (soot).

Fuels.question: Which type of coal has the highest carbon content and highest calorific value?
Fuels.comment: Anthracite is the highest-rank coal with high fixed carbon, low volatiles and high calorific value.

Fuels.question: Which process converts heavy residues to lighter fuels using hydrogen gas and catalyst under high pressure and temperature?
Fuels.comment: Hydrocracking uses hydrogen and catalysts to crack heavy fractions to high-quality lighter fuels with low sulfur.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is the main pollutant from combustion of sulfur-containing fuels?
Fuels.comment: Sulfur in fuels oxidizes to SO₂ (and further to SO₃) contributing to acid rain and particulate sulfate formation.

Fuels.question: Which refinery process removes sulfur compounds from petroleum fractions (improves fuel quality and reduces emissions)?
Fuels.comment: Hydrodesulfurization converts organosulfur compounds to H₂S which is then removed to produce low-sulfur fuels.

Fuels.question: Which of the following fuels typically has the lowest emissions of particulate matter and SOx when burned under optimal conditions?
Fuels.comment: Natural gas combustion emits lower particulates and much lower SOx compared to coal or heavy oils.

Fuels.question: Which test measures the ignition quality of diesel fuel using a reference mixture of cetane and heptamethylnonane?
Fuels.comment: Cetane number is determined against reference fuels; higher cetane shortens ignition delay in diesel engines.

Fuels.question: Which statement about flash point and fire point of liquid fuels is correct?
Fuels.b: Fire point is slightly higher than flash point (temperature at which vapour sustains combustion)
Fuels.d: Fire point is irrelevant for safety
Fuels.comment: Flash point is lowest T for momentary ignition; fire point slightly higher where sustained burning occurs.

Fuels.question: Which property is important for diesel fuel in cold climates to avoid waxing and poor flow?
Fuels.comment: Cloud point and pour point indicate temperatures at which wax crystals form and fuel becomes less fluid.

Fuels.question: Which fuel is produced by anaerobic decomposition of organic matter and typically contains CH₄ and CO₂?
Fuels.comment: Biogas results from anaerobic digestion and generally contains 50–70% CH₄ and remainder CO₂ with traces of H₂S.

Fuels.question: Which of the following processes is used to liquefy natural gas for transport and storage at low temperatures?
Fuels.b: Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) production (cooling to cryogenic temperatures)
Fuels.comment: LNG is natural gas cooled to cryogenic temperatures to become a liquid for efficient shipping and storage.

Fuels.question: Which parameter of fuels indicates how easily the fuel vapour mixes and ignites at the engine inlet in SI engines?
Fuels.comment: Volatility affects vaporization, cold-start performance and tendency for vapor lock; measured by RVP and distillation curve.

Fuels.question: Which of following best describes Reid Vapor Pressure (RVP) of gasoline?
Fuels.b: Measure of vapour pressure at 37.8 °C (100 °F) indicating volatility
Fuels.comment: RVP quantifies gasoline volatility for evaporation and cold-start performance, regulated seasonally in many regions.

Fuels.question: Which refinery process combines light olefinic gases (e.g., isobutene) with isobutane to produce high-octane gasoline blending components?
Fuels.comment: Alkylation produces high-octane branched hydrocarbons used in gasoline blending.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is a heavy residual fuel commonly used in ships (bunker fuel) and industry burners?
Fuels.b: Residual fuel oil (RFO) or heavy fuel oil (HFO)
Fuels.comment: Heavy residual oils are viscous, high-sulfur fuels used in marine and industrial applications; require heating for handling.

Fuels.question: Which phenomenon causes knocking in spark-ignition (SI) engines?
Fuels.b: Autoignition of end-gas ahead of flame front causing pressure oscillations
Fuels.comment: Knock is caused by spontaneous detonation of the unburnt fuel-air mixture (end-gas) leading to damaging pressure spikes.

Fuels.question: Which fuel additive class is used to reduce deposit formation in intake valves and fuel injectors?
Fuels.comment: Detergent additives help keep engine components clean and maintain performance and emissions.

Fuels.question: Which parameter indicates the ignition temperature for diesel engines (compression ignition)?
Fuels.b: Cetane number (higher cetane means easier ignition)
Fuels.comment: Higher cetane number indicates shorter ignition delay and better cold-start and smooth ignition in diesel engines.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is TRUE about LPG storage and transport?
Fuels.a: LPG is stored and transported as a high-pressure liquid in cylinders/tanks
Fuels.b: LPG must be cryogenically cooled to remain liquid
Fuels.c: LPG is always gaseous under ambient conditions and cannot be liquefied
Fuels.comment: LPG is liquefied under moderate pressure at ambient temperatures and stored in pressurized cylinders/tanks.

Fuels.question: Which fuel has the highest volumetric energy density under normal storage conditions (liquid fuels vs gases stored as gas)?
Fuels.a: Compressed natural gas (CNG) at ambient temperature
Fuels.comment: Liquid fuels (LPG, petrol, diesel) have much higher volumetric energy densities than compressed gases at moderate pressures.

Fuels.question: Which combustion product is the main greenhouse gas produced by hydrocarbon fuel combustion?
Fuels.comment: CO₂ is produced from carbon oxidation and is a major contributor to greenhouse effect from fossil fuel combustion.

Fuels.question: Which fuel upgrading technology reduces aromatic content and increases hydrogen content for cleaner-burning fuels?
Fuels.comment: Hydrotreating removes heteroatoms and saturates aromatics using hydrogen and catalysts producing cleaner fuels.

Fuels.question: Which refinery fraction is commonly used as kerosene (paraffin) for heating and aviation turbine fuel feedstock?
Fuels.comment: Kerosene or middle distillate fraction (C₁₂–C₁₆ approx) is feed for jet fuels and heating oil after processing.

Fuels.question: Which fuel property influences flame temperature and heat transfer in boilers and furnaces?
Fuels.comment: Calorific value and completeness of combustion (air-fuel ratio) determine flame temperature and heat release.

Fuels.question: Which gaseous fuel requires catalytic or thermal reforming to produce hydrogen-rich syngas for industrial uses?
Fuels.d: All of the above (depending on application)
Fuels.comment: Natural gas, LPG, biogas can be reformed thermally or catalytically to produce H₂/CO synthesis gas for industry.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is likely to increase thermal NOx formation during combustion?
Fuels.b: Higher combustion temperature and excess air
Fuels.comment: Thermal NOx forms at high flame temperatures from N₂–O interactions; reducing peak temperatures reduces NOx.

Fuels.question: Which fuel monitoring test assesses volatility distribution of gasoline by measuring temperatures at which certain percentages distill (e.g., T10, T50, T90)?
Fuels.comment: Distillation curve T10, T50, T90 characterize gasoline volatility and behaviour during engine operation.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is the main constituent of CNG (compressed natural gas)?
Fuels.comment: CNG is primarily methane stored at high pressures for vehicular fuel applications.

Fuels.question: Which fuel additive helps prevent engine knocking in petrol engines by increasing octane rating and also acts as an oxygenate?
Fuels.comment: Ethanol raises octane and provides oxygen in gasoline blends; used as biofuel additive (E10, E85 etc.).

Fuels.question: Which of the following describes the term 'synthesis gas' or syngas?
Fuels.b: Mixture mainly of CO and H₂ used as chemical feedstock
Fuels.comment: Syngas (CO + H₂) is produced by gasification or reforming and used to synthesize fuels and chemicals (e.g., methanol, Fischer–Tropsch).

Fuels.question: Which process for cleaner fuel production substitutes aromatic hydrocarbons with branched paraffins of higher octane by catalytic action?
Fuels.d: Isomerization and alkylation (both used to upgrade gasoline components)
Fuels.comment: Isomerization and alkylation are used to produce high-octane branched hydrocarbons; catalytic reforming increases aromatics and octane in naphtha.

Fuels.question: Which of the following statements about LPG as automotive fuel (autogas) is TRUE?
Fuels.a: LPG has lower octane number than petrol always
Fuels.b: LPG tends to burn cleaner than petrol producing lower particulates and SOx
Fuels.c: LPG cannot be used in spark-ignition engines
Fuels.d: LPG is highly corrosive to all metals
Fuels.comment: LPG burns relatively cleanly; it is used as autogas with appropriate engine modification and fueling systems.

Fuels.question: Which of the following best describes thermal efficiency of an engine or combustion system?
Fuels.a: Ratio of useful energy output to energy input from fuel
Fuels.d: Mass flow rate of fuel only
Fuels.comment: Thermal efficiency indicates how effectively chemical energy of fuel is converted to useful work or heat.

Fuels.question: Which reagent or test is commonly used to detect sulfur or its compounds in petroleum products historically?
Fuels.a: Lead acetate paper for H₂S detection (darkens on H₂S)
Fuels.comment: Lead acetate paper is used to detect hydrogen sulfide from sulfur compounds; desulfurization processes are used to remove sulfur.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is a renewable fuel produced by fermentation of sugars and used as gasoline blending agent and oxygenate?
Fuels.comment: Bioethanol produced from biomass fermentation is used as a renewable oxygenate and octane enhancer in gasoline blends.

Fuels.question: Which fuel property is critical for safety handling and is the temperature above which liquid fuel releases enough vapor to form ignitable mixture near surface (used for storage classification)?
Fuels.comment: Flash point determines flammability hazard classification and safe storage/transport of liquids.

Fuels.question: Which of the following processes is used to convert vegetable oils into fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) used as biodiesel?
Fuels.a: Transesterification with methanol and base catalyst (e.g., NaOH)
Fuels.comment: Transesterification converts triglycerides into methyl esters (biodiesel) and glycerol byproduct.

Fuels.question: Which term describes the tendency of a fuel to form deposits and coke within engines and burners when burned?
Fuels.comment: High aromatic or heavy fractions increase coking and deposit formation; fuel formulation and additives mitigate this.

Fuels.question: Which measurement is primarily used to assess volatility of diesel and jet fuels for cold-weather operability?
Fuels.b: Distillation curve and freeze point (for jet fuel)
Fuels.comment: Distillation characteristics and freezing point (Jet A-1 spec) ensure operability across temperature conditions.

Fuels.question: Which of the following fuels is produced by the Fischer–Tropsch process from syngas?
Fuels.comment: Fischer–Tropsch converts CO + H₂ to liquid hydrocarbons used as synthetic diesel or kerosene.

Fuels.question: Which of the following best explains why branched hydrocarbons generally have higher octane numbers than straight-chain isomers?
Fuels.b: Branched hydrocarbons resist autoignition and reduce tendency to knock
Fuels.c: Straight chains always have higher boiling points
Fuels.comment: Branching stabilizes molecules against premature autoignition, improving knock resistance (higher octane).

Fuels.question: Which environmental regulation trend has strongly influenced modern fuel specifications?
Fuels.b: Lowering sulfur content and phasing out lead; tighter limits on aromatics and volatile organic compounds
Fuels.comment: Regulations aim to reduce harmful emissions (SOx, NOx, particulates, lead) driving cleaner fuel technologies.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is an important reason to remove sulfur from transportation fuels?
Fuels.b: Sulfur poisons catalytic converters and causes SOx emissions which form acid rain
Fuels.comment: Sulfur compounds poison emission control catalysts and lead to SO₂ emissions; desulfurization is therefore essential.

Fuels.question: Which fuel property is most directly related to how fast flame front propagates in a spark-ignition engine?
Fuels.b: Laminar flame speed and fuel-air mixture properties
Fuels.comment: Laminar flame speed and mixture reactivity influence flame propagation and engine performance.

Fuels.question: Which of the following processes produces hydrogen-rich fuel by reacting hydrocarbons with steam at high temperature over catalyst (CH₄ + H₂O → CO + 3H₂)?
Fuels.comment: Steam reforming of methane and other hydrocarbons is a major industrial route to H₂.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is a likely advantage of biodiesel compared to conventional diesel?
Fuels.b: Lower sulfur and often lower net CO₂ lifecycle emissions if sustainably produced
Fuels.comment: Biodiesel is typically low in sulfur and renewable feedstocks can reduce lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions.

Fuels.question: Which of the following terms refers to fuel oil used in domestic kerosene stoves?
Fuels.comment: Kerosene (paraffin) is used in stoves and lamps and is a middle distillate distinct from diesel/gasoline.

Fuels.question: Which property is important for marine bunker fuels to evaluate risk of sludge formation and storage handling?
Fuels.comment: Viscosity and pour point affect pumping and handling; sludge and sediment formation are concerns for heavy residual fuels.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is true about partial oxidation (POX) for syngas production?
Fuels.a: POX uses oxygen to partially combust fuel producing CO and H₂ quickly and exothermically
Fuels.c: POX is same as complete combustion
Fuels.comment: Partial oxidation with limited oxygen yields syngas (CO + H₂) and is exothermic compared to steam reforming.

Fuels.question: Which of the following fuel characteristics is directly reduced by catalytic converters in automobiles?
Fuels.b: Tailpipe emissions of CO, unburnt hydrocarbons and NOx when fuels and engine are controlled
Fuels.comment: Catalytic converters reduce harmful exhaust pollutants; low-sulfur fuels are required for catalyst durability.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is used to improve cold-flow properties of diesel and biodiesel fuels (prevent waxing/clouding)?
Fuels.a: Pour point depressants and cold-flow additives
Fuels.comment: Cold-flow additives modify wax crystallization to improve pumpability and filterability at low temperatures.

Fuels.question: Which of the following best describes 'gasoline blending'?
Fuels.a: Mixing various refinery streams and additives to meet octane, volatility and emissions specifications
Fuels.b: Boiling gasoline to remove impurities only
Fuels.comment: Blending combines fractions and additives to optimize performance, safety and emissions per regional specs.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical constituent of biogas?
Fuels.comment: Biogas is produced anaerobically and contains methane and CO₂ with trace H₂S; oxygen is undesirable and low.

Fuels.question: Which of the following statements about coal gasification is correct?
Fuels.a: It converts coal into liquid gasoline directly without intermediate steps
Fuels.b: It produces syngas (CO + H₂) for power generation or chemical synthesis
Fuels.c: It is the same as coal combustion
Fuels.comment: Gasification transforms coal into syngas under controlled oxygen/steam conditions for downstream uses.

Fuels.question: Which of the following describes the main risk with storage of fuels containing volatile hydrocarbons?
Fuels.b: Evaporation losses, vapor buildup and flammability (necessitating vapor recovery and ventilation)
Fuels.comment: Volatile fuels pose vapor emission and flammability risks; storage systems incorporate controls to prevent release and ignition.

Fuels.question: Which of the following describes an advantage of using CNG as vehicle fuel versus petrol in terms of emissions?
Fuels.a: CNG generally produces lower particulate matter and lower CO emissions
Fuels.c: CNG cannot be used in spark ignition engines
Fuels.comment: CNG combustion emits lower particulates and often lower CO and HC; methane slip and NOx depend on engine calibration.

Fuels.question: Which of the following is a common method for controlling particulate emissions from burning heavy fuel oils and coal?
Fuels.comment: Electrostatic precipitators and baghouses remove fly ash and particulates from flue gases in industrial systems.

Metallurgy.question: Metallurgy is the science and technology of:
Metallurgy.b: Extraction of metals from ores and their processing
Metallurgy.comment: Metallurgy covers extraction, refining, alloying and processing of metals.

Metallurgy.question: An ore is defined as a naturally occurring material from which a metal can be economically extracted. Which of the following is an ore of iron?
Metallurgy.comment: Haematite (Fe₂O₃) and magnetite (Fe₃O₄) are important iron ores.

Metallurgy.question: Calcination is the process of:
Metallurgy.a: Removal of moisture and volatile impurities by heating in absence of air
Metallurgy.comment: Calcination decomposes carbonates and drives off volatile impurities, usually below melting point and with limited air.

Metallurgy.question: Roasting of a sulphide ore typically results in:
Metallurgy.a: Conversion of sulphide to oxide with evolution of SO₂
Metallurgy.comment: Roasting (heating in excess air) oxidizes sulphides (e.g., 2ZnS + 3O₂ → 2ZnO + 2SO₂).

Metallurgy.question: Froth flotation is mainly used to concentrate which type of ores?
Metallurgy.comment: Froth flotation separates hydrophobic sulphide minerals (e.g., CuFeS₂, ZnS) from gangue.

Metallurgy.question: In froth flotation the role of collectors (e.g., xanthates) is to:
Metallurgy.b: Make ore particles hydrophobic so they attach to bubbles
Metallurgy.comment: Collectors adsorb on mineral surfaces rendering them hydrophobic for bubble attachment.

Metallurgy.question: Leaching (hydrometallurgy) involves:
Metallurgy.a: Dissolving metal from ore into solution using suitable solvent/reagent
Metallurgy.comment: Leaching dissolves valuable metal into solution for subsequent recovery (e.g., cyanidation of Au, Ag).

Metallurgy.question: Which reagent is commonly used for extraction of gold from low-grade ores (cyanidation)?
Metallurgy.b: NaCN or KCN in presence of O₂ (cyanide leaching)
Metallurgy.comment: Cyanidation (Au + CN⁻ + O₂ → Au(CN)₂⁻) dissolves gold; requires careful environmental controls.

Metallurgy.question: In the extraction of aluminium by Hall–Héroult process, the electrolyte is mainly:
Metallurgy.comment: Cryolite (Na₃AlF₆) lowers melting point and increases conductivity; Al₂O₃ is dissolved and electrolyzed.

Metallurgy.question: The main reducing agent in a blast furnace for iron-making is:
Metallurgy.comment: Coke reacts to form CO which reduces Fe₂O₃ to Fe; also direct reduction by carbon can occur.

Metallurgy.question: Which flux is commonly used in the blast furnace to remove silica (SiO₂) as slag?
Metallurgy.comment: Calcium oxide reacts with acidic SiO₂ to form calcium silicate (CaSiO₃) slag which is removed.

Metallurgy.question: Pig iron obtained from blast furnace typically contains high carbon (~4%) and impurities. The process to convert pig iron to steel by removing carbon is:
Metallurgy.comment: Bessemer (historic) and modern basic oxygen furnaces remove C and impurities to produce steel.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of basic oxygen process (BOF) over Bessemer converter?
Metallurgy.comment: BOF improves control and quality; NaCN is unrelated.

Metallurgy.question: Electrolytic refining of copper produces pure copper at the cathode. What serves as the anode in this process?
Metallurgy.b: Impure copper (anode) which dissolves into solution
Metallurgy.comment: Impure copper anode dissolves, and pure copper plates at the cathode; impurities collect as anode sludge.

Metallurgy.question: The impurity that forms anode sludge during electrolytic refining of copper and is economically recoverable is:
Metallurgy.comment: Noble metals like Ag and Au do not dissolve and accumulate in anode slime for recovery.

Metallurgy.question: Which method is used to extract aluminium from bauxite in industry?
Metallurgy.a: Hall–Héroult electrolysis after Bayer process to produce pure Al₂O₃
Metallurgy.comment: Bayer process purifies bauxite to alumina (Al₂O₃); Hall–Héroult electrolytically reduces alumina to Al.

Metallurgy.question: Bayer process involves digesting bauxite with concentrated NaOH to form which soluble complex?
Metallurgy.comment: Alumina dissolves in NaOH as sodium aluminate; impurities (red mud) are removed and Al₂O₃ is precipitated later.

Metallurgy.question: Which is the chief constituent of 'red mud' formed during the Bayer process?
Metallurgy.b: Impurities like Fe₂O₃, TiO₂ and undissolved silica
Metallurgy.comment: Red mud contains iron oxides, titanium oxides and other insoluble gangue; disposal is an environmental concern.

Metallurgy.question: In the Hall–Héroult cell, aluminium is deposited at which electrode?
Metallurgy.comment: Al³⁺ ions are reduced at the cathode to deposit aluminium metal.

Metallurgy.question: Which gas is typically evolved at the anode during the electrolysis of alumina with carbon anodes in Hall–Héroult process?
Metallurgy.b: O₂ which reacts with carbon anode producing CO/CO₂
Metallurgy.comment: Oxygen formed reacts with carbon anode, consuming the anode and producing CO/CO₂.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is an example of hydrometallurgical technique for copper recovery?
Metallurgy.b: Leaching of oxide ores with acid followed by solvent extraction and electrowinning (SX–EW)
Metallurgy.comment: SX–EW is widely used to recover copper from oxide ores and low-grade materials.

Metallurgy.question: Which reducing agent is commonly used in the metallurgical extraction of metals from their oxides via hydrogen reduction?
Metallurgy.comment: Hydrogen reduces metal oxides (e.g., CuO + H₂ → Cu + H₂O) at suitable temperatures.

Metallurgy.question: Which metallurgical term describes the temperature at which a metal changes from solid to liquid?
Metallurgy.comment: Melting (fusion) point is the temperature where solid and liquid phases are in equilibrium.

Metallurgy.question: Ellingham diagrams are useful in metallurgy because they:
Metallurgy.a: Show variation of Gibbs free energy (ΔG°) for formation of oxides vs temperature to predict reducibility
Metallurgy.comment: Ellingham diagrams help determine which reducing agent (C, CO, H₂) can reduce a metal oxide at a given temperature.

Metallurgy.question: According to Ellingham diagram, carbon can reduce a metal oxide if the ΔG° for formation of CO or CO₂ is:
Metallurgy.a: More positive than that of metal oxide formation at that temperature
Metallurgy.b: More negative (lower) than that for metal oxide formation at that temperature
Metallurgy.comment: Reduction is spontaneous when ΔG° for C→CO/CO₂ is lower (more negative) than for metal oxidation; then C removes oxygen.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is the major reason iron is normally extracted in a blast furnace rather than by electrolysis?
Metallurgy.b: High cost of electricity makes electrolysis uneconomical for bulk Fe production; blast furnace is cheaper
Metallurgy.d: Iron is too reactive to reduce
Metallurgy.comment: Large-scale iron production uses carbon-based reduction in blast furnaces due to economics.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following describes the role of coke in a blast furnace?
Metallurgy.a: Fuel, source of CO for reduction, and provides heat and structural support
Metallurgy.comment: Coke combusts to give CO₂ and CO which reduces iron oxides; it also provides heat and porosity.

Metallurgy.question: Which iron product is produced in the blast furnace that contains ~3–4% carbon and several impurities and is used as feedstock for steelmaking?
Metallurgy.comment: Pig iron (liquid iron from blast furnace) has high C and impurities; it's converted to steel in converters.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following processes is used to remove sulfur from molten iron/steel?
Metallurgy.b: Lime treatment (CaO) and oxygen blown processes to form CaS and slag removal
Metallurgy.comment: Fluxing with lime and desulfurizing agents helps remove S as CaS in slag during steelmaking.

Metallurgy.question: Which are the principal metallurgical operations in sequence for sulphide ores typically? (simplified)
Metallurgy.comment: Sulphide ores often require roasting (partial oxidation), smelting to metal sulfide/metal, and refining.

Metallurgy.question: Matte in sulphide metallurgy refers to:
Metallurgy.a: A molten sulfide phase rich in metal sulfides (e.g., Cu₂S, FeS) formed during smelting
Metallurgy.comment: Matte separates from slag and is further converted to metal in converters or by other refining steps.

Metallurgy.question: The Parkes process is used to separate which metal from lead bullion?
Metallurgy.b: Silver (and sometimes gold) by using zinc to form alloys which are removed
Metallurgy.comment: Zinc is added to molten lead to which Ag and Au preferentially transfer; the Zn–Ag alloy is removed and processed.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is the main principle behind solvent extraction (SX) in hydrometallurgy?
Metallurgy.a: Selective transfer of metal ions from aqueous phase to organic extractant phase based on complexation/solubility
Metallurgy.comment: SX selectively transfers metal complexes into organic phase; metals are then stripped and recovered (e.g., Cu SX–EW).

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following metals is commonly obtained by electrolytic refining (electrowinning) from solution in industry?
Metallurgy.c: Iron from Fe³⁺ aqueous solution at low cost
Metallurgy.d: Titanium from TiO₂ electrolysis in water
Metallurgy.comment: Electrowinning is used for copper and other metals; aluminium requires molten salt electrolysis (Hall–Héroult).

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following statements about gold metallurgy (cyanidation) is correct?
Metallurgy.a: Gold reacts with cyanide in presence of oxygen to form soluble aurocyanide complex Au(CN)₂⁻
Metallurgy.b: Gold is readily soluble in water alone
Metallurgy.c: Gold is reduced by cyanide to metal
Metallurgy.d: Gold forms insoluble cyanide compounds only
Metallurgy.comment: Cyanidation: 4Au + 8CN⁻ + O₂ + 2H₂O → 4Au(CN)₂⁻ + 4OH⁻; requires oxygen and cyanide.

Metallurgy.question: Which metal is commonly produced by the electrolytic reduction of molten chloride salts in the Downs cell?
Metallurgy.comment: The Downs process electrolyzes molten NaCl to produce sodium metal and chlorine gas.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following metallurgical terms refers to the intentional addition of elements to a metal to improve properties?
Metallurgy.comment: Alloying (e.g., adding Cr, Ni to Fe) tailors mechanical, corrosion and thermal properties.

Metallurgy.question: Stainless steel owes its corrosion resistance primarily to which alloying element?
Metallurgy.b: Chromium (Cr) forming a passive Cr₂O₃ layer
Metallurgy.comment: Chromium (≥~11–12%) forms a protective, adherent chromium oxide passive film reducing corrosion.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is a ferrous alloy with high carbon (2–4%) used for castings and has good fluidity in molten state?
Metallurgy.b: Cast iron (various types including grey, white, malleable)
Metallurgy.comment: Cast irons contain higher carbon and silicon and are cast into shapes; properties depend on microstructure.

Metallurgy.question: Which micro constituent in steel is iron carbide (Fe₃C) known as?
Metallurgy.comment: Cementite (Fe₃C) is a hard, brittle intermetallic compound present in pearlite and other microstructures.

Metallurgy.question: What is tempering of steel?
Metallurgy.b: Reheating quenched martensitic steel to a lower temperature to reduce brittleness and achieve desired toughness
Metallurgy.comment: Tempering reduces internal stresses and brittleness of martensite by controlled reheating.

Metallurgy.question: Which phase is face-centered cubic (FCC) iron that is stable at high temperatures and can dissolve more carbon than ferrite?
Metallurgy.comment: Austenite (γ) is FCC and exists above ~723 °C in plain carbon steels; it can dissolve significant carbon.

Metallurgy.question: Which heat treatment is used to refine grain structure, relieve internal stresses and improve ductility by heating to a temperature below transformation and slow cooling?
Metallurgy.a: Annealing (full anneal / stress relief / spheroidizing depending on temp/time)
Metallurgy.comment: Annealing allows recrystallization and stress relief; specific types depend on objectives and temperatures.

Metallurgy.question: Hardening of steel by quenching produces which microstructure (in carbon steels) when cooled rapidly?
Metallurgy.comment: Rapid cooling traps carbon in distorted lattice forming martensite which is extremely hard and brittle.

Metallurgy.question: Case hardening (carburizing) is used to produce a hard surface layer while maintaining a ductile core. It involves:
Metallurgy.a: Diffusing carbon into the surface of low-carbon steel at high temperatures followed by quenching
Metallurgy.comment: Carburizing increases surface carbon to form hard martensitic case after quench while core remains tough.

Metallurgy.question: Which casting defect is caused by entrapment of air or gas leading to cavities in the casting?
Metallurgy.comment: Gas porosity results from dissolved gases evolving from molten metal during solidification.

Metallurgy.question: Which process uses high electrical energy to produce metals (e.g., titanium, magnesium) by electrolysis in molten salts at industrial scale?
Metallurgy.b: Electrolytic reduction in molten salts (various designs for reactive metals)
Metallurgy.comment: Molten salt electrolysis is used for several reactive metals despite energy intensity (e.g., Mg from MgCl₂).

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is an advantage of powder metallurgy?
Metallurgy.b: Ability to produce near-net-shape components with controlled porosity and material savings
Metallurgy.comment: Powder metallurgy allows tight tolerances, complex shapes, controlled microstructure without full melting.

Metallurgy.question: Which method is commonly used for concentration of ores by separating based on difference in specific gravity (density)?
Metallurgy.comment: Gravity concentration exploits density differences between ore minerals and gangue.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is commonly used to prevent corrosion of iron by sacrificial protection?
Metallurgy.a: Coating with a more noble metal like gold only
Metallurgy.b: Cathodic protection using sacrificial anodes (e.g., Zn or Mg) which corrode preferentially
Metallurgy.comment: Sacrificial anodes provide electrons to protected structure, making it the cathode and preventing oxidation.

Metallurgy.question: Which mechanism describes uniform corrosion of metals exposed to corrosive environments?
Metallurgy.b: Even attack over entire surface resulting in thinning over time
Metallurgy.comment: Uniform corrosion is generalized loss of metal across surface; various forms may be localized or selective.

Metallurgy.question: Which alloying element in steel increases hardness and hardenability and promotes carbide formation?
Metallurgy.comment: Elements like Cr, Mo, V form stable carbides and increase hardness and high-temperature strength.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is a non-ferrous alloy commonly used for bearings and contains mainly Cu, Sn and sometimes Pb?
Metallurgy.b: Bronze or Babbitt (tin/lead-based bearing alloys), brass is Cu–Zn
Metallurgy.comment: Bronze (Cu–Sn) and Babbitt alloys are used for bearings; brasses are Cu–Zn alloys used for fittings.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is true about annealed copper compared to cold-worked copper?
Metallurgy.a: Annealed copper is harder and less ductile
Metallurgy.b: Annealed copper is softer and more ductile due to recrystallization
Metallurgy.comment: Annealing restores ductility by removing strain hardening via recrystallization.

Metallurgy.question: Which method is commonly used to determine the composition of alloys qualitatively/quantitatively in metallurgy labs?
Metallurgy.a: Optical emission spectroscopy (OES) or X-ray fluorescence (XRF)
Metallurgy.comment: OES and XRF are widely used for rapid elemental analysis of metals and alloys.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following describes powder metallurgy sintering?
Metallurgy.a: Compacted metal powder is heated below melting point to bond particles and enhance properties
Metallurgy.b: Melting the entire compact to form a casting
Metallurgy.comment: Sintering allows diffusion bonding of particles to form dense components without full melting.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following describes selective leaching (dealloying) in metallurgy?
Metallurgy.a: Removal of more reactive component from an alloy (e.g., dezincification of brass) leaving porous structure
Metallurgy.comment: Selective leaching can severely weaken alloys by removing specific elements under corrosive conditions.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is a common method for scrap iron purification and recovery before remelting in steelmaking?
Metallurgy.a: Magnetic separation to remove non-metallic contaminants
Metallurgy.comment: Magnetic separation and mechanical sorting recover and prepare ferrous scrap for steel production.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is the purpose of deoxidizers (e.g., silicon, aluminium) in steelmaking?
Metallurgy.b: To combine with dissolved oxygen forming stable oxides that float as slag, reducing porosity and gas defects
Metallurgy.comment: Deoxidizers scavenge oxygen as Al₂O₃, SiO₂, etc., improving steel cleanness and mechanical properties.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following metals is primarily extracted by smelting of its oxide with carbon (carbothermic reduction) on an industrial scale?
Metallurgy.a: Copper (from oxide ores) sometimes by smelting but commonly pyrometallurgy; however aluminium requires electrolysis
Metallurgy.b: Iron (blast furnace reduction of oxides by carbon/CO)
Metallurgy.d: All of the above depending on metal
Metallurgy.comment: Carbothermic reduction is widely used (iron, some copper ores) but very reactive metals (Al) use electrolysis.

Metallurgy.question: Which metallurgical process uses molten metal stirred with inert gas or oxygen to remove impurities and homogenize composition?
Metallurgy.a: Ladle metallurgy (e.g., argon oxygen decarburization, vacuum degassing)
Metallurgy.comment: Ladle treatments refine steel composition and remove dissolved gases and impurities.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is TRUE about annealable stainless steels (e.g., 300 series Austenitic)?
Metallurgy.b: Austenitic stainless steels are generally non-magnetic and have good corrosion resistance due to Cr and Ni content
Metallurgy.comment: Austenitic stainless steels (Cr–Ni) are corrosion resistant and generally non-magnetic in annealed condition.

Metallurgy.question: Which metallurgical parameter quantifies the tendency of a metal to corrode in a specific environment electrochemically?
Metallurgy.a: Standard reduction potential (E°) and polarization behavior
Metallurgy.comment: Electrochemical potentials and kinetic polarization determine susceptibility to corrosion; more negative metals oxidize readily.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is used as a common descaling and surface pretreatment step before metal finishing (pickling)?
Metallurgy.a: Treatment with acids (e.g., dilute HCl or H₂SO₄) to remove oxides/scale
Metallurgy.comment: Acid pickling removes scale and oxides to prepare metal surfaces for further processing or plating.

Metallurgy.question: Which of the following is a typical method to recover metals from electronic waste (e-waste)?
Metallurgy.b: Combination of mechanical separation, pyrometallurgical and hydrometallurgical processes to recover precious metals
Metallurgy.comment: E-waste recycling uses multiple technologies to recover gold, silver, copper and other metals economically.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is liquid at room temperature (≈25 °C)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Mercury is the only pure metal that is liquid under standard conditions.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal forms an amalgam with many other metals and was historically used in gold extraction?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Mercury forms amalgams and was used to recover gold/silver from ores (now avoided for health reasons).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is the best conductor of electricity among common metals?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Silver has the highest electrical conductivity of all metals, though copper is commonly used for cost reasons.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is widely used for electrical transmission lines because of its combination of conductivity and lower cost/weight?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Copper provides excellent conductivity, ductility and reasonable cost, making it standard for wiring.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is highly reactive with water even at room temperature, releasing hydrogen gas?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Alkali metals (K, Na) react vigorously with water producing MOH and H₂ (e.g., 2K + 2H₂O → 2KOH + H₂).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal reacts with dilute HCl to produce hydrogen gas and metal chloride (e.g., M + 2HCl → MCl₂ + H₂)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Zinc (above H in electrochemical series) reacts with dilute acids to release H₂ (Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl₂ + H₂).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is protected from corrosion by forming a passive oxide film and is widely used in alloys (e.g., stainless steel) to provide corrosion resistance?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Chromium forms a thin, adherent Cr₂O₃ layer that imparts corrosion resistance; added to steel for stainless properties.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is amphoteric, reacting with both acids and strong bases to form soluble complexes (e.g., M + NaOH)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Aluminum oxide/hydroxide is amphoteric: reacts with acids (HCl) and with strong bases (NaOH) to form aluminate.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used as a sacrificial anode for cathodic protection of steel structures?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Zinc (or magnesium) anodes corrode preferentially, protecting the steel which becomes cathodic.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is the main component of brass when alloyed with zinc?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc; copper is the principal component providing ductility and conductivity.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Bronze is primarily an alloy of copper with which element?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Traditional bronze is copper–tin alloy (Cu–Sn) known for hardness and corrosion resistance.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal readily forms a protective aluminium oxide (Al₂O₃) film that prevents further reaction with air under ordinary conditions?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Aluminium forms an adherent oxide film that passivates the metal, preventing extensive corrosion.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is extracted from bauxite using the Bayer process followed by Hall–Héroult electrolysis?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Bauxite → Al₂O₃ (Bayer) → molten cryolite electrolysis (Hall–Héroult) → Al metal.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is magnetic in its pure form at room temperature?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Iron is ferromagnetic at room temperature; other ferromagnetic metals include cobalt and nickel.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used for electrical contacts and plating because it resists oxidation and has good conductivity?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Silver and gold are used for high-quality electrical contacts due to conductivity and corrosion resistance; gold is very costly.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is highly valuable, resists corrosion, and dissolves in aqua regia (HCl + HNO₃) forming chloroauric acid?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Gold is noble and resists single acids but dissolves in aqua regia due to formation of AuCl₄⁻ species.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which of the following metals does NOT react with dilute hydrochloric acid under normal conditions?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Copper is below hydrogen in the electrochemical series and does not react with non-oxidizing acids like dilute HCl.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is light, has a low density and is widely used in aircraft and lightweight structures?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Aluminium is lightweight, has good strength-to-weight ratio and is extensively used in aerospace and transport.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used as a catalyst in hydrogenation reactions (e.g., H₂ addition to alkenes)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Platinum, palladium and nickel are common hydrogenation catalysts (Pt and Pd are precious metals).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is known for its excellent corrosion resistance and is often used in jewelry and dental applications (also expensive)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Gold is chemically inert, tarnish-resistant and widely used in jewelry and electronics (contacts).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal has the highest melting point among the following?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Tungsten has the highest melting point of all metals (~3422 °C), used in filaments and high-temp applications.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is primarily responsible for the redox reaction in galvanic corrosion when paired with a less noble metal?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: The more noble metal always corrodes preferentially
Important Facts About Some Metals.b: The less noble (more active) metal corrodes preferentially
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: In galvanic coupling, the less noble (more active, more negative potential) metal oxidizes and corrodes.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used to galvanize steel to protect it from corrosion?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Zinc coating (galvanization) provides barrier protection and sacrificial (anodic) protection to steel.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal's oxide is amphoteric and can dissolve in both acids and bases (e.g., oxide reacts with HCl and NaOH)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Al₂O₃ is amphoteric: reacts with HCl to give AlCl₃ and with NaOH to give aluminate.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which of the following metals is a transition metal used extensively in stainless steel and as a plating metal and has symbol Ni?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Nickel (Ni) is a ferromagnetic transition metal used in alloys, plating and batteries.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is extracted on industrial scale by electrolytic reduction of molten oxide (Hall–Héroult) rather than by carbothermic reduction?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Aluminium's high affinity for oxygen makes electrical reduction in molten cryolite economically feasible; carbothermic would be impractical.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal has the property of being ‘noble’ and resists oxidation and corrosion under normal conditions?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Noble metals like gold and platinum are chemically inert and resist corrosion and oxidation.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is widely used as a protective coating for iron objects by electroplating to improve appearance and reduce corrosion?
Important Facts About Some Metals.b: Chromium (Cr) and Nickel (Ni) or Zinc (Zn) are commonly used coatings
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Chrome plating and nickel plating improve appearance and corrosion resistance; zinc galvanizing provides sacrificial protection.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used in aircraft construction for its high strength-to-weight ratio and corrosion resistance when alloyed?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Aluminium alloys (e.g., Al–Cu, Al–Zn–Mg) are standard in aerospace for lightweight strength.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is mainly obtained from its oxide by reduction with carbon in a blast furnace?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Iron oxide is reduced by coke/CO in blast furnace to produce pig iron; aluminium uses electrolytic reduction.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal readily alloys with copper to make coinage metal 'cupronickel' or other alloys and has symbol Ni?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Nickel is used in cupronickel (Cu–Ni) and other corrosion-resistant alloys.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is used as an electrode material in electrochemical cells for hydrogen evolution and generally resists oxidation (noble)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Platinum is inert, catalytically active and commonly used as electrode/catalyst in fuel cells and electrolysis.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal-based compound is responsible for the green patina on weathered copper (e.g., Statue of Liberty)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.b: Basic copper carbonate (e.g., Cu₂(OH)₂CO₃, malachite/azurite-type mixture)
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Copper weathers to form basic copper carbonates and sulfates that give a green patina (protective layer).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is used as a moderator and structural material in some nuclear reactors and has high melting point and corrosion resistance?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Zirconium alloys are used in nuclear reactors due to low neutron absorption and good corrosion resistance.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is known to be very light and is used in rechargeable batteries as a negative electrode (symbol Li)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Lithium is the lightest metal and key in lithium-ion batteries as anode material and intercalation chemistry.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal forms the green flame color in flame tests and is used in fireworks (e.g., MCl₂ gives color)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Strontium (Sr) gives red; copper (Cu) gives green/blue
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Copper compounds give blue/green flame colors; strontium gives red and barium gives green as well depending on compound.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used in automobile catalytic converters to promote oxidation/reduction of pollutants?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Pt, Pd and Rh are precious metal catalysts used in three-way catalytic converters to reduce NOx and oxidize CO/HC.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is soft, dense, and was historically used in pipes, paints and batteries but is toxic and now restricted in many applications?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Lead is toxic (neurotoxin) and its use (e.g., in pipes, paints, gasoline additives) has been greatly reduced.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is essential for hemoglobin in blood and is present in many enzymes; its deficiency leads to anemia?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Iron is central to hemoglobin (Fe²⁺) for oxygen transport; iron deficiency is a common cause of anemia.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly alloyed with iron to produce stainless steel and improve corrosion resistance?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Chromium (≥ ~11–12%) in steel gives corrosion resistance via passive Cr₂O₃ layer (stainless steel).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used in dental amalgams and historically in batteries (nickel–cadmium)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Cadmium (Cd) used in Ni–Cd batteries and as alloy component historically (toxic)
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Cadmium was used in Ni–Cd rechargeable batteries and dental alloys, but Cd is toxic and phased down in many uses.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal readily burns in air producing a bright white flame and forms MgO when heated strongly (e.g., with bunsen burner)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Magnesium burns with intense white flame forming MgO; used in flares and fireworks.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is used to plate iron to improve appearance and provide corrosion resistance giving a shiny, decorative finish?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Chrome plating (Cr) and nickel plating are common for decorative and protective finishes on automotive parts.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal forms a white precipitate with sodium hydroxide that dissolves in excess NaOH to give a soluble complex, indicating amphoteric behaviour?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Zinc (Zn) forming Zn(OH)₂ which dissolves in excess NaOH to give [Zn(OH)₄]²⁻
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Zn(OH)₂ is amphoteric: insoluble in neutral but soluble in excess base forming zincate.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used in PEM fuel cell catalysts and is considered expensive but effective?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Platinum is widely used as catalyst in fuel cells and hydrogen-related catalysis despite cost.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is used for making coins historically and now often used in alloys due to stability and antibacterial properties?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Copper and copper alloys (brass, bronze) have been used for coinage; copper has some antimicrobial action.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is used in aircraft and biomedical implants because it is strong, light and biocompatible (forms stable oxide)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Titanium has excellent strength-to-weight ratio, corrosion resistance and biocompatibility for implants.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal increases steel hardness and strength when added in small amounts and is essential in stainless tool steels?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Chromium (Cr) and Carbon (C) increase hardness; Vanadium (V) and Molybdenum (Mo) also strengthen
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Alloying elements like Cr, V, Mo form carbides and refine microstructure to enhance hardness and toughness.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is produced industrially by reducing its molten chloride in the Downs cell (electrolysis of molten salts)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: The Downs process electrolyzes molten NaCl (often with CaCl₂) to produce sodium metal and chlorine gas.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal's carbonate (e.g., CaCO₃) decomposes on strong heating (calcination) to give oxide and CO₂?
Important Facts About Some Metals.b: Calcium (Ca) as CaCO₃ → CaO + CO₂ (limestone → quicklime)
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Calcination of limestone (CaCO₃) yields CaO (quicklime) + CO₂; important in cement/lime industries.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal commonly tarnishes to form a black sulfide on exposure to hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) in air (e.g., in silverware)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Silver reacts with sulfur compounds to form Ag₂S causing dark tarnish on silver objects.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used for water pipes historically and gives a green/blue patina on long exposure (e.g., in roofing)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Copper develops green copper carbonate/sulfate patina over time; used in plumbing and roofing (e.g., Statue of Liberty).

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is prone to intergranular corrosion if contaminated with certain impurities and heat-treated incorrectly (e.g., stainless steel sensitization)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Stainless steels with chromium carbide precipitation at grain boundaries can suffer sensitization
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Sensitization of stainless steel during welding/heat treatment causes chromium depletion at grain boundaries, leading to intergranular corrosion.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal has multiple allotropic forms and is a primary component in steels and cast irons?
Important Facts About Some Metals.b: Iron (Fe) with allotropes α (ferrite), γ (austenite), δ
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Iron exhibits allotropy (α-Fe ferrite BCC, γ-Fe austenite FCC) critical to steel heat treatments.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used as a catalyst in Haber process (ammonia synthesis) and in hydrogenation and is often supported on iron or promoted with K/Ca?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Iron-based catalysts (with promoters) are central to industrial ammonia synthesis catalysis.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal's oxide is used as a white pigment (TiO₂) with high refractive index and opacity in paints and coatings?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: TiO₂ is the primary white pigment due to brightness, opacity and chemical stability.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly alloyed with copper to make bronze for historical tools and sculptures?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Bronze is traditionally Cu–Sn and was widely used in ancient tools, weapons and art.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is known to poison catalysts (e.g., catalytic converters) if present in fuel as an additive?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Lead (Pb) (historically TEL poisoned catalysts and was phased out)
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Tetraethyllead (TEL) historically poisoned catalytic converters and was phased out from petrol.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used as a radiation shield for X-rays due to its high density and high atomic number?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Lead is dense and attenuates X-rays and gamma rays effectively, used in shields and aprons.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is typically resistant to attack by nitric acid (HNO₃) making it 'noble' to that oxidizing acid?
Important Facts About Some Metals.b: Gold (Au) and platinum (Pt) resist many acids but HNO₃ oxidizes Ag, Cu etc; Au resists except aqua regia
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Gold and platinum are highly resistant; many other metals are attacked by oxidizing acids like HNO₃.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is widely used in lead–acid batteries as the negative plate material (Pb)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Lead–acid batteries use lead and lead dioxide electrodes in sulfuric acid electrolyte.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used for making thermocouples and has good high-temperature strength (e.g., Ni-based alloys)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Nickel (Ni) and nickel alloys (Inconel) have good high-T strength and are used in thermocouples and turbines
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Ni and Ni alloys are common in high-temperature applications and measurement sensors.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is used in dental fillings historically as a major component of amalgams (with mercury) but now limited due to toxicity concerns?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Silver (Ag) and mercury (Hg) were common in dental amalgams
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Dental amalgams historically contained Ag–Sn alloy mixed with Hg; use is declining due to Hg concerns.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal element is essential in small amounts for human health as part of many enzymes (e.g., Zn in Zn-finger proteins)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Zinc is an essential trace element involved in enzyme activity and gene regulation.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal gives a characteristic violet/lilac flame test color (useful in qualitative analysis)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Potassium salts give a lilac or violet flame; sodium gives intense yellow that can mask other colors.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which of the following metals is extracted by electrolysis of molten chloride rather than by reduction with carbon because it is more reactive than carbon?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Highly reactive metals (Al, Mg) are produced by molten salt electrolysis rather than carbothermic reduction.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is often alloyed with copper to form phosphor bronze used in springs and electrical contacts?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Tin (Sn) and small P additions (phosphor bronze is Cu–Sn–P)
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Phosphor bronze contains Cu, Sn and trace P for improved wear resistance and spring properties.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used in armor-piercing and high-strength applications due to very high hardness when alloyed and heat-treated (e.g., tool steels)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Iron (Fe) based tool steels alloyed with carbon, vanadium, tungsten, chromium
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Tool steels (Fe-based) with alloying elements and heat treatment yield very hard, wear-resistant materials.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is most commonly associated with the term 'stainless' when alloyed with chromium (Cr) and nickel (Ni)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Stainless steel is an iron-based alloy with Cr (and often Ni) that forms a passive oxide layer resisting corrosion.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is typically used in high-temperature turbine blades for jet engines due to creep and oxidation resistance (superalloys)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Nickel (Ni) based superalloys (often with Co and refractory elements)
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Ni-based superalloys provide strength, creep resistance and oxidation resistance at high temperatures.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal readily forms an oxide scale that peels off (non-protective) leading to rapid corrosion at high temperature unless alloyed to form protective scale?
