Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Iron (Fe) which forms flaky Fe oxides (rust) that are non-protective
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Iron oxide scales are porous and flaky, allowing continued corrosion unless protected or alloyed.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is widely used to make lightweight, high-strength alloys for aerospace when alloyed with small amounts of copper, magnesium or silicon?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Aluminium alloyed with Cu, Mg, Si etc. yields strong, lightweight materials used in aircraft structures.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly associated with the term 'precious metal' along with gold and platinum and is used in photography, jewelry and currency historically?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Silver is a precious metal used historically in coinage, jewelry and industrial applications.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is used in nuclear fuel (fission) and has isotopes like ²³⁵U useful for reactors and weapons?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Uranium, especially ²³⁵U, is fissile and used in nuclear reactors and weapons; handling requires strict regulation.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal's common oxidation states include +2 and +3 and is an essential trace element present in vitamin B12 (cobalamin)?
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Cobalt is present in vitamin B₁₂ (as Co) and has multiple oxidation states used in catalysis and alloys.

Important Facts About Some Metals.question: Which metal is commonly used for plumbing piping historically because it is malleable and corrosion-resistant in many waters, though concerns over toxicity exist for some alloys?
Important Facts About Some Metals.a: Lead (Pb) historically, but now replaced by copper (Cu) and plastic due to toxicity concerns; copper is common modern plumbing material
Important Facts About Some Metals.comment: Lead pipes were used historically; modern plumbing commonly uses copper or plastics to avoid Pb contamination.

Non Metal.question: Which element is the most abundant by mass in the Earth's crust among the following non-metals?
Non Metal.comment: Oxygen is the most abundant element in Earth's crust by mass (~46% as oxides).

Non Metal.question: What is the molecular formula of ozone?
Non Metal.comment: Ozone is a triatomic form of oxygen: O₃.

Non Metal.question: Which allotrope of carbon is a good conductor of electricity?
Non Metal.comment: Graphite has delocalized π-electrons in layers, enabling electrical conductivity.

Non Metal.question: Which of the following non-metals is essential for the formation of amino acids and proteins?
Non Metal.comment: Nitrogen is a key component of amino acids, proteins and nucleic acids.

Non Metal.question: Which industrial process synthesizes ammonia (NH₃) from N₂ and H₂?
Non Metal.comment: The Haber–Bosch process combines N₂ and H₂ at high pressure and temperature with an Fe-based catalyst to form NH₃.

Non Metal.question: Which reagent is used in the Ostwald process to convert ammonia to nitric acid (HNO₃) via oxidation?
Non Metal.b: Pt–Rh catalyst for NH₃ → NO (then to HNO₃)
Non Metal.comment: Ostwald process oxidizes NH₃ to NO over Pt–Rh catalyst; NO → NO₂ → HNO₃ in subsequent steps.

Non Metal.question: Which gas turns lime water (Ca(OH)₂) milky?
Non Metal.comment: CO₂ reacts with Ca(OH)₂ to form insoluble CaCO₃, giving a milky suspension.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms acidic oxides that produce acidic solutions in water (e.g., SO₂ → H₂SO₃)?
Non Metal.comment: Non-metallic sulfur forms acidic oxides (SO₂, SO₃) leading to acid solutions (sulfurous/sulfuric acids).

Non Metal.question: Which of the following statements about hydrogen bonding is TRUE?
Non Metal.a: It occurs between hydrogen and any atom
Non Metal.b: It occurs when H is bonded to highly electronegative atoms (F, O, N) and interacts with lone pairs on F/O/N
Non Metal.c: It is weaker than van der Waals forces
Non Metal.d: It does not affect boiling points
Non Metal.comment: Hydrogen bonding (e.g., in H₂O, HF, NH₃) is strong dipole–dipole interaction increasing b.p. and solubility.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal has the highest electronegativity (Pauling scale)?
Non Metal.comment: Fluorine is the most electronegative element (≈3.98 on Pauling scale).

Non Metal.question: Which halogen is the strongest oxidizing agent in aqueous solution under standard conditions?
Non Metal.comment: Fluorine (F₂) is the strongest oxidizer among halogens; it oxidizes water and many other substances.

Non Metal.question: Which halogen is commonly used for water disinfection in the form of its aqueous solution?
Non Metal.comment: Chlorine (as Cl₂ or hypochlorite) is widely used for municipal water disinfection.

Non Metal.question: Which product is formed when chlorine gas reacts with cold, dilute NaOH (disproportionation)?
Non Metal.comment: Cl₂ + 2NaOH (cold, dilute) → NaCl + NaClO + H₂O (chlorine disproportionates to chloride and hypochlorite).

Non Metal.question: Which gas is commonly responsible for acid rain formation when emitted from fossil fuel combustion?
Non Metal.comment: SO₂ and NOₓ oxidize in atmosphere to form H₂SO₄ and HNO₃, leading to acid rain.

Non Metal.question: Which allotrope of phosphorus is the most reactive and pyrophoric (ignites spontaneously in air)?
Non Metal.comment: White phosphorus is highly reactive and glows/ignites in air; red and black allotropes are more stable.

Non Metal.question: Which acid is produced when sulfur trioxide (SO₃) dissolves in water?
Non Metal.comment: SO₃ + H₂O → H₂SO₄ (sulfuric acid). SO₂ would give H₂SO₃ (sulfurous acid).

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal has the highest first ionization energy among the following?
Non Metal.comment: Fluorine has very high first ionization energy due to small size and high nuclear charge (among light elements).

Non Metal.question: Which reagent is used to prepare oxygen in the laboratory by decomposition of hydrogen peroxide (H₂O₂)?
Non Metal.comment: MnO₂ catalyzes decomposition: 2H₂O₂ → 2H₂O + O₂ (g).

Non Metal.question: Which of the following is NOT a typical property of non-metals?
Non Metal.comment: Malleability and ductility are metallic properties; non-metals are generally brittle (if solid).

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal element is the primary component of natural gas (major constituent)?
Non Metal.comment: Methane (CH₄) is the principal component of natural gas (~70–90%).

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal exists as diatomic molecules in elemental form at STP (standard temperature and pressure)?
Non Metal.comment: Many non-metals are diatomic (H₂, N₂, O₂, F₂, Cl₂, Br₂ as liquid/solid diatomic molecules).

Non Metal.question: Which halogen is a liquid at room temperature?
Non Metal.comment: Bromine is a reddish-brown liquid at room temperature; iodine is a solid with purple vapor.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms covalent network solid with very high hardness and high melting point (used as an abrasive)?
Non Metal.comment: Diamond (sp³ carbon network) is extremely hard with very high melting point under high pressure.

Non Metal.question: Which of the following gases is relatively insoluble in water and supports combustion vigorously?
Non Metal.comment: O₂ supports combustion; N₂ is inert under many conditions; CO₂ is used to extinguish fires.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is used widely as an inert atmosphere in high-temperature work (e.g., welding, food packaging)?
Non Metal.comment: Argon is an inert noble gas commonly used to provide non-reactive atmosphere.

Non Metal.question: Which noble gas is used in neon signs to give characteristic reddish-orange glow?
Non Metal.comment: Neon emits bright reddish-orange light in discharge tubes; other noble gases give different colors.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is a reducing agent in organic chemistry hydrogenation reactions (as H-donor) commonly used industrially as a fuel and feedstock)?
Non Metal.comment: Hydrogen gas (H₂) is a reducing agent in many hydrogenation and reduction processes.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal compound is responsible for ozone layer depletion when released as CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons) breakdown products?
Non Metal.comment: CFC photolysis releases Cl• radicals which catalytically destroy O₃ in the stratosphere.

Non Metal.question: Which of the following is a characteristic reaction of chlorine with sodium bromide (NaBr) solution?
Non Metal.b: Displacement: Cl₂ oxidizes Br⁻ to Br₂ (Cl₂ + 2Br⁻ → 2Cl⁻ + Br₂)
Non Metal.comment: Chlorine (more oxidizing) displaces bromide to produce bromine.

Non Metal.question: Which test distinguishes oxidizing acids (e.g., HNO₃) from non-oxidizing acids (e.g., HCl) by producing brown fumes (NO₂) with organic matter?
Non Metal.b: Reaction of concentrated HNO₃ with organic compounds producing nitration/oxidation and NO₂ fumes
Non Metal.comment: Concentrated HNO₃ oxidizes organics producing brown NO₂ fumes and char; distinguishing oxidizing acid behaviour.

Non Metal.question: Which acid is formed when chlorine reacts with water and undergoes disproportionation, producing antiseptic properties?
Non Metal.b: Hypochlorous acid (HOCl) along with HCl (Cl₂ + H₂O ⇌ HOCl + HCl)
Non Metal.comment: Cl₂ + H₂O ⇌ HCl + HOCl; HOCl is the active disinfectant species.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms hydrogen bonds leading to unusually high boiling point compared to its hydride series (e.g., H₂O vs H₂S)?
Non Metal.comment: H₂O exhibits strong hydrogen bonding raising b.p. much above H₂S, H₂Se, etc.

Non Metal.question: Which oxide is acidic and reacts with water to give a strong acid: SO₃ gives H₂SO₄, CO₂ gives H₂CO₃ (weak)?
Non Metal.comment: SO₃ reacts vigorously with H₂O to form strong sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄).

Non Metal.question: Which allotrope of sulfur is most stable at room temperature?
Non Metal.comment: Rhombic (S₈) is the stable form of sulfur at room temperature.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal hydride is known to be a strong reducing agent and is commonly used as a laboratory reducing reagent (e.g., LiAlH₄ reduces carbonyls)?
Non Metal.comment: LiAlH₄ is a powerful hydride donor reducing aldehydes, ketones, carboxylic acids and esters to alcohols.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal oxide is amphoteric, reacting with both acids and bases (e.g., Al₂O₃ is amphoteric but aluminium is a metal)?
Non Metal.b: Aluminium oxide (Al₂O₃) – though Al is a metal, its oxide is amphoteric
Non Metal.comment: Al₂O₃ dissolves in acids and in bases (forms aluminate), showing amphoteric behaviour.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is responsible for the pungent smell of rotten eggs (H₂S gas)?
Non Metal.comment: Hydrogen sulfide (H₂S) is a toxic gas with characteristic rotten-egg odor.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms gaseous hydrides that are generally toxic and have strong odors (e.g., H₂S, PH₃)?
Non Metal.b: Chalcogens and pnictogens (S → H₂S, P → PH₃) produce toxic hydrides
Non Metal.comment: Hydrides of heavier non-metals like S and P are often toxic and malodorous.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms a colourless, odourless and slightly soluble gas used in packaging to displace oxygen (inert atmosphere)?
Non Metal.comment: Nitrogen is inert for many purposes and is used to displace oxygen in packaging and processes.

Non Metal.question: Which of the following non-metals dissolves poorly in water but reacts with alkali to form phosphides or complex species (amphoteric behaviour of some)?
Non Metal.a: Phosphorus (P) reacts with NaOH to produce phosphine under certain conditions; white P is not soluble in water
Non Metal.comment: White phosphorus is insoluble in water and reacts under special conditions; phosphorus chemistry is complex (phosphates, phosphine, etc.).

Non Metal.question: Which oxide of nitrogen is a greenhouse gas and also involved in tropospheric photochemical smog (NO₂)?
Non Metal.comment: NO₂ contributes to smog and can form nitric acid in atmosphere; N₂O is also a potent greenhouse gas and ozone-depleting in stratosphere.

Non Metal.question: Which of the following non-metals forms a diatomic molecule having a triple bond and is relatively inert at room temperature (N≡N)?
Non Metal.comment: N₂ has a strong triple bond, making it relatively inert and requiring high energy to break (e.g., Haber process).

Non Metal.question: Which acid is formed when sulfur dioxide (SO₂) dissolves in water?
Non Metal.comment: SO₂ + H₂O → H₂SO₃ (sulfurous acid), which is a weak acid.

Non Metal.question: Which halogen forms a brown gas at room temperature and is less reactive than chlorine but more than iodine?
Non Metal.comment: Bromine is a dark red-brown liquid that produces brown vapour and is intermediate in reactivity among halogens.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is essential for the structure of DNA and is present in nucleotides as phosphate (PO₄³⁻)?
Non Metal.comment: Phosphorus in phosphate groups links nucleotides in the DNA backbone.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal reacts with hot, concentrated NaOH to produce phosphine (PH₃) and hypophosphite/phosphate depending on conditions (reaction of P with base)?
Non Metal.comment: White phosphorus reacts with NaOH to form phosphine (PH₃) and phosphite/phosphate species depending on conditions.

Non Metal.question: Which gaseous non-metal is produced industrially by fractional distillation of liquefied air?
Non Metal.b: Nitrogen (N₂) and oxygen (O₂) are major products from air distillation
Non Metal.comment: Fractional distillation of liquefied air yields N₂, O₂ and noble gases like Ar, Kr, Xe.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is commonly obtained in the laboratory by heating potassium chlorate (KClO₃) with MnO₂ catalyst to give O₂?
Non Metal.comment: 2KClO₃ → 2KCl + 3O₂ (with MnO₂ as catalyst) is a laboratory method to prepare oxygen.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms both molecular and network solids (e.g., S₈ molecular and polymeric forms)?
Non Metal.b: Sulfur (S) exhibits several allotropes including S₈ rings and polymeric sulfur
Non Metal.comment: Sulfur has many allotropes with different molecular/network structures and ring sizes.

Non Metal.question: Which compound is formed when chlorine reacts with water under sunlight producing bleaching action (used in pools)?
Non Metal.comment: Chlorine hydrolyzes to HOCl and OCl⁻ which are germicidal/bleaching agents (pH dependent).

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal hydride is a greenhouse gas and anesthetic (laughing gas)?
Non Metal.comment: Nitrous oxide (N₂O) is a greenhouse gas and has anesthetic properties; not an ordinary hydride of hydrogen with single element but a nitrogen oxide.

Non Metal.question: Which halogen produces purple vapour when heated and sublimes, and is used as an antiseptic in some forms?
Non Metal.comment: Iodine sublimes to give violet vapour and is used in antiseptics (tincture of iodine).

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal oxide is basic and reacts with acids to form salts (e.g., Na₂O + H₂SO₄ → Na₂SO₄ + H₂O)?
Non Metal.b: Na₂O (but Na₂O is basic oxide of metal sodium; non-metal oxides are usually acidic)
Non Metal.comment: Basic oxides are typically of metals (e.g., Na₂O); question contrasts typical behaviour of metal vs non-metal oxides.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is essential for respiration and is produced by plants during photosynthesis?
Non Metal.comment: Plants produce O₂ as a byproduct of photosynthesis (splitting water in light reactions).

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal reacts with metals to form interstitial compounds rather than ionic salts (e.g., N forms metal nitrides)?
Non Metal.a: N (nitrogen) can form nitrides with metals (e.g., Li₃N, TiN)
Non Metal.comment: Nitrogen can form stable metal nitrides which are often refractory and hard.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is used as the principal oxidizing agent in laboratory nitration reactions (e.g., generation of NO₂⁺)?
Non Metal.b: Concentrated HNO₃ (nitric acid) in presence of H₂SO₄ generates NO₂⁺ electrophile
Non Metal.comment: Conc. HNO₃ with H₂SO₄ generates nitronium ion (NO₂⁺) used in electrophilic aromatic nitration.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal element when bonded to carbon gives organohalide compounds that can be ozone-depleting if stable in stratosphere?
Non Metal.a: Fluorine, chlorine, bromine (particularly chlorine in CFCs)
Non Metal.comment: Chlorine-containing CFCs release Cl• in stratosphere which catalyze O₃ destruction; brominated compounds can be even more effective per atom.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms acidic oxides that are generally soluble in water to give acids (e.g., SO₃ → H₂SO₄, P₄O₁₀ → H₃PO₄)?
Non Metal.a: Non-metals like P and S form acidic oxides
Non Metal.c: Noble gases form acidic oxides readily
Non Metal.comment: Non-metal oxides (P₄O₁₀, SO₃, CO₂) produce acids in water, though CO₂ gives weak acid (H₂CO₃).

Non Metal.question: Which gas is produced when concentrated nitric acid reacts with copper metal?
Non Metal.b: NO₂ (brown fumes) and NO in some conditions
Non Metal.comment: Cu + 4HNO₃ (conc) → Cu(NO₃)₂ + 2NO₂ + 2H₂O; NO₂ brown fumes are characteristic.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is widely used as fertilizer component in the form of phosphate (PO₄³⁻) and nitrogenous compounds (NH₄⁺, NO₃⁻)?
Non Metal.comment: N and P compounds are major fertilizer components (ammonium/nitrate and phosphate salts).

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is involved in acid rain formation via atmospheric oxidation to nitric acid and sulfuric acid precursors?
Non Metal.b: Nitrogen and sulfur (as NOₓ and SO₂ emissions)
Non Metal.comment: NOₓ and SO₂ from combustion oxidize to HNO₃ and H₂SO₄ leading to acid precipitation.

Non Metal.question: Which reagent is used to detect the presence of ozone by producing a characteristic blue color with potassium iodide-starch paper?
Non Metal.a: KI–starch paper turns blue on exposure to O₃ (oxidizes I⁻ to I₂ which forms blue starch complex)
Non Metal.comment: Ozone oxidizes I⁻ to I₂ which with starch gives blue color; useful qualitative test for ozone.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal has significant allotropy including white, red and black forms and is found in both organic molecules and biological systems?
Non Metal.comment: Phosphorus has several allotropes (white, red, black) with distinct properties and reactivities.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal reacts with hydrogen to form hydrides used as reducing agents or as toxic gases (e.g., H₂S, PH₃)?
Non Metal.a: Chalcogens and pnictogens (S → H₂S, P → PH₃)
Non Metal.comment: Hydrides of non-metals (e.g., H₂S, PH₃) are common and vary in properties from acidic to basic and toxic.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal oxide absorbs ultraviolet (UV) radiation in the stratosphere protecting life on Earth?
Non Metal.comment: Stratospheric ozone (O₃) absorbs harmful UV-B and UV-C radiation, protecting living organisms.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal forms a stable covalent oxide with formula CO₂ that is acidic in water (gives H₂CO₃) and is a greenhouse gas?
Non Metal.comment: Carbon forms CO₂ which equilibrates with water to give carbonic acid; CO₂ is a major greenhouse gas.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal element is used in disinfectants and antiseptics in the form of iodine or iodophors?
Non Metal.comment: Iodine is used as an antiseptic (tincture of iodine, povidone-iodine) due to broad-spectrum antimicrobial action.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal compound is used as a bleaching agent and oxidizer in household bleach formulations (active species often OCl⁻)?
Non Metal.comment: NaOCl solutions provide hypochlorite (OCl⁻) which bleaching and disinfecting action via oxidation.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal is used as a raw material for phosphoric acid production (wet process) for fertilizers (via reaction of phosphate rock with H₂SO₄)?
Non Metal.b: Phosphate rock (contains phosphorus as Ca₃(PO₄)₂) reacts with H₂SO₄ to give H₃PO₄
Non Metal.comment: Wet-process phosphoric acid uses phosphate rock (calcium phosphate) and sulfuric acid to produce H₃PO₄ and gypsum.

Non Metal.question: Which non-metal element is essential in hemoglobin for oxygen transport (as Fe centre is metal but the non-metal ligand in oxyhemoglobin is O₂)?
Non Metal.a: Oxygen (O₂) is the transported non-metal molecule
Non Metal.comment: Oxygen (O₂) binds reversibly to the iron centre in hemoglobin enabling transport in blood.

Common Fact.question: Avogadro's number (approx.) is:
Common Fact.comment: Avogadro's number ≈ 6.02214076×10²³ entities per mole.

Common Fact.question: Universal gas constant R (value) in J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ is approximately:
Common Fact.comment: R ≈ 8.314 J·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹. (0.08206 L·atm·mol⁻¹·K⁻¹ is alternative units).

Common Fact.question: Standard temperature and pressure (STP) commonly used in older conventions is:
Common Fact.comment: STP historically = 0 °C (273.15 K) and 1 atm (101.325 kPa).

Common Fact.question: Molar volume of an ideal gas at STP (0 °C, 1 atm) is approximately:
Common Fact.comment: At 273.15 K and 1 atm, Vm ≈ 22.414 L·mol⁻¹ for an ideal gas.

Common Fact.question: pH of pure water at 25 °C is:
Common Fact.comment: Pure water is neutral with [H⁺] = 1×10⁻⁷ M, pH = 7 at 25 °C.

Common Fact.question: Which ion determines acidity/basicity in aqueous solutions?
Common Fact.comment: Acidity is due to hydronium (H₃O⁺) or proton concentration; pH = −log₁₀[H⁺].

Common Fact.question: Which of these gases is most soluble in water at 25 °C under similar partial pressures?
Common Fact.comment: CO₂ is more soluble due to chemical equilibrium forming carbonic acid/ bicarbonate species.

Common Fact.question: Which of the following is the strongest acid among them (aqueous)?
Common Fact.comment: HCl is a strong acid (completely dissociates); acetic acid and HF are weak (HF partially dissociates).

Common Fact.question: Which metal reacts vigorously with cold water to give hydroxide and hydrogen gas?
Common Fact.comment: Alkali metals (Na, K) react vigorously with water: 2Na + 2H₂O → 2NaOH + H₂↑.

Common Fact.question: Which statement about isotopes is TRUE?
Common Fact.b: Isotopes have the same number of protons but different neutrons
Common Fact.comment: Isotopes share atomic number (protons) but differ in neutron count and mass number.

Common Fact.question: The valency (common combining capacity) of oxygen in most compounds is:
Common Fact.comment: Oxygen typically forms two bonds (oxidation state −2) in most stable compounds.

Common Fact.question: Which of the following is a polar molecule?
Common Fact.comment: Water is polar due to bent geometry and unequal electron distribution; CO₂ is linear and nonpolar.

Common Fact.question: Which intermolecular force is primarily responsible for the anomalously high boiling point of water?
Common Fact.comment: Hydrogen bonds between H (bound to O) and lone pairs on neighboring O raise water's b.p.

Common Fact.question: Which of these is an example of an endothermic process?
Common Fact.comment: Melting absorbs heat (endothermic); combustion and neutralization are exothermic.

Common Fact.question: The oxidation number of sulfur in H₂SO₄ is:
Which species is the oxidizing agent in a redox reaction?
Common Fact.comment: Oxidizing agent accepts electrons and is itself reduced.

Common Fact.question: Which common laboratory reagent is used to test for reducing sugars (gives brick-red precipitate with aldehydes)?
Common Fact.comment: Fehling's solution oxidizes aldehyde groups; positive test yields red Cu₂O precipitate.

Common Fact.question: Which reagent gives a silver mirror with aldehydes (Tollens test)?
Common Fact.comment: Tollens' reagent oxidizes aldehydes to acids reducing Ag⁺ to metallic Ag (silver mirror).

Common Fact.question: Which of the following has the highest electronegativity (Pauling scale)?
Common Fact.comment: Fluorine is the most electronegative element.

Common Fact.question: Which acid is used in the laboratory to remove rust and prepare metal surfaces (common industrial acid)?
Common Fact.comment: Dilute HCl (muriatic acid) is used for pickling/ descaling iron/steel surfaces.

Common Fact.question: Which compound is commonly known as washing soda?
Common Fact.comment: Washing soda is hydrated sodium carbonate (Na₂CO₃·10H₂O).

Common Fact.question: Which household baking agent releases CO₂ on heating or reaction with acid?
Common Fact.comment: NaHCO₃ decomposes/ reacts to release CO₂ (leavening agent in baking).

Common Fact.question: Which of the following is the common name for CaO?
Common Fact.comment: Calcium oxide (CaO) is quicklime; slaked lime is Ca(OH)₂ formed by adding water.

Common Fact.question: Which chemical is commonly used as household bleach?
Common Fact.comment: Household bleach is generally an aqueous solution of NaOCl; active oxidizing species is OCl⁻/HOCl.

Common Fact.question: Which metal is commonly used to galvanize iron to protect from corrosion?
Common Fact.comment: Zinc provides sacrificial protection (anodic) and a barrier coating (galvanization).

Common Fact.question: Which gas is produced when sodium bicarbonate reacts with acetic acid (vinegar)?
Common Fact.comment: NaHCO₃ + CH₃COOH → CH₃COONa + H₂O + CO₂↑.

Common Fact.question: Which element is commonly used in thermometers (traditional mercury thermometers)?
Common Fact.comment: Mercury (Hg) was traditionally used due to its liquid range and uniform expansion; now often replaced for safety.

Common Fact.question: Which of following is the lightest element?
Common Fact.comment: Hydrogen is the lightest element (atomic number 1, atomic mass ≈1 u).

Common Fact.question: Which process converts glucose to ethanol and CO₂ anaerobically?
Common Fact.comment: Fermentation: C₆H₁₂O₆ → 2C₂H₅OH + 2CO₂ (approx) by yeast under anaerobic conditions.

Common Fact.question: Which is the major greenhouse gas produced by burning fossil fuels?
Common Fact.comment: Carbon dioxide (CO₂) is the main greenhouse gas from fossil fuel combustion contributing to global warming.

Common Fact.question: Which molecule is responsible for acidification of rain when sulfur dioxide is present in the atmosphere?
Common Fact.b: H₂SO₄ (from oxidation of SO₂ to SO₃ then to H₂SO₄)
Common Fact.comment: SO₂ oxidizes to SO₃ which forms H₂SO₄ in water droplets causing acid rain.

Common Fact.question: Which common laboratory solvent is polar protic and miscible with water (also used in beverages)?
Common Fact.comment: Ethanol is polar protic, miscible with water and widely used as solvent and beverage alcohol.

Common Fact.question: Which substance is used to neutralize acid spills in laboratories (common base)?
Common Fact.comment: NaHCO₃ is a mild base used to neutralize small acid spills safely (produces CO₂).

Common Fact.question: Which form of radiation is most penetrating and requires dense shielding (e.g., lead)?
Common Fact.comment: Gamma rays are highly penetrating electromagnetic radiation; shielding uses dense materials like lead or concrete.

Common Fact.question: Which particle has no electric charge and is found in the nucleus?
Common Fact.comment: Neutrons are neutral nucleons in atomic nuclei; protons are positively charged.

Common Fact.question: Which is the most electronegative element and often forms hydrogen fluoride (HF)?
Common Fact.comment: Fluorine is the most electronegative; HF is a strong hydrogen-bonding acid and corrosive.

Common Fact.question: Which common gas used in scuba tanks and welding is extremely soluble in lipids and can cause 'the bends' when pressure changes?
Common Fact.comment: Nitrogen dissolved in tissues under pressure can form bubbles on rapid decompression causing decompression sickness.

Common Fact.question: Which analysis gives percent composition of elements (C, H, N, S, O) in organic samples?
Common Fact.comment: Ultimate (elemental) analysis determines elemental composition by mass (C, H, N, S, O).

Common Fact.question: Which salt is commonly used to lower freezing point of water on roads (de-icing) and is inexpensive?
Common Fact.comment: NaCl is widely used as de-icer; alternatives (CaCl₂, MgCl₂) are used for very low temperatures.

Common Fact.question: Which laboratory glassware is primarily used to measure a single, precise volume of liquid?
Common Fact.comment: Volumetric flasks/pipettes are calibrated for a single accurate volume; beakers are approximate.

Common Fact.question: Which law relates pressure (P) of a gas to its temperature (T) at constant volume?
Common Fact.c: Gay-Lussac's law (pressure–temperature law: P ∝ T at constant V)
Common Fact.comment: Gay-Lussac: at constant volume, pressure is directly proportional to absolute temperature.

Common Fact.question: Which acid is used in car batteries as the electrolyte?
Common Fact.comment: Lead–acid batteries use dilute sulfuric acid as the electrolyte.

Common Fact.question: Which substance is amphoteric (reacts with both acids and bases)?
Common Fact.comment: Al(OH)₃ reacts with acids (→ Al³⁺) and bases (→ aluminate [Al(OH)₄]⁻).

Common Fact.question: Which chemical is commonly used as a desiccant (drying agent) in laboratory dessicators?
Common Fact.b: Silica gel or concentrated sulfuric acid (H₂SO₄) for strong drying
Common Fact.comment: Silica gel is common desiccant; concentrated H₂SO₄ is a strong dehydrating agent but hazardous.

Common Fact.question: Which device measures conductance or electrical conductivity of aqueous solutions?
Common Fact.comment: Conductivity meters measure ionic conductance; depends on ion concentration and mobility.

Common Fact.question: Which indicator turns pink in basic solutions and is commonly used in titrations?
Common Fact.c: Bromothymol blue (yellow in acid, blue in base)
Common Fact.comment: Phenolphthalein is colorless in acid/neutral and pink in basic solutions (approx pH>8.2).

Common Fact.question: Which common laboratory oxidizing agent is purple and loses color upon reduction (used as qualitative test)?
Common Fact.comment: KMnO₄ is purple; reduced MnO₄⁻ → Mn²⁺ (colorless/ pale pink) in acidic medium.

Common Fact.question: Which is the SI base unit for amount of substance?
Common Fact.comment: Mole (mol) is the SI unit for quantity of substance (Avogadro's number defined exactly).

Common Fact.question: Which pair constitutes a conjugate acid–base pair according to Bronsted–Lowry theory?
Common Fact.comment: HCl (acid) ⇌ H⁺ + Cl⁻ ; Cl⁻ is conjugate base of HCl.

Common Fact.question: Which reagent is commonly used to test for presence of chloride ions in solution producing a precipitate with Ag⁺?
Common Fact.b: AgNO₃ (gives white AgCl precipitate soluble in NH₃)
Common Fact.comment: AgNO₃ reacts with Cl⁻ to form AgCl(s), characteristic white precipitate.

Common Fact.question: Which chemical is commonly added to public water supplies to prevent dental caries?
Common Fact.comment: Fluoride at controlled levels strengthens enamel and reduces tooth decay; dosing is regulated.

Common Fact.question: Which of the following is true about catalysts?
Common Fact.a: Catalysts are consumed in the reaction
Common Fact.b: Catalysts increase reaction rate without being consumed and lower activation energy
Common Fact.comment: Catalysts speed up both forward and reverse rates and do not change equilibrium position (only kinetics).

Common Fact.question: Which law expresses that at constant pressure the volume of a gas is proportional to its absolute temperature?
Common Fact.b: Charles's law (V ∝ T at constant P)
Common Fact.comment: Charles's law: V/T = constant at constant pressure for ideal gases.

Common Fact.question: Which acid is used to prepare esters in Fischer esterification (acid-catalyzed)?
Common Fact.comment: Concentrated sulfuric acid acts as catalyst by protonating carbonyl and removing water to drive esterification.

Common Fact.question: Which common gas used in refrigeration and aerosols was phased out due to ozone depletion?
Common Fact.comment: CFCs release Cl• in stratosphere which catalyzes O₃ destruction; replaced by alternatives under Montreal Protocol.

Common Fact.question: Which substance is commonly used to soften hard water by precipitating calcium as an insoluble salt in industrial treatment?
Common Fact.comment: Na₂CO₃ precipitates Ca²⁺ as CaCO₃, softening water (carbonate softening).

Common Fact.question: Which common household gas is lighter than air and highly flammable (used in balloons historically but now limited)?
Common Fact.comment: Hydrogen is lighter than air and flammable; helium is now used for balloons for safety.

Common Fact.question: Which chemical reaction type is characterized by exchange of ions between two compounds in aqueous solution producing a precipitate?
Common Fact.comment: Double displacement (metathesis) can form an insoluble product (precipitate) when ions swap partners.

Common Fact.question: Which common laboratory technique separates components of a mixture based on boiling points?
Common Fact.comment: Distillation uses differences in volatility (boiling points) to separate liquids.

Man Made Substances.question: A polymer is:
Man Made Substances.a: A small molecule with low molar mass
Man Made Substances.b: A large molecule made by repeating monomer units
Man Made Substances.comment: Polymers are macromolecules composed of repeating monomeric units (e.g., polyethylene (−CH₂−)ₙ).

Man Made Substances.question: Addition polymerization differs from condensation polymerization in that addition polymerization:
Man Made Substances.b: Involves monomers with unsaturated bonds and does not release small molecules
Man Made Substances.comment: Addition polymerization (e.g., ethene → polyethylene) joins monomers without forming by-products.

Man Made Substances.question: Which of the following is a thermosetting polymer (cannot be remelted once cured)?
Man Made Substances.b: Polystyrene (PS)
Man Made Substances.comment: Thermosets like Bakelite form irreversible crosslinks during curing and do not remelt on heating.

Man Made Substances.question: High-density polyethylene (HDPE) differs from low-density polyethylene (LDPE) mainly because HDPE has:
Man Made Substances.b: Less branching and more crystalline packing
Man Made Substances.comment: HDPE has fewer branches, allowing chains to pack closely → higher density and strength than LDPE.

Man Made Substances.question: The repeating unit of polyethylene can be represented as:
Man Made Substances.b: −CH₂−
Man Made Substances.comment: Polyethylene consists of repeating −CH₂− units (formula (−CH₂−)ₙ).

Man Made Substances.question: Poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) is prepared from which monomer?
Man Made Substances.b: Vinyl chloride (CH₂=CHCl)
Man Made Substances.comment: PVC is the addition polymer of vinyl chloride (CH₂=CHCl).

Man Made Substances.question: Bakelite is a polymer obtained by condensation of:
Man Made Substances.b: Phenol and formaldehyde
Man Made Substances.comment: Bakelite (phenol–formaldehyde) is an early thermosetting plastic formed via condensation (water eliminated).

Man Made Substances.question: Teflon (PTFE) is chemically resistant because its backbone contains:
Man Made Substances.b: C–F bonds (polytetrafluoroethylene: −(CF₂−CF₂)ₙ−)
Man Made Substances.comment: PTFE's strong C–F bonds and shielding by fluorine atoms give exceptional chemical inertness and non-stick properties.

Man Made Substances.question: Nylon-6,6 is produced by condensation polymerization of hexamethylenediamine and:
Man Made Substances.b: Adipic acid (HOOC–(CH₂)₄–COOH)
Man Made Substances.comment: Nylon-6,6 forms by condensation between hexamethylenediamine and adipic acid with elimination of water.

Man Made Substances.question: Polyethylene terephthalate (PET), used in bottles and fibres, is produced from:
Man Made Substances.b: Propylene + oxygen
Man Made Substances.comment: PET is a condensation polyester from ethylene glycol (HO–CH₂–CH₂–OH) and terephthalic acid (HOOC–C₆H₄–COOH).

Man Made Substances.question: Which catalyst type is commonly used for stereospecific polymerization of polypropylene and polyethylene (producing isotactic polymers)?
Man Made Substances.b: KMnO₄
Man Made Substances.comment: Ziegler–Natta catalysts (TiCl₄ + Al(C₂H₅)₃ etc.) enable controlled stereochemistry in olefin polymerization.

Man Made Substances.question: Vulcanization of natural rubber involves adding sulfur to produce:
Man Made Substances.b: Cross-links (sulfur bridges) between polymer chains improving elasticity and strength
Man Made Substances.comment: Sulfur creates cross-links (S–S or C–S bonds) between polyisoprene chains, yielding vulcanized rubber with improved properties.

Man Made Substances.question: Natural rubber is primarily a polymer of:
Man Made Substances.b: Isoprene (cis-1,4-polyisoprene)
Man Made Substances.comment: Natural rubber is cis-1,4-polyisoprene (from isoprene monomers).

Man Made Substances.question: Buna-S (styrene–butadiene rubber) is widely used for:
Man Made Substances.b: Tyres (as synthetic rubber) due to good abrasion resistance
Man Made Substances.comment: SBR (Buna-S) is a common general-purpose synthetic rubber used especially in tyres.

Man Made Substances.question: Which recycling code corresponds to polyethylene terephthalate (PET) bottles?
Man Made Substances.comment: Recycling resin identification code 1 = PET (polyethylene terephthalate).

Man Made Substances.question: Polylactic acid (PLA) is best described as:
Man Made Substances.b: A biodegradable, bio-based polyester (from lactic acid)
Man Made Substances.comment: PLA is produced from renewable resources (corn starch) and is biodegradable under industrial composting conditions.

Man Made Substances.question: Glass is primarily an amorphous solid made of:
Man Made Substances.b: NaCl lattice
Man Made Substances.comment: Soda-lime and other commercial glasses are based on a silica (SiO₂) network.

Man Made Substances.question: Soda–lime glass typically contains significant amounts of:
Man Made Substances.a: CaO and Na₂O in addition to SiO₂
Man Made Substances.b: Pure carbon only
Man Made Substances.comment: Soda–lime glass includes Na₂O (flux) and CaO (stabilizer) with SiO₂ as the glass former.

Man Made Substances.question: Tempered glass is strengthened primarily by:
Man Made Substances.b: Controlled surface compression produced by rapid cooling of outer surfaces after heating
Man Made Substances.comment: Tempering creates compressive stresses on the surface and tensile stresses inside, increasing impact resistance.

Man Made Substances.question: Optical fibres used in telecommunications are typically made from high-purity:
Man Made Substances.b: Fused silica (SiO₂) with controlled refractive index
Man Made Substances.comment: Telecom fibres are usually made from very pure silica with doping to control refractive index for core and cladding.

Man Made Substances.question: Ceramics are best described as:
Man Made Substances.b: Inorganic, non-metallic solids that are often brittle and heat-resistant
Man Made Substances.comment: Ceramics include materials like alumina, porcelain and refractory oxides used for high-T and insulating applications.

Man Made Substances.question: Portland cement primarily forms which main binding oxide during hydration?
Man Made Substances.b: Calcium silicate hydrates (C–S–H) from CaO and SiO₂ components
Man Made Substances.comment: Hydration of clinker phases yields calcium silicate hydrates and Ca(OH)₂ which give cement strength.

Man Made Substances.question: Bakelite is commonly used for electrical fittings because it is:
Man Made Substances.b: A good electrical insulator and heat resistant
Man Made Substances.comment: Phenol–formaldehyde resins are heat resistant, hard and electrically insulating—suitable for switches and handles.

Man Made Substances.question: PMMA (polymethyl methacrylate), also called acrylic or Plexiglas, is:
Man Made Substances.a: A brittle, transparent thermoplastic used as glass substitute
Man Made Substances.b: A thermoset used for tyres
Man Made Substances.comment: PMMA is clear, lightweight and weather resistant—used in lenses, windows and signage.

Man Made Substances.question: Stereoregularity (isotactic/atactic syndiotactic) in polymers affects:
Man Made Substances.b: Crystallinity, melting point and mechanical properties
Man Made Substances.comment: Tacticity affects chain packing and hence physical properties (e.g., isotactic polypropylene is crystalline).

Man Made Substances.question: The monomer for polystyrene is:
Man Made Substances.b: Ethylene glycol
Man Made Substances.comment: Polystyrene is an addition polymer of styrene monomers.

Man Made Substances.question: Which species commonly initiates free-radical addition polymerization in industry and labs?
Man Made Substances.b: HCl
Man Made Substances.comment: Organic peroxides (e.g., benzoyl peroxide) or azo initiators generate radicals that start chain growth in addition polymers.

Man Made Substances.question: Condensation polymerization is typically characterized by:
Man Made Substances.a: Only one-step chain growth with no by-product
Man Made Substances.b: Step-growth between bifunctional monomers with elimination of small molecules (e.g., H₂O)
Man Made Substances.comment: Polyesters and polyamides form by stepwise condensation with loss of water or HCl.

Man Made Substances.question: The glass transition temperature (Tg) of a polymer is the temperature at which it:
Man Made Substances.b: Transitions from a hard glassy state to a softer rubbery state
Man Made Substances.comment: Tg marks the onset of large-scale segmental chain mobility in amorphous polymers.

Man Made Substances.question: Higher crystallinity in a polymer typically results in:
Man Made Substances.a: Lower density and weaker mechanical properties
Man Made Substances.b: Higher density, higher tensile strength and higher melting point
Man Made Substances.comment: Crystalline regions pack tightly, increasing density, strength and thermal resistance.

Man Made Substances.question: Plasticizers are added to polymers (e.g., PVC) to:
Man Made Substances.b: Increase flexibility and lower Tg by spacing polymer chains
Man Made Substances.comment: Plasticizers (e.g., phthalates historically) interpose between chains, increasing mobility and flexibility.

Man Made Substances.question: Historically used flame retardant additives that raised environmental concerns were often:
Man Made Substances.b: Brominated compounds (brominated flame retardants)
Man Made Substances.comment: Some brominated flame retardants are persistent and bioaccumulative; alternatives and regulations have increased.

Man Made Substances.question: A 'smart polymer' typically is one that:
Man Made Substances.b: Responds to external stimuli (temperature, pH, light) with a change in properties
Man Made Substances.comment: Stimuli-responsive polymers (e.g., shape-memory polymers, pH-responsive hydrogels) change behavior on triggers.

Man Made Substances.question: Elastomers are distinguished by:
Man Made Substances.b: Large elastic deformation and recovery due to flexible chain network
Man Made Substances.comment: Elastomers (rubbers) can stretch significantly and recover due to entropic elasticity and crosslinks.

Man Made Substances.question: Which process is commonly used to shape thermoplastic polymers into complex parts by injecting molten polymer into a mould?
Man Made Substances.b: Injection moulding
Man Made Substances.comment: Injection moulding is widely used for mass production of plastic parts (toys, housings, containers).

Man Made Substances.question: Extrusion as a polymer processing technique is primarily used to make:
Man Made Substances.b: Continuous profiles such as pipes, sheets and films
Man Made Substances.comment: Extrusion forces molten polymer through a die to form continuous cross-sectional shapes.

Man Made Substances.question: Blow molding is principally used to manufacture:
Man Made Substances.b: Hollow plastic bottles (e.g., PET water bottles)
Man Made Substances.comment: Blow moulding produces hollow containers by inflating a hot parison inside a mould.

Man Made Substances.question: The molecular weight (Mₙ or M_w) of a polymer primarily affects:
Man Made Substances.b: Mechanical strength, viscosity and melting behaviour
Man Made Substances.comment: Higher molecular weights generally increase strength, toughness and melt viscosity of polymers.

Man Made Substances.question: Degree of polymerization (DP) refers to:
Man Made Substances.b: Average number of repeating units in a polymer chain
Man Made Substances.comment: DP is the average count of monomeric units (n) in a polymer chain.

Man Made Substances.question: Cross-linking in polymers usually results in:
Man Made Substances.b: Higher rigidity, higher Tg and reduced solubility/meltability
Man Made Substances.comment: Cross-links restrict chain mobility, increasing stiffness and thermal resistance (e.g., vulcanized rubber).

Man Made Substances.question: Impurities or oxygen during polymer processing often cause:
Man Made Substances.b: Polymer degradation (chain scission, oxidation) leading to embrittlement
Man Made Substances.comment: Oxidation and hydrolysis can degrade polymers; stabilizers are added to mitigate such effects.

Man Made Substances.question: Antioxidants in polymer formulations serve to:
Man Made Substances.b: Scavenge radicals and prevent oxidative degradation
Man Made Substances.comment: Primary and secondary antioxidants (e.g., BHT, phosphites) protect polymers from thermal/oxidative damage.

Man Made Substances.question: Bioplastics are best defined as polymers that are:
Man Made Substances.b: Derived from renewable biomass, or biodegradable, or both
Man Made Substances.comment: Bioplastics include PLA (bio-based & biodegradable) and some materials that are bio-based but not biodegradable.

Man Made Substances.question: When PVC burns it may release corrosive gas:
Man Made Substances.b: H₂ only
Man Made Substances.comment: Combustion of chlorine-containing plastics like PVC can release HCl gas and toxic compounds.

Man Made Substances.question: PTFE (Teflon) is most noted for which property?
Man Made Substances.b: Very low coefficient of friction and high chemical resistance
Man Made Substances.comment: PTFE is non-stick, chemically inert and stable at high temperatures.

Man Made Substances.question: Nylon is classified chemically as a:
Man Made Substances.b: Polyamide (contains −CONH− linkages)
Man Made Substances.comment: Nylons are polyamides formed by condensation between diamines and diacids (amide bonds link units).

Man Made Substances.question: An example of a condensation polyamide is formed by the reaction of:
Man Made Substances.b: Hexamethylenediamine + adipic acid → Nylon-6,6 + H₂O
Man Made Substances.comment: Nylon-6,6 forms by step-growth condensation producing water as a by-product.

Man Made Substances.question: Polyesters such as PET are commonly called 'terylene' or 'Dacron' in trade names and are:
Man Made Substances.b: Condensation polymers of diacid (terephthalic acid) and diol (ethylene glycol)
Man Made Substances.comment: Polyesters arise from esterification between diacids and diols forming −COO− linkages.

Man Made Substances.question: Rayon is classified as a:
Man Made Substances.b: Regenerated cellulose (semi-synthetic fibre)
Man Made Substances.comment: Rayon is produced by chemically processing cellulose (from wood pulp) and regenerating it into fibres.

Man Made Substances.question: Cellulose acetate is produced by acetylation of cellulose and is used in:
Man Made Substances.b: Film, textiles and photographic film base
Man Made Substances.comment: Cellulose acetate (an ester of cellulose) is a semi-synthetic polymer used in fibres and film.

Man Made Substances.question: Acrylic fibres (e.g., Orlon) are mainly polymers of:
Man Made Substances.b: Ethene only
Man Made Substances.comment: Polyacrylonitrile (PAN) is the principal polymer in acrylic fibres and precursor for carbon fibres.

Man Made Substances.question: Kevlar is classified as an aramid fibre and is notable for:
Man Made Substances.b: High tensile strength and thermal stability (used in bulletproof vests)
Man Made Substances.comment: Kevlar (poly-para-phenylene terephthalamide) is a strong aromatic polyamide (aramid).

Man Made Substances.question: Carbon fibre reinforced polymer (CFRP) is an example of a:
Man Made Substances.b: Composite material with carbon fibre reinforcement in a polymer matrix
Man Made Substances.comment: CFRP combines high-strength carbon fibres with polymer matrix (epoxy, polyester) giving high strength-to-weight ratio.

Man Made Substances.question: In a composite material, the 'matrix' serves to:
Man Made Substances.b: Bind reinforcement (fibres/particles), transfer load and protect reinforcement
Man Made Substances.comment: Matrix (polymer, metal or ceramic) holds reinforcement and helps distribute stresses.

Man Made Substances.question: Fibreglass is produced by reinforcing a polymer matrix with:
Man Made Substances.b: Glass fibres (silica-based)
Man Made Substances.comment: Glass fibre reinforced plastics (GFRP) use glass fibres embedded in resins (polyester, epoxy).

Man Made Substances.question: Epoxy resins are widely used in composites and adhesives because they:
Man Made Substances.b: Exhibit strong adhesion, good chemical resistance and mechanical strength after curing
Man Made Substances.c: Are always gas at room temperature
Man Made Substances.comment: Epoxies cure with hardeners to form crosslinked thermoset networks used for structural bonding and composites.

Man Made Substances.question: Urea–formaldehyde and melamine–formaldehyde resins are commonly used as:
Man Made Substances.b: Adhesives, laminates and molded articles (thermosetting resins)
Man Made Substances.comment: UF and MF resins provide rigid, heat-resistant thermosets for plywood adhesives and laminate surfaces.

Man Made Substances.question: Silicone polymers (silicones) are characterized by which backbone?
Man Made Substances.b: Si–O–Si backbone with organic side groups
Man Made Substances.comment: Silicones (polysiloxanes) have flexible Si–O chains and are heat-resistant, flexible and water-repellent.

Man Made Substances.question: Polycarbonate (PC) plastics are known for:
Man Made Substances.a: Being brittle and low impact strength
Man Made Substances.b: High impact resistance, transparency and use in safety eyewear
Man Made Substances.comment: PC (from bisphenol A and phosgene historically) is tough, transparent and used for safety helmets and lenses.

Man Made Substances.question: Rigid PVC (uPVC) differs from flexible PVC primarily because:
Man Made Substances.b: Flexible PVC contains plasticizers whereas uPVC is unplasticized and rigid
Man Made Substances.comment: Plasticizers make PVC flexible (cables, flooring); uPVC (windows, pipes) is without plasticizers and rigid.

Man Made Substances.question: Polymer electrolytes are used in batteries and fuel cells; a distinguishing feature is that they:
Man Made Substances.b: Conduct ions (ionic conductivity) while being solid or gel-like
Man Made Substances.comment: Polymer electrolytes (PEM, solid polymer electrolytes) conduct ions and enable solid-state electrochemical devices.

Man Made Substances.question: Conducting polymers such as polyaniline are unique because they:
Man Made Substances.b: Can conduct electricity due to conjugated π-electron systems and doping
Man Made Substances.comment: Conjugated polymers become conductive upon doping (e.g., polyaniline, polythiophene).

Man Made Substances.question: Linear alkylbenzene sulfonates (LAS) are examples of:
Man Made Substances.b: Synthetic detergent surfactants used in laundry detergents
Man Made Substances.comment: LAS replaced less biodegradable branched alkylbenzene sulfonates and are common anionic surfactants.

Man Made Substances.question: One main difference between soap and synthetic detergent is that soap:
Man Made Substances.a: Works well in hard water without forming precipitate
Man Made Substances.b: Forms insoluble scum (precipitate) with Ca²⁺ and Mg²⁺ in hard water
Man Made Substances.comment: Soap (sodium/potassium salts of fatty acids) precipitate with hardness ions; detergents are formulated to resist this.

Man Made Substances.question: Biodegradable detergents are preferred because:
Man Made Substances.b: They break down more readily in the environment reducing persistent pollution
Man Made Substances.comment: Biodegradability reduces environmental accumulation and impacts on aquatic life.

Man Made Substances.question: Azo dyes are characterized by which functional group?
Man Made Substances.b: −N=N− (azo linkage)
Man Made Substances.comment: Azo dyes contain −N=N− linkages connecting aromatic systems and are widely used industrially.

Man Made Substances.question: Mechanical recycling of plastics typically involves:
Man Made Substances.b: Collection, sorting, cleaning, shredding and remelting to make new products
Man Made Substances.comment: Mechanical recycling is energy-efficient but limited by contamination and polymer property degradation on reprocessing.

Man Made Substances.question: Chemical recycling (chemical depolymerization) of polymers aims to:
Man Made Substances.b: Break polymers back into monomers or useful chemicals for remanufacture
Man Made Substances.comment: Chemical recycling (pyrolysis, glycolysis, hydrolysis) can restore monomers (e.g., PET → terephthalic acid + ethylene glycol).

Man Made Substances.question: Compostable plastics must meet standards for:
Man Made Substances.b: Biodegradation rate and disintegration under defined composting conditions
Man Made Substances.comment: Compostable materials degrade to CO₂, water and biomass under industrial composting conditions within a specified timeframe.

Man Made Substances.question: Photodegradable plastics are designed to:
Man Made Substances.b: Break down under sunlight (UV) via photo-initiated chain scission or additives
Man Made Substances.comment: Photodegradable additives promote UV-driven breakdown, but complete mineralization in environment may be limited.

Man Made Substances.question: Microplastics are:
Man Made Substances.b: Tiny plastic particles (<5 mm) resulting from fragmentation or primary manufacture (e.g., microbeads)
Man Made Substances.comment: Microplastics persist in environment and can be ingested by organisms, raising ecological concerns.

Man Made Substances.question: HALS (hindered amine light stabilizers) are additives used to:
Man Made Substances.b: Stabilize polymers against photodegradation by scavenging radicals
Man Made Substances.comment: HALS protect polymers from UV-induced radical damage, prolonging outdoor life of plastics.

Man Made Substances.question: ABS plastic is a terpolymer of acrylonitrile, butadiene and styrene; a key property is:
Man Made Substances.b: Good toughness and impact resistance with a glossy surface (used in LEGO bricks)
Man Made Substances.comment: ABS combines rigidity (styrene), toughness (butadiene) and chemical resistance (acrylonitrile).

Man Made Substances.question: Polyurethane (PU) foams are formed by reaction of polyols with:
Man Made Substances.b: Sulfuric acid
Man Made Substances.comment: Polyurethane formation involves isocyanates reacting with polyols; blowing agents create foams.

Man Made Substances.question: Isocyanates (used in PU production) are notable because they are:
Man Made Substances.b: Reactive and can be hazardous (respiratory sensitizers)
Man Made Substances.comment: Isocyanates (MDI, TDI) require careful handling due to health risks like asthma and skin sensitization.

Man Made Substances.question: Polyacrylic acid salts are the basis of superabsorbent polymers (SAPs) used in diapers; they function by:
Man Made Substances.b: Swelling and retaining large amounts of water due to ionic carboxylate groups and crosslinking
Man Made Substances.comment: Crosslinked polyacrylates absorb and retain water by osmosis and ionic interactions, swelling massively.

Man Made Substances.question: Urea (CO(NH₂)₂) is an important nitrogen fertilizer and is produced industrially from:
Man Made Substances.a: Ammonia and carbon dioxide under high pressure
Man Made Substances.b: Nitrogen gas only
Man Made Substances.comment: Urea synthesis uses NH₃ and CO₂ (from synthesis gas or refinery sources) under high pressure/temperature.

Man Made Substances.question: Neoprene is the trade name for polychloroprene; it is a synthetic rubber notable for:
Man Made Substances.b: Oil and weather resistance (used in wetsuits, gaskets)
Man Made Substances.comment: Polychloroprene (neoprene) offers good chemical, oil and weather resistance compared to natural rubber.

Man Made Substances.question: Nitrile rubber (NBR, Buna-N) is copolymer of butadiene and acrylonitrile and is especially:
Man Made Substances.b: Resistant to oils and fuels (used in O-rings and hoses)
Man Made Substances.comment: Acrylonitrile provides oil resistance; butadiene gives elasticity—NBR is widely used in automotive seals.

Man Made Substances.question: In rubber compounding, accelerators (e.g., sulfur donors, ZnO, stearic acid) serve to:
Man Made Substances.b: Speed up vulcanization and improve crosslinking efficiency
Man Made Substances.comment: Accelerators shorten vulcanization time and improve mechanical properties by efficient cross-link formation.

Man Made Substances.question: Antiozonants are added to rubber to prevent:
Man Made Substances.b: Cracking due to ozone attack in air (ozone cracking)
Man Made Substances.comment: Antiozonants (e.g., p-phenylenediamine derivatives) protect rubbers against ozone-induced surface cracks.

Man Made Substances.question: Polymer foams are described as 'closed-cell' when:
Man Made Substances.a: Cells are interconnected allowing fluid flow
Man Made Substances.b: Cells are discrete and enclosed, limiting fluid penetration (good insulation)
Man Made Substances.c: They are made only of metal
Man Made Substances.comment: Closed-cell foams trap gas in discrete pockets giving good thermal insulation; open-cell foams are permeable.

Man Made Substances.question: Which polymer is most commonly used for beverage bottles (clear, strong and recyclable)?
Man Made Substances.b: Polyvinyl chloride (PVC)
Man Made Substances.comment: PET (recycling code 1) is widely used for drink bottles due to clarity and good barrier properties.

Man Made Substances.question: Why is recycling of condensation polymers (e.g., polyesters, polyamides) often more difficult than addition polymers?
Man Made Substances.a: They are fully inert to chemical processes
Man Made Substances.b: They require chemical depolymerization or high-energy processes and properties degrade on reprocessing
Man Made Substances.comment: Condensation polymers have strong linkages and may need chemical recycling or careful reprocessing to retain properties.

Man Made Substances.question: Recent research has found enzymes (e.g., PETase) that can:
Man Made Substances.b: Biodegrade PET by hydrolyzing ester bonds under mild conditions
Man Made Substances.comment: Enzymes like PETase can hydrolyze PET to monomers, offering potential biological recycling routes.

Man Made Substances.question: Polylactic acid (PLA) is primarily produced by polymerizing:
Man Made Substances.b: Lactic acid (or its lactide) derived from fermentation of sugars
Man Made Substances.comment: PLA is a bio-based polyester prepared via ring-opening polymerization of lactide or direct polycondensation of lactic acid.

Man Made Substances.question: Thermoplastic elastomers (TPE) combine which two properties?
Man Made Substances.b: Elasticity of elastomers and processability (melt-reformable) of thermoplastics
Man Made Substances.c: Being a metal and a ceramic
Man Made Substances.comment: TPEs can be processed like thermoplastics but behave elastically at service temperatures.

Man Made Substances.question: Fillers such as calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) are added to plastics mainly to:
Man Made Substances.b: Reduce material cost, modify stiffness, and affect thermal properties
Man Made Substances.c: Make plastics melt at lower temperatures
Man Made Substances.comment: Fillers lower cost per unit, can increase stiffness, and affect dimensional stability and thermal conductivity.

Man Made Substances.question: Silver nanoparticles are sometimes incorporated into plastics for:
Man Made Substances.b: Antimicrobial properties (e.g., medical devices), raising safety/environmental concerns
Man Made Substances.comment: Ag-NPs show antimicrobial activity but their release and environmental impact are under scrutiny.

Man Made Substances.question: Hot-melt adhesives are:
Man Made Substances.a: Thermosetting adhesives that cure only by moisture
Man Made Substances.b: Thermoplastic adhesives that melt on heating and solidify on cooling
Man Made Substances.comment: Hot-melts (e.g., EVA, polyolefin) are molten for application and set on cooling—used in packaging and woodworking.

Man Made Substances.question: Solvent-based adhesives differ from water-based adhesives in that solvent-based adhesives:
Man Made Substances.a: Evaporate solvent to leave a solid bond and may have VOC emissions
Man Made Substances.b: Are always non-sticky
Man Made Substances.comment: Solvent-borne adhesives dry by evaporation of volatile organic solvents; water-based disperse polymers coagulate on drying.

Man Made Substances.question: Which synthetic polymer is commonly used for electrical insulation of wires and cables due to flexibility and dielectric properties?
Man Made Substances.b: Stainless steel
Man Made Substances.comment: PVC is widely used for cable insulation because of its dielectric properties, flexibility and flame retardance (with additives).

Man Made Substances.question: Which process is typically used to convert natural gas (methane) into hydrogen and syngas for chemical feedstocks (industrial relevance to man-made substances)?
Man Made Substances.b: Steam reforming (CH₄ + H₂O → CO + 3H₂)
Man Made Substances.comment: Steam reforming is major industrial route to H₂ and CO (syngas) used to produce ammonia, methanol, and other chemicals.

Man Made Substances.question: Which of the following is an environmental concern associated with many man-made polymers?
Man Made Substances.a: They always dissolve and disappear instantly
Man Made Substances.b: Persistence in environment, microplastic formation and accumulation in ecosystems
Man Made Substances.c: They convert to gold on sunlight exposure
Man Made Substances.comment: Durability of many plastics leads to environmental persistence and accumulation; recycling and alternatives are sought.

Man Made Substances.question: Which man-made substance is commonly used as a food-contact safe plastic when certified (clear, shatter-resistant)?
Man Made Substances.a: Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) and high-density polyethylene (HDPE) when certified for food use
Man Made Substances.b: Lead oxide
Man Made Substances.comment: PET (bottles) and HDPE (containers) are commonly approved for food contact; regulatory compliance is required.

Man Made Substances.question: Which additive in plastics reduces brittleness at low temperatures and improves impact resistance?
Man Made Substances.b: Impact modifiers (e.g., rubbery phases or elastomeric particles)
Man Made Substances.comment: Impact modifiers (e.g., elastomeric copolymers) toughen brittle plastics like polystyrene and polycarbonate.

Man Made Substances.question: Which man-made fibre is regenerated cellulose often called?
Man Made Substances.b: Rayon (viscose)
Man Made Substances.comment: Rayon (viscose) is regenerated cellulosic fibre from natural cellulose chemically converted and spun into filaments.
